learning.explanation: As an aircraft flies faster, the streamline pattern around the wing changes. Faster than about four tenths the speed of sound (M 0.4) these changes start to become significant. This phenomenon is known as compressibility. Figure 1 shows that at low speed, the streamline pattern is affected far ahead of the wing and the air has a certain distance in which to upwash. As speed increases, the wing gets closer to its leading pressure wave, and the streamline pattern is affected a shorter distance ahead so must approach the wing at a steeper angle. This change in the streamline pattern accentuates the adverse pressure gradient near the leading edge and flow separation occurs at a reduced angle of attack. Above M0.4 CLMAX decreases as seen in figure 2. The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1/2ρV2. Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes. If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes. At a constant EAS, Mach number will increase as altitude increases. Figure 3 shows the variation of stalling speed with altitude at constant load factor (n). Such a curve is called the stalling boundary for the given load factor, in which altitude is plotted against equivalent airspeed. At this load factor (1g), the aircraft cannot fly at speeds to the left of this boundary. Over the lower range of altitude, stall speed does not vary with altitude. This is because at these low altitudes, the Mach number at VS is too low for compressibility effects to be present. Eventually (approximately 30000 ft), Mach number at VS has increased with altitude to such an extent that these effects are important, and the rise in stalling speed with altitude is apparent. As altitude increases, stall speed is initially constant then increases, due to compressibility.

key_points: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i
e
wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT
learning.explanation: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i.e. wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT. It increases the cruise Mach number, the range, and the endurance of the airplane. The main features of a supercritical wing are: The upper surface is flattened but the lower surface is reflex cambered towards the trailing edge. Thus, the airflow over the upper surface is not accelerated as much as conventional airfoils, which delays the formation of the shockwave to a higher speed. Compared with a conventional airfoil section it has a larger leading-edge radius, a flatter upper surface and both positive and negative camber and enables a relatively thick wing to be used for approximately the same cruise Mach number. The curved lower surface increases the lift generated by the aft end of the airfoil and replaces some of the lift lost from the flat upper surface. Because of the rear-loaded lift generation it is often called an aft-loaded wing. The leading edge of the supercritical wing has a greater radius than traditional airfoils that suffer from excessive wave drag and the loss of longitudinal stability (tuck under). By ensuring that its profile is carefully designed any expansion waves will be reflected from the subsonic boundary back to the shockwave, thereby weakening its intensity.

key_points: In transonic flight it is the nature of the airflow behind a shock wave that determines the stability characteristics of the aircraft
Longitudinal stability is the most commonly affected form of stability
It is determined by movement of the centre of pressure, coupled with changes in the coefficient of lift and the amount of downwash acting on the tailplane
learning.explanation: In transonic flight it is the nature of the airflow behind a shock wave that determines the stability characteristics of the aircraft. Longitudinal stability is the most commonly affected form of stability. It is determined by movement of the centre of pressure, coupled with changes in the coefficient of lift and the amount of downwash acting on the tailplane. The nose-down pitching moment produced by the wing is counteracted by placing a small download on the tailplane. If the shock stall occurs, any lift aft of the shock wave is destroyed and the tailplane becomes covered in disturbed airflow. The downwash acting on the tailplane is consequently eliminated causing a smooth and radical change in its angle of attack. The angle of attack becomes more positive and the download acting on the tailplane becomes an upload which, in conjunction with the wing pitching moment, causes a violent nose-down pitching moment, known as tuck-under. The exact nature and strength of the changes in trim and stability depend on the design of the aircraft.

learning.explanation: 081.02.03.01.02: Explain how a change in alpha, aeroplane weight, manoeuvres, and centre-of-gravity (CG) position influences MCRIT. When air travels over an aerofoil in normal operation, the air above the aerofoil, near the leading edge, increases in velocity, due to the "squashing" of the streamlines together, causing a venturi effect, creating the low pressure zone that is required. This means that air is usually going faster over the top of the wing than anywhere else on the airframe. As the aircraft approaches the speed of sound, Mach 1, the air above the wing will get there first, as it is faster than the freestream airflow (TAS). In particular, it is usually the air just above the wing root, where the wing is thickest, and the streamlines get "squashed" the most, that is the first bit of air to reach the sound barrier. The TAS at which the first particle of air becomes sonic (exactly Mach 1) is called MCRIT, and is the beginning of the transonic speed regime. Above this speed, shockwaves will begin to form on various parts of the airframe. MCRIT is variable, and in particular depends on the airspeed increase over the wing. If the speed increase equates to M0.2, then the aircraft will have an MCRIT of M0.8, a higher MCRIT than if the speed increase due to the wing was M0.25, giving an MCRIT of M0.75. A higher MCRIT is better, as the drag increases rapidly just above the MCRIT, at MDD, the drag divergence speed, and we would like to fly as fast as possible with the lowest drag. The higher the angle of attack of the wing, the higher the speed increase, and therefore the lower the MCRIT. This would come from anything that increases the angle of attack, such as higher weight, or a more forward CG, which acts like increased weight due to the increased downforce from the tailplane. Effectively, bad things for performance such as increased weight or forward CG, cause a bad effect, lower MCRIT, due to increased AoA. Therefore, in this question, the more aft CG will cause a reduction in lift required by the main wing, which will require a lower angle of attack (lower lift coefficient for level flight), and the speed increase over the wing would be lower, so the aircraft can fly faster before getting shockwaves forming, thus a higher MCRIT, which is good.

learning.explanation: Critical Mach Number: (MCRIT) The critical Mach number is the Mach number of the aircraft when the speed of the airflow over some part of the aircraft first reaches the speed of sound. At high altitude, a large high-speed jet transport aircraft will be cruising at a speed marginally above its critical Mach number, and it will have a small shock wave on the wing. If such an aircraft overspeeds, the shock wave will rapidly grow larger, causing the static pressure to increase sharply in the immediate vicinity of the shock wave. The locally increased adverse pressure gradient will cause the boundary layer to separate immediately behind the shock wave. This is called a ‘shock stall’ because it results from a separated boundary layer just as the low speed stall does. Shock stall occurs when the lift coefficient, as a function of Mach number, reaches its maximum value (for a given angle of attack).

learning.explanation: As speed increases beyond the Critical Mach number (MCRIT), shock wave formation at the root of a swept-back wing will: - reduce lift forward of the CG (CP moves rearward), and - reduce downwash at the tail plane. Together, these factors will generate a nose-down pitching moment. At high Mach numbers, an aircraft will become unstable with respect to speed; instead of an increasing push force being required as speed increases, a pull force becomes necessary to prevent the aircraft accelerating further. A small increase in Mach number will give a nose-down pitch which will further increase the Mach number. This in turn leads to a further increase in the nose-down pitching moment. This unfavorable high-speed characteristic, known as “Mach Tuck”, “High Speed Tuck” or “Tuck Under” would restrict the maximum operating speed of a modern high-speed jet transport aircraft. To maintain the required stick force gradient at high Mach numbers, a Mach trim system must be fitted.

learning.explanation: The centre of pressure of an aerofoil is determined by the pressure distribution. As the speed increases through the transonic region, the pressure distribution changes and the centre of pressure will move. Above the MCRIT, the upper surface pressure continues to drop on the wing until the shock wave is reached. Instead of an increasing push force being required as speed increases, a pull force becomes necessary to prevent the aircraft accelerating further. When decelerating, the effect is reversed. The decreased shockwave formation will ease the nose-down pitch, and a decrease in speed will eventually require a nose-up trim.

Faster than about four tenths the speed of sound (M 0
learning.explanation: LOW SPEED VS. HIGH SPEED STREAMLINES (Figure 1) As an aircraft flies faster, the streamline pattern around the wing changes. Faster than about four tenths the speed of sound (M 0.4) these changes start to become significant. This phenomenon is known as compressibility. Coefficient of Lift (CL) is assumed to remain constant for a particular angle of attack at low subsonic speeds. In high subsonic speeds and the transonic speed regime, the compressibility of the air begins to take effect and, for a particular angle of attack, the coefficient of lift increases. This is because the air cannot "feel the wing coming" from as far away (due to it moving so fast), so has to react and get out of the way later. This is more aggressive and gains more lift from the air, but it also removes some of the energy from the air by doing this, and causes a much lower stalling angle of attack, and thereby decreases the CLMAX of the wing overall. This reduced stalling angle of attack is also what causes the low speed buffet boundary to get faster at high altitudes.

key_points: The terms compressibility and incompressibility describe the ability of molecules in a fluid to be compacted or compressed (made more dense) and their ability to bounce back to their original density, in other words, their "springiness
" An incompressible fluid cannot be compressed and has relatively constant density throughout
Liquid is an incompressible fluid
learning.explanation: The terms compressibility and incompressibility describe the ability of molecules in a fluid to be compacted or compressed (made more dense) and their ability to bounce back to their original density, in other words, their "springiness." An incompressible fluid cannot be compressed and has relatively constant density throughout. Liquid is an incompressible fluid. A gaseous fluid such as air, on the other hand, can be either compressible or incompressible. Generally, for theoretical and experimental purposes, gases are assumed to be incompressible when they are moving at low speeds (under approximately M0.4). The motion of the object traveling through the air at such speed does not affect the density of the air. This assumption has been useful in aerodynamics when studying the behavior of air in relation to airfoils and other objects moving through the air at slower speeds. However, when aircraft began traveling faster than M0.4, assumptions regarding the air through which they flew that were true at slower speeds were no longer valid. At high speeds some of the energy of the quickly moving aircraft goes into compressing the fluid (the air) and changing its density. The air at higher altitudes where these aircraft fly also has lower density than air nearer to the Earth's surface. The airflow is now compressible, and aerodynamic theories have had to reflect this.

learning.explanation: The critical Mach number (MCRIT) is the lower limit of a speed band, known as the transonic range, in which the local Mach number may be either subsonic or supersonic. Its value varies with the angle of attack and is the free-stream Mach number at which sonic speed is reached over the upper surface of a wing. In other words, it is the speed at which the local Mach number is equal to the free-airstream Mach number. It is also the highest speed possible without supersonic flow over the wing. The critical Mach number is inversely proportional to the angle of attack, i.e. MCRIT decreases with increasing angle of attack and vice versa. This is because, as the angle of attack increases the local peak velocity of the airflow over the wing also increases. It therefore reaches Mach 1 sooner than it would have done at a lower angle of attack; thus, the critical Mach number is less.

key_points: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag
This is caused by the formation of shock waves, which adversely affect the stability and control characteristics of the aircraft
The speed of sound is defined as the rate at which small pressure disturbances are propagated through the air, which is solely a function of air temperature
learning.explanation: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag. This is caused by the formation of shock waves, which adversely affect the stability and control characteristics of the aircraft. The speed of sound is defined as the rate at which small pressure disturbances are propagated through the air, which is solely a function of air temperature. THE DEVELOPMENT OF SHOCK WAVES When aircraft fly through the air, every part of them sets up tiny pressure disturbances, which radiate outward at the speed of sound in all directions. As Mach number increases, the flow over the wing continues to accelerate and eventually reaches a sonic value at a particular point on the wing, normally the point of maximum thickness. With increasing Mach number, this point grows into an area of supersonic flow, so the air moving over the upper surface will be moving rearward faster than the pressure disturbances can move forward. These disturbances consequently pile up on each other and form a shock wave. The overall direction of the airflow remains the same, but as it passes through the shock wave, the following changes take place: - The flow is rapidly decelerated to a subsonic Mach number. - Static pressure increases. - Temperature increases. - Density increases. - The energy of the airstream (total pressure) is greatly reduced. In fluid dynamics, the pressure coefficient is a dimensionless number that describes the relative pressures throughout a flow. The increase in pressure due to the compressibility effects created by the presence of shockwaves will lead to an increase in the pressure coefficient.

learning.explanation: CRITICAL MACH NUMBER Critical Mach Number (MCRIT): The critical Mach number is the Mach number of the aircraft when the speed of the airflow over some part of the aircraft (usually the point of maximum thickness on the aerofoil) first reaches the speed of sound. An aerofoil generates lift by accelerating air over the top surface. At small angles of attack the highest local velocity on an aircraft will usually be located at the point of maximum thickness on the wing. At increased angles of attack the local velocity will be greater and further forward. Also, if the thickness/chord ratio were greater, the local speed will be higher. Increased thickness/chord ratio and increased angle of attack cause greater accelerations over the top surface of the wing, so the Critical Mach number will decrease with increasing thickness/chord ratio or angle of attack. If we consider two aeroplanes maintaining a constant flight level and flying at the same IAS, one heavier and one lighter, the heavier aeroplane will be flying at a greater AoA in order to maintain a constant flight level. As mentioned above, a higher AofA leads to a higher airflow acceleration over the upper wing surface for the heavier aeroplane, even though both are flying at the same speed. If both aeroplanes accelerate at the same rate, the heavier aeroplane would be the first to get into a situation where the airflow over the upper surface of its wings would locally reach a sonic speed. Therefore, at the same speed, the heavier aeroplane has a lower MCRIT due to the higher AoA. In conclusion: Higher mass = lower MCRIT due to a greater AoA to maintain a level flight at a given speed. Lower mass = higher MCRIT due to a smaller AoA to maintain a level flight at a given speed.

content.question: Which of the following flight controls loses the most effectiveness after exceeding the MCRIT speed?

options.A: Spoilers
options.B: Ailerons
options.C: Rudder
options.D: Flaps

key_points: Exceeding the MCRIT speed means that the aircraft is in the transonic speed regime, and that the air going over the wing is becoming supersonic, and therefore forming a shockwave as it reduces back below supersonic speeds
The formation of the shockwave over the wing is the main focus of this question

Transonic effects do cause changes in elevator (pitch) controls due to Mach tuck, but the largest control surface change is the ailerons, as they are mounted on the main wings, and can interact quite badly with the shockwave formation
learning.explanation: Exceeding the MCRIT speed means that the aircraft is in the transonic speed regime, and that the air going over the wing is becoming supersonic, and therefore forming a shockwave as it reduces back below supersonic speeds. The formation of the shockwave over the wing is the main focus of this question. Transonic effects do cause changes in elevator (pitch) controls due to Mach tuck, but the largest control surface change is the ailerons, as they are mounted on the main wings, and can interact quite badly with the shockwave formation. When ailerons deflect downwards, they change the camber of the wing and cause further acceleration over the wing, which increases the magnitude of the shockwave. The shockwave causes shockwave induced separation behind it on the wing, and this greatly reduces the effect that ailerons can have, as they are trailing edge devices. The worst effect occurs when the section of the wing in front of the ailerons does not yet have a shockwave, so just above MCRIT, when the wing root has formed a shockwave but the thinner section near the wing tip has not. The down-going aileron can increase the camber enough to cause an isolated shockwave in that area, and this can massively reduce the lift from that section of the wing. Of course, that is the exact opposite of the desired effect, as that wing is supposed to be the one with more lift. Therefore, you get a aileron reversal effect, where you ask the aircraft to roll left but it actually rolls to the right. As for the other options: Spoilers are affected by shockwave formation, of course, but as they tend to accelerate the air over them, the shockwave would form right at the back of the spoiler, so they would have at least mostly the desired effect. The rudder is not massively affected by shockwave effects as the fin is very thin in comparison to the wing, and therefore doesn't accelerate the air as much, so shockwaves form much later, and quite evenly on either side of the fin. Flaps should not be used at transonic speeds, for so many reasons.

key_points: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1/2ρV2

Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes

learning.explanation: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1/2ρV2. Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes. If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes. At a constant EAS, Mach number will increase as altitude increases. Figure 1 shows the variation of stalling speed with altitude at constant load factor (n). Such a curve is called the stalling boundary for the given load factor, in which altitude is plotted against equivalent airspeed. At this load factor (1g), the aircraft cannot fly at speeds to the left of this boundary. Over the lower range of altitude, stall speed does not vary with altitude. This is because at these low altitudes, the Mach number at VS is too low for compressibility effects to be present. Eventually (approximately 30000 ft), Mach number at VS has increased with altitude to such an extent that these effects are important, and the rise in stalling speed with altitude is apparent. As altitude increases, stall speed is initially constant then increases, due to compressibility.

Together, these factors will generate a nose-down pitching moment

At high Mach numbers, an aircraft will become unstable with respect to speed; instead of an increasing push force being required as speed increases, a pull force becomes necessary to prevent the aircraft accelerating further
learning.explanation: As speed increases beyond the Critical Mach number (MCRIT), shock wave formation at the root of a swept-back wing will: reduce lift forward of the CG (CP moves rearward), and reduce downwash at the tail plane. Together, these factors will generate a nose-down pitching moment. At high Mach numbers, an aircraft will become unstable with respect to speed; instead of an increasing push force being required as speed increases, a pull force becomes necessary to prevent the aircraft accelerating further. A small increase in Mach number will give a nose-down pitch which will further increase the Mach number. This in turn leads to a further increase in the nose-down pitching moment. This unfavorable high-speed characteristic, known as “Mach Tuck”, “High Speed Tuck” or “Tuck Under” would restrict the maximum operating speed of a modern high-speed jet transport aircraft. learning.explanation: Note: Recent feedback from Polish ULC indicates that the option containing "light buffet" is wrong, so we have changed the correct answer to that containing "severe buffet". We think that the "light buffet" is most correct, but this seems like the next best option for us, however we cannot be sure yet. Please let us know if you see this question in the exam, what the correct answer could have been (if you can find out) and which authority you sat the exam with, thank you! When an aircraft accelerates through the transonic speed range and exceeds its Critical Mach number, a normal shock wave can form on the upper surface of the wing. This shock wave induces flow separation, causing turbulent airflow over the wing and along the fuselage. This turbulent airflow can create airframe buffet, which is felt throughout the aircraft. If the tailplane is aligned with the separated airflow, the turbulent airflow caused by the flow separation can also hit the tail of the aircraft, which may result in a change in the aerodynamic forces acting on the tail and buffet. Option a) "up wash over the tail, causing a nose down pitching moment." is not correct because the flow separation on the wing does not cause upwash over the tail, but rather turbulent airflow and a slight reduction in downwash (naturally, due to the higher airspeed). There will be a nose-down pitching moment around this time, but it is due to the AC moving on the wing and the reduction in downwash, not upwash from the shockwave.

key_points: In transonic flight it is the nature of the airflow behind a shock wave that determines the stability characteristics of the aircraft
Longitudinal stability is the most commonly affected form of stability
It is determined by movement of the centre of pressure, coupled with changes in the coefficient of lift and the amount of downwash acting on the tailplane
learning.explanation: In transonic flight it is the nature of the airflow behind a shock wave that determines the stability characteristics of the aircraft. Longitudinal stability is the most commonly affected form of stability. It is determined by movement of the centre of pressure, coupled with changes in the coefficient of lift and the amount of downwash acting on the tailplane. The nose-down pitching moment produced by the wing is counteracted by placing a small download on the tailplane. If the shock stall occurs, any lift aft of the shock wave is destroyed and the tailplane becomes covered in disturbed airflow. The downwash acting on the tailplane is consequently eliminated causing a smooth and radical change in its angle of attack. The angle of attack becomes more positive and the download acting on the tailplane becomes an upload which, in conjunction with the wing pitching moment, causes a violent nose-down pitching moment, known as tuck-under. The exact nature and strength of the changes in trim and stability depend on the design of the aircraft.

learning.explanation: Never regard any thunderstorm lightly, even when radar observers report the echoes are of light intensity. Avoiding thunderstorms is the best policy. Avoid thunderstorms by at least 20 NM => this general guideline applies even to jet fighters and large airliners. Hail and severe turbulence can exist well outside of the storm cloud. • If you plan to deviate around a thunderstorm => fly on the upwind side so that your path does not converge with the path of the storm. • Do not be tempted to try to fly under a thunderstorm, even if you can see through the rain on the other side => besides rain, hail and lighting, the area under a thunderstorm typically contains severe turbulence (including microbursts, windshear and downdrafts • Trying to fly over a developing storm is also dangerous => the rising clouds can usually outclimb your aircraft. “1. Descend to a lower altitude” CORRECT. The AOA of the wing has the greatest effect on inducing the Mach buffet, or pre-stall buffet, at either the high or low speed boundaries for the airplane. The higher the plane flies, the thinner the air and the greater the AOA required to produce the lift needed to maintain level flight. Increasing the AOA increases the speed of the airflow over the wing and the chances of Mach buffet. “4. Avoid cells by using weather radar” CORRECT. If your aircraft is equipped with a weather avoidance system, such as a weather radar, you can use it to avoid thunderstorms. You should avoid intense thunderstorms echoes by at least 20 NM. Airborne weather radar is designed for avoiding severe weather, not for penetrating it. It detects drops of precipitation. Therefore, do not try to use it to avoid instrument weather associated with clouds and fog – it does not provide any assurance of avoiding IFR weather conditions.

learning.explanation: The unfavorable characteristics associated with compressibility are due to boundary layer separation behind the shock wave (shock stall). Flow separation occurs because the boundary layer loses kinetic energy as it flows against the adverse pressure gradient. Shock wave formation increases the adverse pressure gradient so the loss of kinetic energy in the boundary layer will be greater. Increasing the kinetic energy of the boundary layer will reduce flow separation. Simple devices called vortex generators are used to re-energize the boundary layer. Vortex generators are small plates, vanes, blades, or wedges mounted in spanwise rows along the wing surface. Each vortex generator produces a vortex at its tip which will induce high energy air from the free stream flow to mix with the boundary layer, thus increasing its kinetic energy and helping it flow through the shock wave with much less separation. Vortex generators are usually located on the upper wing surface, particularly ahead of control surfaces, but may be used anywhere where separation is causing high drag or reduced control effectiveness. It should be noted that vortex generators may also be used on subsonic aircraft to prevent separation caused by high adverse pressure gradients due to the contours of the surface.

key_points: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag
This is caused by the formation of shock waves, which adversely affect the stability and control characteristics of the aircraft

learning.explanation: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag. This is caused by the formation of shock waves, which adversely affect the stability and control characteristics of the aircraft. The speed of sound is defined as the rate at which small pressure disturbances are propagated through the air, which is solely a function of air temperature. THE DEVELOPMENT OF SHOCK WAVES When aircraft fly through the air, every part of them sets up tiny pressure disturbances, which radiate outward at the speed of sound in all directions. As Mach number increases, the flow over the wing continues to accelerate and eventually reaches a sonic value at a particular point on the wing, normally the point of maximum thickness. With increasing Mach number, this point grows into an area of supersonic flow, so the air moving over the upper surface will be moving rearward faster than the pressure disturbances can move forward. These disturbances consequently pile up on each other and form a shock wave. The shock wave acts perpendicular, or normal, to the surface, and is more commonly referred to as a normal shock wave. Notably, this occurs where the flow changes from supersonic back to subsonic.

Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes

learning.explanation: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1/2 ρV2. Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes. If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes. At a constant EAS, Mach number will increase as altitude increases. Figure 1 shows the variation of stalling speed with altitude at constant load factor (n). Such a curve is called the stalling boundary for the given load factor, in which altitude is plotted against equivalent airspeed. At this load factor (1g), the aircraft cannot fly at speeds to the left of this boundary. Over the lower range of altitude, stall speed does not vary with altitude. This is because at these low altitudes, the Mach number at VS is too low for compressibility effects to be present. Eventually (approximately 30000 ft), Mach number at VS has increased with altitude to such an extent that these effects are important, and the rise in stalling speed with altitude is apparent. As altitude increases, stall speed is initially constant then increases, due to compressibility.

Together, these factors will generate a nose-down pitching moment

learning.explanation: As speed increases beyond the Critical Mach number (MCRIT), shock wave formation at the root of a swept-back wing will: reduce lift forward of the CG (CP moves rearward), and reduce downwash at the tail plane. Together, these factors will generate a nose-down pitching moment. At high Mach numbers, an aircraft will become unstable with respect to speed; instead of an increasing push force being required as speed increases, a pull force becomes necessary to prevent the aircraft accelerating further. A small increase in Mach number will give a nose-down pitch which will further increase the Mach number. This in turn leads to a further increase in the nose-down pitching moment. This unfavorable high-speed characteristic, known as “Mach Tuck”, “High Speed Tuck” or “Tuck Under” would restrict the maximum operating speed of a modern high-speed jet transport aircraft. To maintain the required stick force gradient at high Mach numbers, a Mach trim system must be fitted. It is operational at high Mach numbers in the transonic speed range. In the event of this equipment failing, the speed is limited to specified Mach number.

key_points: The critical Mach number (MCRIT) is the lower limit of a speed band, known as the transonic range, in which the local Mach number may be either subsonic or supersonic
Its value varies with the angle of attack and is the free-stream Mach number at which sonic speed is reached over the upper surface of a wing
In other words, it is the speed at which the local Mach number is equal to the free-airstream Mach number
learning.explanation: The critical Mach number (MCRIT) is the lower limit of a speed band, known as the transonic range, in which the local Mach number may be either subsonic or supersonic. Its value varies with the angle of attack and is the free-stream Mach number at which sonic speed is reached over the upper surface of a wing. In other words, it is the speed at which the local Mach number is equal to the free-airstream Mach number. It is also the highest speed possible without supersonic flow over the wing. The critical Mach number is inversely proportional to the angle of attack, i.e. MCRIT decreases with increasing angle of attack and vice versa. This is because, as the angle of attack increases the local peak velocity of the airflow over the wing also increases. It therefore reaches Mach 1 sooner than it would have done at a lower angle of attack; thus, the critical Mach number is less. At the design stage of an airplane the inclusion of some characteristics will increase the value of the critical Mach number: A thin airfoil cross-section (low thickness to chord ratio). Generally, a thicker wing with a large amount of camber has a lower critical Mach number than a thin wing with little camber because the airflow over its upper surface accelerates to a higher speed than it would over a thin wing. Therefore, an airfoil with reduced camber will have a higher MCRIT.

learning.explanation: Even slightly beyond critical Mach number (but below the drag divergence Mach number) CL/CD ratio is still higher than in low-speed range. Should the aeroplane be fitted with supercritical aerofoils, the gap between MCRIT and MDIV is greater. Consequently, modern airliners can cruise slightly above MCRIT and it is beneficial to do so. Since CL/CD ratio is still high, their speed versus drag ratio is close to maximum here, which in turn means that specific range is also close to maximum at this velocity. Remember that Specific range (SR) is the distance an aircraft travels per unit of fuel consumed. Thrust required can be calculated: TR = W x CD/CL Thus, for a given velocity thrust required reduces with increasing CL/CD, as a consequence of which fuel consumption reduces.

key_points: The centre of pressure of an aerofoil is determined by the pressure distribution
As the speed increases through the transonic region, the pressure distribution changes and the centre of pressure will move
Above the MCRIT, the upper surface pressure continues to drop on the wing until the shock wave is reached
learning.explanation: The centre of pressure of an aerofoil is determined by the pressure distribution. As the speed increases through the transonic region, the pressure distribution changes and the centre of pressure will move. Above the MCRIT, the upper surface pressure continues to drop on the wing until the shock wave is reached. This means that a greater proportion of the suction pressure will come from the rear of the wing and the centre of pressure is further aft. The aerodynamic centre moves back to the 50% chord position during transonic flight. As speed increases beyond MCRIT, shock wave formation will generate a nose-down pitching moment because there is less lift forward of the CG, and downwash on the tailplane is reduced. At high Mach numbers, an aircraft tends to become speed unstable. Instead of an increasing push force being required as speed increases, a pull force becomes necessary to prevent the aircraft accelerating further.

content.question: Regarding a normal shock wave on the upper surface of a wing, as Mach number increases towards Mach drag divergence...

options.A: the shock wave moves aft and the coefficient of lift increases.
options.B: the reduction in the local speed of sound from in front of the shock wave to behind it increases.
options.C: the coefficient of drag increases and the coefficient of lift decreases.
options.D: the shock wave intensifies and the reduction in air density from in front of the shock wave to behind it increases.

key_points: Short explanation As the aircraft approaches drag divergence, its increasing speed causes both the coefficient of lift (CL) and coefficient of drag (CD) to increase, with CL continuing to rise until the point of shock stall
Additionally, the shockwave moves aft as the Mach number increases
Behind the shockwave, the air density increases
learning.explanation: Short explanation As the aircraft approaches drag divergence, its increasing speed causes both the coefficient of lift (CL) and coefficient of drag (CD) to increase, with CL continuing to rise until the point of shock stall. Additionally, the shockwave moves aft as the Mach number increases. Behind the shockwave, the air density increases. The temperature rises, this results in a higher LSS behind the shockwave. Detailed explanation: An airplane does not have to be flying at the local speed of sound for the airflow over the wings to be supersonic. A normal shockwave can develop at any time the airplane is in the transonic speed range. The function of the wing is to accelerate the air passing over its upper surface. The airflow may be subsonic at the leading edge of the wing but can be accelerated to become supersonic by the trailing edge of the wing, despite the fact that the airplane is flying at a speed of less than Mach 1.0. This is transonic flight, which usually occurs between Mach 0.75 and Mach 1.2. At speeds less than Mach 0.75 all the airflow over the wing is subsonic and as the airplane accelerates the first shockwave will form on the upper surface at the wing root. When the air over the upper surface of the wing becomes sonic, a shockwave forms because the pressure waves over the rear of wing at the wing root are attempting to move forward and meet the air moving aft from the leading edge at exactly the same speed but in the opposite direction. The meeting point is usually just aft of the point of maximum camber because this is where the air over the upper surface of the wing is accelerating at the greatest rate. The meeting point of the two air-pressure waves is the shockwave and is where the airflow changes from being sonic or supersonic to become subsonic. Air passing through the shockwave experiences an increase of pressure, temperature, and density. If the airplane speed continues to increase the area of supersonic air on top of the wing spreads backward towards the trailing edge, resulting in the shockwave moving aft. As seen in figures 2 and 3, at speeds between M0.75 and drag divergence Mach number CL increases. This is due to the pressure distribution over the airfoil resulting from the aft movement of the shockwave.

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting
Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure
Aircraft must therefore be operated with a (safety) margin to aerodynamic buffet
learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Aircraft must therefore be operated with a (safety) margin to aerodynamic buffet. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved: - Load factor. - Mach number. - Angle of attack. - Pressure altitude. - Weight. - CG position. Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor. In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range. The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries.

key_points: Lets look at each answer and see why each is correct or incorrect: “A turbulent boundary layer produces less friction drag than a laminar one
” A turbulent boundary layer produces more friction than a laminar boundary layer
This is because the average velocity of the air close to the surface is higher than in a laminar boundary layer, this creates more skin friction and therefore increases drag
learning.explanation: Lets look at each answer and see why each is correct or incorrect: “A turbulent boundary layer produces less friction drag than a laminar one.” A turbulent boundary layer produces more friction than a laminar boundary layer. This is because the average velocity of the air close to the surface is higher than in a laminar boundary layer, this creates more skin friction and therefore increases drag. – Incorrect! “A turbulent boundary layer turns into a laminar one at the transition point.” As we can see from the figure, the laminar boundary layer can turn into a turbulent one. This process cannot be reversed, therefore once turbulent, a layer will never return to being laminar. – Incorrect! “A laminar boundary layer is thinner than a turbulent one.” A laminar boundary layer is indeed thinner than a turbulent boundary layer, as we can see from the figure. – Correct! “Compared with a turbulent boundary layer, a laminar boundary layer is better able to resist a positive pressure gradient before it seperates.” A laminar layer cannot exist when pressure is rising in the direction of the flow. On a curved surface like an airfoil where the pressure starts increasing from the point of maximum thickness, the transition from laminar to turbulent usually occurs at the point of maximum thickness. Therefore, turbulent boundary layer is actually better at resisting a positive pressure gradient. – Incorrect!

key_points: As ice accumulates on a wing's profile, it modifies its shape and negatively impacts the maximum lift coefficient (CLMAX)
This, in turn, reduces the critical angle of attack necessary for lift, thereby causing the wing to stall at a lower angle of attack
During the rotation phase of takeoff, the angle of attack is increased, and it may surpass the critical value, resulting in a stall of the wing
learning.explanation: As ice accumulates on a wing's profile, it modifies its shape and negatively impacts the maximum lift coefficient (CLMAX). This, in turn, reduces the critical angle of attack necessary for lift, thereby causing the wing to stall at a lower angle of attack. During the rotation phase of takeoff, the angle of attack is increased, and it may surpass the critical value, resulting in a stall of the wing. Further information: ICE ACCRETION The formation of ice on the surface of an aeroplane has a dramatically adverse effect on its performance. The most dangerous type of ice accretion is that which occurs when flying through cumulo-nimbus cloud or through supercooled water droplets ahead of a warm front because of its rapid accumulation. The effect that ice accretion has on an aeroplane’s performance includes: - increased mass; - decreased total lift; - decreased CLMAX (that is the most serious effect); - increased total drag; - up to 25% increased stalling speed; - reduced stalling angle; - changed aerofoil shape; - abnormal stalling characteristics. For an aeroplane in the take-off or landing configuration, ice accretion is extremely dangerous because of the close proximity of the normal operating speed to the stalling speed. Consequently, there is a very high risk of the aeroplane stalling when it is close to the ground.

Gusts, or in other word abrupt wind changes (or windshear), are known to occur close to or in thunderstorm cells, thus particularly in ITCZ, in clear air turbulence (jet streams) and in wake turbulence
learning.explanation: The Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) appears as a band of clouds (extensive Cu, Cb and thunderstorms). These areas should be avoided as they impose great risks to flight safety, namely moderate to severe icing and turbulence. Gusts, or in other word abrupt wind changes (or windshear), are known to occur close to or in thunderstorm cells, thus particularly in ITCZ, in clear air turbulence (jet streams) and in wake turbulence. If an aerofoil encounters an upgust, it will experience an increase in angle of attack. For a given gust velocity, the increment in angle increases as the aircraft TAS decreases. If the angle of attack is already large (low speed), the increment due to the gust could cause the wing to stall. Furthermore, ice on the wings can raise the stall speed in various ways. The weight of ice adds to the aeroplane’s total weight, increasing the stall speed. Ice can change the shape of the aerofoil, either by reducing the coefficient of lift or the stalling angle of attack. Even a thin coating of ice can trigger separation by disrupting the smooth flow of air.

content.question: You are the pilot flying of an aircraft currently over a holding fix and you observe that you are about to enter an area with heavy rain. How should you proactively respond to this situation?

options.A: By maintaining the aeroplane’s pitch and thrust to anticipate for any erroneous airspeed indications due to water entering the pitot tubes.
options.B: By increasing the holding speed and thrust to anticipate for the increased drag due to the film of water on the aeroplane.
options.C: By reducing the aeroplane’s pitch to anticipate for a pitch-up moment caused by water downpour on the tail.
options.D: By reducing the holding speed and thrust to prevent a potential engine flame-out caused by ingesting a lot of water.

key_points: The airframe may become contaminated by ice, frost or water either whilst it is in flight or when standing on the ground

HEAVY RAIN Heavy rain has the following effects on aeroplane performance: - The impingement and rapid accumulation of water sufficiently distorts the shape of the upper wing surface and diminishes the total lift by up to 30% of its normal value
- The impact of the rain on an aeroplane in the landing configuration decreases the aircraft’s forward speed
learning.explanation: The airframe may become contaminated by ice, frost or water either whilst it is in flight or when standing on the ground. HEAVY RAIN Heavy rain has the following effects on aeroplane performance: - The impingement and rapid accumulation of water sufficiently distorts the shape of the upper wing surface and diminishes the total lift by up to 30% of its normal value. - The impact of the rain on an aeroplane in the landing configuration decreases the aircraft’s forward speed. - When operating in such conditions a jet engine is slow to respond to rapid demands for thrust. - The mass of the rain can increase the aircraft mass momentarily. The total effect of these factors for any aeroplane experiencing such weather conditions is to produce a much lower level of performance. The mass increase raises the stalling speed, whilst the reduced lift and increased drag together reduce the forward speed achieved. An additional consideration, while not affecting stall speed, is the effect of the impact of heavy rain on the aircraft. Momentum will be lost and airspeed will decrease, requiring increased thrust. At the same time, heavy rain will also be driving the aircraft downwards.

This helps to delay the onset of flow separation and stall, particularly at the wingtips, which are prone to stalling first on swept wings
By preventing spanwise flow and promoting a more uniform flow distribution, the boundary-layer fence helps to increase the effective span of the wing and improve its overall performance

By preventing spanwise flow and promoting a more uniform flow distribution, the boundary-layer fence helps to increase the effective span of the wing and improve its overall performance.

When you engage the vertical speed mode, the FD/autopilot will attempt to maintain the specified vertical speed until you choose a different setting in autopilot, the aircraft reaches an assigned altitude set into the assigned altitude selector/alerter, or the autopilot is disconnected
learning.explanation: The autopilot's vertical speed mode allows you to perform constant-rate climbs and descents. In this mode, the vertical speed is prioritised over airspeed. When you engage the vertical speed mode, the FD/autopilot will attempt to maintain the specified vertical speed until you choose a different setting in autopilot, the aircraft reaches an assigned altitude set into the assigned altitude selector/alerter, or the autopilot is disconnected. As altitude increases and the air gets thinner, the power available and the IAS will reduce for a given pitch setting - the vertical speed will reduce for a certain pitch attitude. Consequently, the autopilot will gradually increase pitch to chase the selected vertical speed. This results in further decreased IAS. Ultimately, this could lead to a stall.

content.question: An aircraft is performing a take-off when it encounters windshear. What action should be taken?

options.A: Pitch up to a value just above stall warning alarm.
options.B: Pitch up to a value just below the stall warning.
options.C: Wait to apply full power until being stabilised in the climb.
options.D: Speed control is more important than a pitch input.

key_points: Wind shear are sudden changes in wind speed and/or wind direction

It may radically change the aerodynamic circumstances of the flight, particularly the critical phases of flight - during the final approach path and landing, take-off and initial climb-out flight paths
The aircraft may experience sudden increases and decreases in airspeed which increase the risk of stall or ground impact
learning.explanation: Wind shear are sudden changes in wind speed and/or wind direction. It may radically change the aerodynamic circumstances of the flight, particularly the critical phases of flight - during the final approach path and landing, take-off and initial climb-out flight paths. The aircraft may experience sudden increases and decreases in airspeed which increase the risk of stall or ground impact. If the presence of windshear is confirmed, delay take-off or do not continue an approach. If windshear is suspected, be especially alert to any of the danger signals and be prepared for the possibility of an inadvertent encounter. WINDSHEAR ESCAPE MANEUVER - Manual flight (Boeing 737) Disengage autopilot Push either TO/GA switch Aggressively apply maximum thrust Disengage autothrottle Simultaneously roll wings level and rotate toward an initial pitch attitude of 15º Retract speedbrakes Follow flight director TO/GA guidance (if available) Note: In all cases, the pitch attitude that results in intermittent stick shaker or initial buffet is the upper pitch attitude limit. Flight at intermittent stick shaker may be needed to obtain a positive terrain separation. Use smooth, steady controls to avoid a pitch attitude overshoot and stall.

options.B: Mach buffet characteristics.

key_points: A boundary layer fence is an aerodynamic surface that is commonly fixed to the wing, inline with the free stream airflow
The main goal of the boundary layer fence is to restrict the spanwise flow of air
A swept wing at low speed has a large amount of spanwise airflow, this is because airflow hitting the leading edge will because of the angle be forced to move towards the tip of the wing
learning.explanation: A boundary layer fence is an aerodynamic surface that is commonly fixed to the wing, inline with the free stream airflow. The main goal of the boundary layer fence is to restrict the spanwise flow of air. A swept wing at low speed has a large amount of spanwise airflow, this is because airflow hitting the leading edge will because of the angle be forced to move towards the tip of the wing. This leads to an almost completely diagonal airflow at the tip of the wing which causes it to stall first. To prevent the tip stall, the boundary layer fences are installed, which decrease the spanwise flow, and therefore improve low-speed stall characteristics.

In a stall, lift has decreased and the aircraft will start to descend because lift is now less than weight.

content.question: Which of the following statements regarding wake turbulence is correct?

options.A: Wake turbulence can be avoided by flying just below the flightpath of the aircraft ahead.
options.B: On final approach, wake turbulence is a bigger hazard in light crosswinds.
options.C: Wake turbulence is a bigger hazard at high level.
options.D: Wake turbulence is not an issue on take-off.

key_points: WAKE TURBULENCE Whenever an airplane generates lift, air spills over the wing tips from the high pressure areas below the wings to the low pressure areas above them
This flow causes rapidly rotating whirlpools of air called wingtip vortices
An aircraft generates vortices from the moment it rotates on take-off to touchdown
learning.explanation: WAKE TURBULENCE Whenever an airplane generates lift, air spills over the wing tips from the high pressure areas below the wings to the low pressure areas above them. This flow causes rapidly rotating whirlpools of air called wingtip vortices. An aircraft generates vortices from the moment it rotates on take-off to touchdown. The intensity depends on aircraft weight, speed and configuration. The greatest wake turbulence danger is produced by large, heavy airplanes operating at low speeds, high angles of attack and in a clean configuration. Although wake turbulence settles, it persists in the air for several minutes, depending on wind conditions. In light winds of 3 to 7 knots, the vortices can stay in the touchdown area, sink into your take-off or landing path, or drift over a parallel runway => Light crosswinds may cause the vortices to drift. A 3 to 5 knot crosswind will tend to keep the upwind vortex in the runway area and may cause the downwind vortex to drift toward another runway.

options.B: (1) increases; (2) decreases
options.C: (1) decreases; (1) increases
options.D: (1) decreases; (2) decreases

key_points: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does
The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack

The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost
learning.explanation: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does. The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack. The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost. Stalling of an ice contaminated tailplane could be precipitated by extension of the wing flaps. Lowering the flaps increases the downwash, and this increases the negative angle of attack of the tailplane. If the tailplane has ice contamination, this could be sufficient to cause it to stall. Recovery procedure in this situation would be to retract the flaps again, thus reducing the downwash. Take care when increasing an aircraft's forward airspeed to compensate for ice on the wings, since every knot of airspeed added to prevent wing stall brings the aircraft a knot closer to tailplane stall. Consequently, it is vital that the tailplane, like the wing, is free from contamination. This type of stall does not usually occur, but if it does, recovery is normally impossible.

options.A: density
options.B: altitude (below approximately 10000 ft)
options.C: weight
options.D: temperature

key_points: Any airplane, within the limits of its structure and the strength of the pilot, can be stalled at any airspeed
VS = √(2W ÷ p S CLMAX) The equation above well defines the factors affecting the stall speed, in summary; aircraft weight, air density, maximum lift coefficient, and the load factor
AIRCRAFT WEIGHT
learning.explanation: Any airplane, within the limits of its structure and the strength of the pilot, can be stalled at any airspeed. VS = √(2W ÷ p S CLMAX) The equation above well defines the factors affecting the stall speed, in summary; aircraft weight, air density, maximum lift coefficient, and the load factor. AIRCRAFT WEIGHT. Stall speed is proportional with the aircraft weight. Stall speed increases, as the weight increases; and decreases as the weight decreases. AIR DENSITY. Aircraft stall speeds are usually given in terms of CAS or IAS as an aircraft limitations. However, as seen in the equation above, it is actually a true airspeed which is inversely proportional with the density. Therefore, although it is constant in terms of CAS/IAS, it increases with the altitude because of the density variation. MAXIMUM LIFT COEFFICIENT. Maximum lift coefficient may be varied by high lift devices such as flaps and slats. Higher maximum lift coefficients will result in slower stall speeds. Lowest maximum lift coefficient is obtained when flaps are retracted (airplane in clean configuration), thus highest stall speed occurs in clean configuration. LOAD FACTOR. Stall speed is proportional with the load factor. It increases as the load factor increases. If VSS is the stall speed of an aircraft in steady level flight, then stall speed during maneuvers will be: VSN =√n VSS Or during a turn maneuver: VSN = VSS ÷ √ cos a

content.question:
Regarding deep stall characteristics, identify whether the following statements are correct or incorrect:
I. The combination of a wing with sweepback and a T-tail make an aeroplane prone to deep stall.
II. A stick pusher system can be fitted to an aeroplane that exhibits abnormal stall characteristics.

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: "I
The combination of a wing with sweepback and a T-tail make an aeroplane prone to deep stall
" CORRECT
learning.explanation: "I. The combination of a wing with sweepback and a T-tail make an aeroplane prone to deep stall." CORRECT. A deep stall is a dangerous phenomenon that occurs when the turbulence created by the main wing encompasses the horizontal stabilizer of the aircraft, preventing the aircraft from recovering from the stall. Aircraft with swept-back wings are prone to deep stall, regardless of horizontal stabilizer position (T-tail or low tail). T-tail will worsen recovery characteristics. Swept-forward wings at very high angle of attack are prone to deep stall as well. However, if a low horizontal tail is fitted, some pitch down moment may be produced with the help of the horizontal stabilizer since it is out of the separated turbulent wake of the wing. "II. A stick pusher system can be fitted to an aeroplane that exhibits abnormal stall characteristics." CORRECT. A stick pusher is a system that will push the stick forward, lowering the nose and therefore decreasing the angle of attack to prevent a stall. Stick pushers are typically installed where the 'natural aerodynamic stall characteristics' of the aircraft are unacceptable and do not meet the regulatory requirements.

content.question: An aircraft is de-iced on the ground in bad lighting conditions. After take-off, the crew is forced to apply higher than normal thrust to achieve the desired rate of climb. This is most likely due to…

options.A: high speed being maintained in order to avoid ice formation.
options.B: airframe contamination resulting in increased weight.
options.C: the low prevailing OAT, resulting in a higher fuel density.
options.D: the low prevailing OAT, resulting in less dense air.

key_points: The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil
- increase the roughness of the aircraft surface
- increase the weight of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil. - increase the roughness of the aircraft surface. - increase the weight of the aircraft. THE EFFECT OF CONTAMINATION ON TAKE-OFF PERFORMANCE Any wing contamination greatly affects the take-off performance of the aircraft, with the associated increase in drag not only extending the take-off run, but also reducing the aircraft's climb performance. Any increase in the stall speed may also dangerously reduce the margin to stall on take-off, and may even reach a critical level, especially when operating in turbulent conditions. The resulting increase in aircraft drag also reduces the amount of excess thrust available at a given climb speed, thus decreasing the aircraft's angle of climb. The aircraft's rate of climb is similarly reduced. With severely contaminated wings, the pitch and roll pre-stall buffet characteristics (compared to a clean wing), may occur before the stick shaker activates.

content.question: What data may be obtained from the Buffet Onset Boundary chart?

options.A: The values of the Mach number at which low speed and Mach buffet occur at different masses and altitudes.
options.B: The values of the Mach number at which low speed and shock stall occur at different masses and altitudes.
options.C: The values of MMO and VMO at different masses and altitudes.
options.D: The values of MCRIT at different masses and altitudes.

key_points: The buffet onset boundary chart has both high and low speed limits
The low speed buffet boundary marks the onset of the pre stall buffet with a 10% margin above stall speed
The high speed buffet boundary marks the onset of high speed buffeting
learning.explanation: The buffet onset boundary chart has both high and low speed limits. The low speed buffet boundary marks the onset of the pre stall buffet with a 10% margin above stall speed. The high speed buffet boundary marks the onset of high speed buffeting. This speed is Mmo most of the time, sometimes it is slightly below. These speeds come closer together as altitude increases. At a certain altitude the aircraft can encounter the so called “Coffin corner”. The speeds for high and low speed buffeting are very close together here, and thus it is easy to stall or hit Mmo. The coffin corner is a dangerous situation and is supposed to be avoided, as a slight amount of turbulence could cause the aircraft to stall. The speeds for high and low speed buffeting are dependent on weight, altitude, load factor and CG position. On the buffet onset boundary chart we will find the variables for altitude, weight and load factor. The margins between high and low speed buffeting can be decreased by: - Higher aircraft weight - Higher altitude - Higher load factor - More forward CG position

content.question: In order to reduce friction drag, some wings are designed so that, compared to a conventional aerofoil...

options.A: the transition point is further aft to have more area with laminar flow.
options.B: the transition point is further forward to have more area with turbulent flow.
options.C: the separation point is further forward, to keep the boundary layer off the wing.
options.D: the separation point is further aft to keep the boundary layer attached to the wing.

key_points: Friction drag is the drag caused by the friction between the air molecules and the boundary layer of the airfoil's surface
It is also the energy lost due to friction within the boundary layer
Very close to the surface, the air molecules are slowed down and brought to a standstill relative to the aircraft's surface
learning.explanation: Friction drag is the drag caused by the friction between the air molecules and the boundary layer of the airfoil's surface. It is also the energy lost due to friction within the boundary layer. Very close to the surface, the air molecules are slowed down and brought to a standstill relative to the aircraft's surface. All this is happening just a few millimetres of the surface. The boundary layer exists in two forms: Laminar flow is the thinnest layer, smooth and produces the least friction. Turbulent flow is unsteady, thicker, the layers become mixed and as a result produces more friction drag. The laminar layer transitions to the turbulent layer at the transition point. The airflow starts off as laminar flow, the speed increases steadily from the surface to the free stream and at some point along the airfoil's surface the airflow transits into turbulent flow. The difference in drag caused by the two states of the boundary layer is very marked about the same order of magnitude as the effect of streamlining, so it's understandable that much design effort is focussed on keeping the flow laminar for as long as possible. Thus, some aerofoils are designed to delay the transition by making it occur further aft so there is a greater area of laminar flow. But such aerofoils have their disadvantges: They produce less lift, so they tend to be used on aircraft that fly at higher speeds. The separtion point tends to move forward very quickly leading to a narrow stall region.

The maximum achievable load factor without buffet onset at FL380 at a mass of 90 tons is approximately:

learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. The aircraft must therefore be operated in such a manner that a (safety) margin exists before aerodynamic buffet will occur. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved. This is called a ‘Buffet Onset’ chart which is used by flight crews to ensure their aircraft is always operated with a specified minimum buffet margin. learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. The aircraft must therefore be operated in such a manner that a (safety) margin exists before aerodynamic buffet will occur. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved. For any given combination of mass, center of gravity position and airspeed, the maximum operating altitude is that altitude at which a normal positive acceleration increment of 0.3 g, without exceeding the buffet onset boundary, is possible. Any of the following factors reduces the margins between cruising speed and the high-speed and the low-speed buffets: - increased altitude - increased mass - increased load factor - a forward CG position - an increased bank angle

key_points: CLIMBING TURNS During a steady, level banked turn an aircraft has a tendency to overbank because the faster moving outer wing produces greater lift
During climbing and descending turns the aircraft is subject to additional rolling moments resulting from the variation in each wing’s angle of attack
Although the whole aircraft covers the same altitude during a complete turn, the wings follow differing spiral paths due to the variation in turn radius
learning.explanation: CLIMBING TURNS During a steady, level banked turn an aircraft has a tendency to overbank because the faster moving outer wing produces greater lift. During climbing and descending turns the aircraft is subject to additional rolling moments resulting from the variation in each wing’s angle of attack. Although the whole aircraft covers the same altitude during a complete turn, the wings follow differing spiral paths due to the variation in turn radius. During climbing turns, an aircraft describes an upward spiral path. Thus, the relative airflow comes downward to meet the wings, thereby reducing their angles of attack and hence their coefficients of lift. The faster moving outer wing is subject to a smaller reduction in angle of attack. This makes the net coefficient of lift higher than on the inner wing, thereby producing greater lift. Its increased velocity further enhances the lifting capability of the outer wing. An aircraft in a climbing turn therefore tends to overbank more than in a steady level turn. If necessary, utilise the ailerons to maintain the desired angle of bank.

content.question: On the rear part of the upper surface of an asymmetrical aerofoil, when the angle of attack increases, the area covered by an adverse pressure gradient (1) _____ and the speed of the airflow in that area (2) _____.

options.A: (1) increases; (2) increases
options.B: (1) increases; (2) decreases
options.C: (1) decreases; (2) increases
options.D: (1) decreases; (2) decreases

key_points: Over an aerofoil, airflow creates a series of static pressure zones, some low pressure and some high, depending on whether the air is fast or slow there

The air all arrives at "freestream" velocity, which we call the TAS, True Airspeed, but the way the streamlines of air split between top and bottom of the wing causes some to stretch away or squash towards each other, which increases or decreases the speed of the air
If you are familiar with the venturi tube, you know that air in the thin section is faster than air at the wide section, due to lower cross-sectional area
learning.explanation: Over an aerofoil, airflow creates a series of static pressure zones, some low pressure and some high, depending on whether the air is fast or slow there. The air all arrives at "freestream" velocity, which we call the TAS, True Airspeed, but the way the streamlines of air split between top and bottom of the wing causes some to stretch away or squash towards each other, which increases or decreases the speed of the air. If you are familiar with the venturi tube, you know that air in the thin section is faster than air at the wide section, due to lower cross-sectional area. Well this happens above a wing also; the streamlines some distance above the wing remain straight (they have no idea the wing has passed beneath them), but the wing squashes the other streamlines into them, therefore creating faster airflow, and lower static pressure. Also, the opposite occurs for streamlines that get further apart: the air slows down, creating a high static pressure zone. This creates a pressure pattern around the wing, which obviously changes with the angle of attack, how the wing is presented to the airflow. Notice the low pressure zone on the top of the wing; that will get stronger and further towards the leading edge (up until the stall), as it is squeezing the air streamlines more, and the air is having to go much faster. Notice also how there is little to no pressure zone at the back, which can remain like that, or become a slight high pressure zone at high angles of attack. The air wants to flow from high to low pressure (against the direction of airflow). This means we have an "adverse pressure gradient". The top surface of the wing has air flowing along it, but due to the air interacting with other nearby air particles (we call this viscosity), this airflow does not reach the surface of the wing. The particles of air on the surface of the wing are stationary, and there is an increasing amount of airflow in each subsequent particle, moving away from the wing. We call this the boundary layer. The boundary layer obviously has some slow moving air, whereas the freestream air over the wing is quite fast. When an adverse pressure gradient builds up on the top surface of the wing, the particles in the boundary layer become more and more excited to flow from the high to low pressure, which means flowing backwards along the surface of the wing. This initially turns the laminar boundary layer into a turbulent one. The problem is, as soon as pressure gradient reaches a certain threshold, the particles will begin to flow backwards uncontrollably, creating vortices which separate from the wing and creates the stall (see annex above). This is compounded by the low energy of the boundary layer at high angles of attack, causing a lower speed airflow, to make stall happen at an even lower angle of attack. In terms of this question, the area covered by an adverse pressure gradient on the top of the aerofoil gets larger with increasing angle of attack, and the pressure gradient gets stronger also. The air in that area will have lower energy, and therefore lower speed due to this, eventually causing the stall, starting at the trailing edge and moving forwards to cover the whole wing upper surface.

content.question: Just after take-off, a pilot inadvertently retracts the flaps instead of the landing gear. What are the consequences?

options.A: The take-off may be continued normally as the aeroplane has already lifted-off.
options.B: None, because in accordance with the certification requirements, an interlock prevents retracting the flaps if the gear is down.
options.C: The aeroplane will stall if the speed is lower than the stall speed in clean configuration.
options.D: The rate of climb will be increased as drag will be less than with take-off flaps.

key_points: Let's just start by stating that Flaps allow you to fly slower, but they generate a lot of extra drag
You are paying the price of slower speeds by using more power to fly, and also by having a reduced climb performance
This alone means that the pilot usually wants to retract the flaps to a clean configuration as-soon-as-possible
learning.explanation: Let's just start by stating that Flaps allow you to fly slower, but they generate a lot of extra drag. You are paying the price of slower speeds by using more power to fly, and also by having a reduced climb performance. This alone means that the pilot usually wants to retract the flaps to a clean configuration as-soon-as-possible. How soon that is, is a bit more complicated to answer. For starters, you need a specific (safe) speed for each notch of flaps to be retracted. Stall speed will increase every time you retract a notch of flaps so you want to be well above that speed before putting your hand on the flaps lever. So, in theory, the second the wheels are off the ground, you can just level off, keep flying a few feet above ground and keep accelerating until a safe speed is reached then retract flaps all the way to a clean configuration. In this case, the flaps are retracted right after take-off, when a positive rate of climb is observed (the pilot retracts the flaps when he/she should have retracted the landing gear). At this point, the speed is likely to be slower than the stall speed for a clean configuration - the aircraft may stall.
