content.question: According to CS-23 and CS-25 an aeroplane must have controllable stall characteristics and be able to recover control at or slightly beyond the stalling angle of attack. Which of the statements that follow is a factor that, if certain design measures are not taken, might hinder the ability to meet the mentioned requirements?

options.A: Straight wings tend to stall at the root first, which creates a large nose-down pitching moment.
options.B: Tapered wings tend to stall at the tips first, making the aeroplane too stable in roll.
options.C: Highly cambered aerofoils tend to provide little or NO warning when approaching the stall.
options.D: Aft swept wings tend to stall at the tips first, which may create a nose-up pitching moment.

key_points: Wing sweep is a tendency for first stalling the wingtip and a pitch-up moment
Both are unwanted stall characteristics which can lead to a deep stall
This tendency can be reduced by design modifications (wing fences, vortilons and saw tooth leading edges) which minimize the root-to-tip spanwise flow of the boundary layer
learning.explanation: Wing sweep is a tendency for first stalling the wingtip and a pitch-up moment. Both are unwanted stall characteristics which can lead to a deep stall. This tendency can be reduced by design modifications (wing fences, vortilons and saw tooth leading edges) which minimize the root-to-tip spanwise flow of the boundary layer. These devices delay tip stall. Vortex generators are also frequently used on a swept wing to delay tip stall and improve the stall characteristics. The wing root can also be encouraged to stall first. This can be done by modifying the aerofoil section at the root, fitting stall strips and by fitting less efficient leading edge flaps (Kruger flaps) to the inboard section of the wing. During the recovery ailerons can be used with smooth and coordinated application of rudder.

content.question: It is possible for the stabiliser to stall prematurely due to ice contamination. In this case...

options.A: the aeroplane will pitch down.
options.B: the aeroplane will pitch up.
options.C: longitudinal control of the aeroplane will NOT be affected.
options.D: lateral control of the aeroplane will be greatly affected.

key_points: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does
The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack

The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost
learning.explanation: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does. The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack. The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost. Stalling of an ice contaminated tailplane could be precipitated by extension of the wing flaps. Lowering the flaps increases the downwash, and this increases the negative angle of attack of the tailplane. If the tailplane has ice contamination, this could be sufficient to cause it to stall. Recovery procedure in this situation would be to retract the flaps again, thus reducing the downwash. Take care when increasing an aircraft's forward airspeed to compensate for ice on the wings, since every knot of airspeed added to prevent wing stall brings the aircraft a knot closer to tailplane stall. Consequently, it is vital that the tailplane, like the wing, is free from contamination. This type of stall does not usually occur, but if it does, recovery is normally impossible.

key_points: Since flaps significantly change the aerodynamic characteristics of the wing both by increased lift and increased drag, abnormal asymmetric operation of the augmentation device could seriously jeopardise flight safety by asymmetrically loading the wings
If the situation is allowed to progress unchecked, it will result in a pronounced roll towards the wing with the lessor amount of flap extended
In this case, it is possible that the induced roll could exceed the amount of aileron authority available and could result in a spin or other loss of control situation
learning.explanation: Since flaps significantly change the aerodynamic characteristics of the wing both by increased lift and increased drag, abnormal asymmetric operation of the augmentation device could seriously jeopardise flight safety by asymmetrically loading the wings. If the situation is allowed to progress unchecked, it will result in a pronounced roll towards the wing with the lessor amount of flap extended. In this case, it is possible that the induced roll could exceed the amount of aileron authority available and could result in a spin or other loss of control situation. In all cases of asymmetric flap, the wing with the greater amount of flap extended is producing a substantially higher amount of lift. At the same time, increased drag on the flaps-down side creates a pronounced adverse yaw situation, with the nose swinging toward the wing with most flaps deflected.

content.question: A student pilot is performing slow flight exercises at a constant altitude. They reduce speed whilst pulling the stick back to maintain altitude. As the aircraft has excellent stall characteristics, the aircraft eventually stalls and starts to descend at a constant speed, with the pilot still pulling the stick fully backwards. Select the correct statement about drag before and after the stall.

options.A: Induced drag decreases before the stall and increases sharply after, while parasite drag decreases after the stall.
options.B: Induced drag increases until the stall, then decreases slightly, while total drag continues to increase beyond the stall.
options.C: Induced drag decreases steadily until the stall, then sharply increases.
options.D: Induced drag and parasite both increase to their maximum during the stall, then decrease sharply thereafter.

key_points: Important note: At time of writing, this question has been fed back to us 3 times, all similar questions but with a few differences
The correct option has been the same or very similar in all feedback so far, and therefore we have added this as a single question

Please inform us in the comments if you see this question in the exam, and please add information about anything different you remember, along with your exam authority, thank you! As you will likely know by this point, aircraft drag at low subsonic speeds is split into 2 components, parasite drag and induced drag
learning.explanation: Important note: At time of writing, this question has been fed back to us 3 times, all similar questions but with a few differences. The correct option has been the same or very similar in all feedback so far, and therefore we have added this as a single question. Please inform us in the comments if you see this question in the exam, and please add information about anything different you remember, along with your exam authority, thank you! As you will likely know by this point, aircraft drag at low subsonic speeds is split into 2 components, parasite drag and induced drag. For unstalled flight, the induced drag decreases with speed and parasite drag increases with speed, as shown above, creating the familiar total drag graph. Therefore, as the pilot in question slows the aircraft down when close to the stall, the induced drag will increase quite significantly and the parasite drag will gradually decrease. When the aircraft does actually stall though, the rules become more complex. Induced drag is actually short for "lift-induced drag", and when the aircraft stalls, it loses a lot of lift, so therefore the lift induced drag decreases somewhat after the stall. Parasite drag, however, no longer fits the usual curve, as the aircraft now has a much larger frontal area, as it has a very high (fully stalled) angle of attack, and therefore the air is hitting the underside of the fuselage, wings and tailplane much more than previously. This is not streamlined at all, so the parasite drag increases after the stall, and the more stalled the aircraft gets, the larger the parasite drag. Together, this means that total drag continues increasing after the stall.

learning.explanation: Stall speeds are determined with the least favourible CG position. For an aircraft, this is the most forward point because then the main wing will be producing the most lift. However, the position of the CG will influence the rudder arm, and hence the rudder moment. A CG on the af limit will provide a small arm and therefore the least ability to oppose the yawing moment of the engine failure.

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting

learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Aircraft must therefore be operated with a (safety) margin to aerodynamic buffet. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved: - Load factor. - Mach number. - Angle of attack. - Pressure altitude. - Weight. - CG position. LOAD FACTOR Because load factor increases the stall speed, different curves can be drawn for all values of load factor up to the maximum permissible ‘g’, and together they constitute the set of stalling boundaries for the given aircraft. Such a set of curves is shown in attached figure. Superimposed on these curves are dashed lines representing lines of constant Mach number, showing how high Mach numbers can be achieved, even at relatively low EAS, at high altitudes. Encountering wind shear increases the load factor, which increases the stall speed. This means that the margin to the low speed buffet margin is decreased. Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor. In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range. The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries.

content.question: When considering a swept-back wing, without corrective design features, at the stall:

options.A: wing root stall will occur first, which produces a rolling moment.
options.B: tip stall will occur first, which produces a nose-up pitching moment.
options.C: tip stall will occur first, which produces a nose-down pitching moment.
options.D: leading edge stall will occur first, which produces a nose-down pitching moment.

key_points: The lift from a wing is generated by airflow over it from front to back
If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer
This causes them to be thicker and more susceptible to transition to turbulence or flow separation
learning.explanation: The lift from a wing is generated by airflow over it from front to back. If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer. This causes them to be thicker and more susceptible to transition to turbulence or flow separation. The normal tip vortice on a swept wing joins up with a leading edge separation bubble, creating a larger vortex called the Ram’s horn vortex. This vortex goes inboard along the wing’s leading edge. The downward flow from the vortex induces pressure on the boundary layer at the wingtip, whereas on straight wings the exact opposite occurs. With a swept wing, this creates a slow-moving layer of air at the wing tip. This slow-moving air will separate into disturbed flow and will then stall the tip. As the wingtips for a swept wing are positioned aft of the center of pressure (CP), the center of pressure upon a wing tip stall will move forward, creating a nose up moment. This nose up moment will further increase the Angle of Attack if not corrected in time, increasing the layer of slow-moving air, worsening the situation. Due to the decreased downwash on the elevator, the elevator could be less responsive, creating a so called deep stall. Unswept wings do not have this problem, as the CP for an unswept wing will move backwards as the aircraft approaches and exceeds CLMAX. The pitch up phenomenon is a dangerous characteristic of swept wing aircraft (with a T-tail) that move at high speed. It could result in a quickly worsening stalling situation, making it very hard to recover.

learning.explanation: SPIN RECOVERY Although the POH is the primary reference for recovery from a spin, the following can be used as a general procedure: P - Retard the throttle to idle. In most aircraft, power hampers the recovery. A - Ailerons neutral. Many pilots will attempt to recover from the spin using the ailerons. This may actually make the problem worse. R - Apply full opposite rudder. Apply rudder opposite the rotation of the spin. If you have trouble determining which way the airplane is spinning, look at your turn coordinator or turn needle. It will indicate the direction of rotation. E - Apply forward elevator. Immediately after applying opposite rudder, apply a quick forward motion on the control yoke and hold anti-spin controls until the aircraft starts to recover. D - Recover from the dive. Once you have completed the four previous steps, and the rotation stops, recover from the dive. The descent rate may be over 5000 feet per minute and the airspeed will rapidly exceed redline. Remember to neutralize the rudder after the rotation stops.

key_points: Spinning is a condition of stalled flight in which an aircraft describes a downward spiral path, and is normally the by-product of wing drop when operating near the stall
THE INCIPIENT SPIN (figures 1 and 2) If the wing drops at the stall, the resulting rolling action alters the direction of the relative airflow on to the wing
It increases the angle of attack of the down-going wing and reduces the angle of attack of the up-going wing
learning.explanation: Spinning is a condition of stalled flight in which an aircraft describes a downward spiral path, and is normally the by-product of wing drop when operating near the stall. THE INCIPIENT SPIN (figures 1 and 2) If the wing drops at the stall, the resulting rolling action alters the direction of the relative airflow on to the wing. It increases the angle of attack of the down-going wing and reduces the angle of attack of the up-going wing. The down-going wing becomes more stalled, leading to a reduction in the coefficient of lift and an increase in the coefficient of drag. Conversely, the up-going wing becomes less stalled, leading to an increase in the coefficient of lift and a reduction in the coefficient of drag. The difference in lift between the wings produces a rolling moment and the aircraft rolls in the direction of the down-going wing. The yawing moment resulting from the large difference in drag between the down-going and up-going wings further aids this. These moments lead to autorotation: the aircraft continues to roll, a side-slip develops, and the nose drops. Without corrective action, the rate of rotation steadily increases, resulting in a fully developed spin. FULLY DEVELOPED SPIN It is usual for the aircraft to rotate several times around a spin axis before settling into a steady state spin, with the final pitch attitude depending mainly on the position of the centre of gravity. The spin can be either flat or steep. This condition is reached when the rate of rotation and sink stabilise at constant values. When this occurs, the forces and moments acting are considered to be in equilibrium and the relative airflow comes vertically upward to meet the aircraft. FORWARD CG This results in a steeper spin and a faster rate of sink. This makes the recovery easier because the spin is less stable. AFT CG This results in a flatter spin and a lower rate of sink. This makes the recovery more difficult, because the spin is more stable. If the centre of gravity is aft of its permitted limits, it significantly reduces the likelihood of recovery from a settled spin condition. When an aircraft is in a steep spin rotation it is primarily in roll, whereas in a flat spin it is primarily in yaw. (figure 3)

content.question:
During training flights, it is normal to demonstrate accelerated stalls. These are carried out at speeds below 90kt and are induced by using excessive stick inputs to pull up during stall recovery. Spiral dives are also manoeuvres which are demonstrated during training flights. In this case, as the spiral dive develops, the speed is allowed to increase to 130kt. Considering the aeroplane limitations given below, which statement is correct?
VS: 45 kt
VA: 100 kt
VNO: 125 kt
VNE: 160 kt

options.A: Careful application of the elevator must be used to recover from the spiral dive in order to avoid an excessive load factor.
options.B: The aeroplane may suffer an excessive load factor and damage during the stall recovery exercises.
options.C: If too much elevator is used to recover from the spiral dive, the aeroplane may stall and enter a spin.
options.D: The rudder must be used to roll the wings level from the spiral dive, as the ailerons may cause excessive wing bending.

key_points: "The aeroplane may suffer an excessive load factor and damage during the stall recovery exercises
" Incorrect
The question's mention of "excessive" stick inputs, creates the impression that the aircraft might experience a high load factor and potential damage during recovery exercises
learning.explanation: "The aeroplane may suffer an excessive load factor and damage during the stall recovery exercises." Incorrect. The question's mention of "excessive" stick inputs, creates the impression that the aircraft might experience a high load factor and potential damage during recovery exercises. Nevertheless, the fact that they limit the speed increase to only 130 kt, well below VNE, minimizes the actual risk of structural damage. "If too much elevator is used to recover from the spiral dive, the aeroplane may stall and enter a spin." Incorrect. If excessive pulling occurs and surpasses the critical angle of attack, the aircraft will stall. However, what the examiner likely intends is that when initially employing ailerons to level the wings and recover from a spiral dive, there's no need for an "excessive" application of elevator. The essence of the statement is to emphasize not pulling too hard at the detection of a spiral dive but prioritizing leveling the wings first. It's crucial to recall that in a spiral dive, the wings are not yet stalled, making it imperative to first halt the rolling moment and then initiate a pull to recover lost altitude. In contrast, a spin involves a stall, necessitating a recovery process of pushing the control stick initially, followed by maintaining neutral ailerons and applying rudder in the opposite direction of the spin. "The rudder must be used to roll the wings level from the spiral dive, as the ailerons may cause excessive wing bending." Incorrect. In contrast to a spin, a recovery from a spiral dive involves initially leveling off to counteract the excessive static directional stability relative to lateral stability, thereby stopping the rolling moment. It's crucial to execute this maneuver cautiously to prevent any potential structural damage. If the rudder is applied before the ailerons in this situation, additional stress is imposed on the airframe because the aircraft is already in a nose-down attitude with a sideslip, further banking due to directional stability. This is why stall escape maneuvers or upset recovery procedures in commercial airliners explicitly avoid instructing the use of the rudder pedals.

content.question: An aeroplane where its CG is located forward of its Centre of Pressure suffers a premature tailplane stall as a result of ice contamination. Provided the wings do NOT stall, the outcome will be a(n)...

options.A: nose up pitch upset, the magnitude of which will depend on the location of the aeroplane’s CG.
options.B: uncommanded nose down pitch that will be accompanied by the activation of the stall warning system.
options.C: uncommanded nose up pitch that will be accompanied by the activation of the stall warning system.
options.D: nose down pitch upset, the magnitude of which will depend on the location of the aeroplane’s CG.

key_points: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does
The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack

The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost
learning.explanation: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does. The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack. The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost. Stalling of an ice contaminated tailplane could be precipitated by extension of the wing flaps. Lowering the flaps increases the downwash, and this increases the negative angle of attack of the tailplane. If the tailplane has ice contamination, this could be sufficient to cause it to stall. Recovery procedure in this situation would be to retract the flaps again, thus reducing the downwash. Take care when increasing an aircraft's forward airspeed to compensate for ice on the wings, since every knot of airspeed added to prevent wing stall brings the aircraft a knot closer to tailplane stall. Consequently, it is vital that the tailplane, like the wing, is free from contamination. This type of stall does not usually occur, but if it does, recovery is normally impossible.

content.question:
Which statements are correct or incorrect?
1) A stick pusher activates at a higher angle of attack than a stick shaker.
2) A stick pusher prevents the pilot from increasing the angle of attack further.

options.A: 1) is correct, 2) is correct.
options.B: 1) is correct, 2) is incorrect.
options.C: 1) is incorrect, 2) is correct.
options.D: 1) is incorrect, 2) is incorrect.

key_points: A stick shaker, as the name suggests shakes the control colum warning the pilot of an impeding stall
It does not apply any corrective measures
A stick pusher is a system that will push the stick forward, lowering the nose and therefore decreasing the angle of attack to prevent a stall
learning.explanation: A stick shaker, as the name suggests shakes the control colum warning the pilot of an impeding stall. It does not apply any corrective measures. A stick pusher is a system that will push the stick forward, lowering the nose and therefore decreasing the angle of attack to prevent a stall. The stick pushers will automatically disengage when the angle of attack reaches below a suitable value. Stick pushers are mandatory for aircraft that are prone to deep stalls. For an aircraft mounted with both the stick shaker system and stick pusher system, the sequence of events is as follows: First as a warning of impeding stall, the stick shaker will activate and a corrective action by the pilot is expected. As the angle of attack keeps increasing and reaches a pre set dangerous value that might be unrecoverable, the stick pusher will activate and force the nose down. The stick shaker will stay active during the entire duration of the stick pusher, but not vice versa. Therefore the stick shaker activates at a lower angle of attack than the stick pusher, and the stick pusher prevents the pilot from increasing the angle of attack further.

Refer to figure.
The two aeroplanes from the annex have conventional flight controls but different design principles. On a manually flown approach, they are instructed by ATC to go-around, which requires a change in pitch attitude from +2° to approximately +12°, whilst maintaining speed. The pilots in both aeroplanes select full thrust, which makes aeroplane 1...

options.A: pitch up, requiring a push force to maintain the climb attitude, while aeroplane 2 requires a pull force to counteract the pitching motion caused by the engines.
options.B: and aeroplane 2 pitch up since they are statically speed-stable, requiring only small control inputs by the pilots in order to refine the appropriate attitude and speed.
options.C: accelerate, unless a slight pull force is applied to achieve the climb attitude, while aeroplane 2 requires a push force to prevent over-rotation and speed loss.
options.D: and aeroplane 2 require a pull force to achieve the appropriate attitude and speed since they are statically stable and resist moving from the trimmed position.

key_points: In this scenario, it is all about the engine location
Aeroplane 1 has a high tail-mounted engine design, whereas aeroplane 2 has underslung wing-mounted engines
This means that the two aircraft will be affected by thrust changes in different ways
learning.explanation: In this scenario, it is all about the engine location. Aeroplane 1 has a high tail-mounted engine design, whereas aeroplane 2 has underslung wing-mounted engines. This means that the two aircraft will be affected by thrust changes in different ways. We call the high mounted engines on aeroplane 1 "thrust stabilising", as they produce thrust through or above the line of our CG, so cause a small pitch down moment when extra thrust is applied, which gains airspeed. The underslung engines on aeroplane 2 have a much lower thrust line, so the aircraft will pitch up significantly when thrust is increased. This is a de-stabilising effect, as the airspeed may actually reduce with increased engine thrust, due to the pitch up moment. In the go-around then, aircraft 1 will handle as expected, with full thrust causing an acceleration, and pitch up command required to achieve the +12º go-around attitude. In aircraft 2, it is highly likely that applying full power will pitch the aeroplane so much nose up that the pilots will have to push on the controls to avoid over-rotating and losing valuable speed. Note: there are a few other questions with this (or a very similar) graphic, so make sure to read the question and options carefully. We can pretty much guarantee that the examiner will mix and match some options to catch out people who mistake the question for a different one.

content.question:
Regarding deep stall characteristics, identify whether the following statements are correct or incorrect:
I. The combination of a wing with sweepback and a T-tail make an aeroplane prone to deep stall.
II. A stick shaker system is fitted to an aeroplane to resolve deep stall problems.

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: "I
The combination of a wing with sweepback and a T-tail make an aeroplane prone to deep stall
" CORRECT
learning.explanation: "I. The combination of a wing with sweepback and a T-tail make an aeroplane prone to deep stall." CORRECT. A deep stall is a dangerous phenomenon that occurs when the turbulence created by the main wing encompasses the horizontal stabilizer of the aircraft, preventing the aircraft from recovering from the stall. Aircraft with swept-back wings are prone to deep stall, regardless of horizontal stabilizer position (T-tail or low tail). T-tail will worsen recovery characteristics. Swept-forward wings at very high angle of attack are prone to deep stall as well. However, if a low horizontal tail is fitted, some pitch down moment may be produced with the help of the horizontal stabilizer since it is out of the separated turbulent wake of the wing. "II. A stick shaker system is fitted to an aeroplane to resolve deep stall problems." INCORRECT A stick shaker, as the name suggests shakes the control colum warning the pilot of an impeding stall. It does not apply any corrective measures.

Imagine you're approaching a microburst at 80 knots
As you enter the vortex ring, you experience turbulence and a rapid increase in IAS as you pick up a headwind

As you enter the vortex ring, you experience turbulence and a rapid increase in IAS as you pick up a headwind. You start to climb as your performance increases. 2. As you enter the strongest part of the horizontal shaft, your airspeed peaks at 100 knots, an increase of 20 knots. You're still climbing as you enter the downdraft. 3. content.question: Both CS-23 and CS-25 specifications state that an aeroplane must have sufficient controllability at and just above the critical angle of attack to aid in stall recovery. Which of the following statements identifies a consideration which could influence the stall handling characteristics, unless particular design measures are taken to avoid this?

options.A: High-wing aeroplane tend to have a greater pitch-up tendency, as an aeroplane progressively pitches up.
options.B: Supercritical aerofoils may increase the pitch-up tendency when compared to traditional cambered aerofoils.
options.C: Aft-fuselage mounted engines have a large pitching moment when thrust is increased during the recovery.
options.D: The vertical position of the horizontal stabiliser may affect the ability to recover, in particular a T-tail design.

key_points: This question is asking about handling characteristics at the stall, and the correct answer is in reference to deep stalls
A deep stall happens when an aircraft main wing stalls, but the angle of airflow means that the stalled air flows directly over the horizontal tailplane
This usually happens on T-tail aircraft, as the tail often becomes about level with the wing at critical angle of attack
learning.explanation: This question is asking about handling characteristics at the stall, and the correct answer is in reference to deep stalls. A deep stall happens when an aircraft main wing stalls, but the angle of airflow means that the stalled air flows directly over the horizontal tailplane. This usually happens on T-tail aircraft, as the tail often becomes about level with the wing at critical angle of attack. This turbulent flow will mean that there is little or no elevator control, and the horizontal stabiliser is not producing any controllable lift. This can leave the aircraft without any pitch control, causing a potentially unrecoverable deep stall (a.k.a. a super stall). Aircraft with deep stall characteristics are often fitted with a stick-pusher to avoid reaching that point. The other design feature they could ask about is underslung engines. Underslung engines are mounted under the main wings, as is most common on modern jets. When thrust is increased on these engines, a very large pitch-up moment is induced, due to their thrust line being far below the centre of gravity. As thrust is often added to recover from a stall, this could cause an upwards pitch which could overpower even full nose-down pitch control at low speeds. We call this thrust line "destabilising". The high mounted tail engines seen on many smaller jets are not susceptible to this effect, as they have a high thrust line and a "stabilising" thrust moment.

options.C: maintain lateral stability because symmetrical thrust will NOT cause control problems.

A spin occurs when one wing stalls more than the other
The wing that is more stalled will drop and the nose of the aircraft will yaw in the direction of the lower wing
learning.explanation: A stall must occur before a spin can take place. A spin occurs when one wing stalls more than the other. The wing that is more stalled will drop and the nose of the aircraft will yaw in the direction of the lower wing. An accidental power-on stall, during take-off or go-around, when a pilot’s attention is diverted, could easily turn into a spin. Power-on stall and recovery in a single-engine propeller aircraft has additional complications. At the high nose attitude and low airspeed associated with a power-on stall, there will be considerable “turning effects” from the propeller. E.g. for an aircraft with a clockwise rotating propeller the effect is to roll and yaw to the left.

content.question:
Which of these statements about the buffet free range in a buffet onset boundary graph are correct or incorrect?
1. When speed increases the buffet free range decreases.
2. When altitude decreases the buffet free range decreases.

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor
In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range
The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries
learning.explanation: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor. In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range. The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries. For a given aircraft there is a Mach number which, even at low angle of attack, cannot be exceeded because of the onset of shock stall. The EAS corresponding to this Mach number falls as altitude increases, so the range of operating speeds is reduced at both ends. Flying at a different speed will not influence the buffet boundaries, therefore statement 1 is incorrect. At altitude, the equivalent stalling speed increases with ‘g’ rather more rapidly than at sea level, because of the Mach number effect on CLMAX. Also, the buffet boundary becomes much more severe. Above a certain altitude the buffet boundary may intersect the stall boundary at a value of ‘g’ lower than the structural limit. This ‘point’ is another representation of “coffin corner”. We can then conclude that decreasing altitude, increases the buffet margin, therefore statement 2 is incorrect.

content.question: An aeroplane is established on final approach descending through 1000 ft when the pilot realizes that the aeroplane is about to enter an area of heavy tropical rain. The pilot must consider that the stalling…

options.A: speed increase due to the CLMAX reduction because of water distorting the shape of the airfoil and the airflow pattern.
options.B: speed increase due to compressibility effects appearing earlier than normal because of the concentration of water on the wings.
options.C: angle of attack decrease due to the apparent decrease of the load factor from the heavy downpour of rain.
options.D: angle of attack decreases due to the associated gusts from the heavy downpour of rain.

key_points: The airframe may become contaminated by ice, frost or water either whilst it is in flight or when standing on the ground

WATER CONTAMINATION If the wings are contaminated with water due to heavy rain, the boundary layer may become turbulent further forward on the wing, particularly if the section is of the laminar flow type
This will cause increased drag and may disrupt the boundary layer resulting in a significantly higher stall speed
learning.explanation: The airframe may become contaminated by ice, frost or water either whilst it is in flight or when standing on the ground. WATER CONTAMINATION If the wings are contaminated with water due to heavy rain, the boundary layer may become turbulent further forward on the wing, particularly if the section is of the laminar flow type. This will cause increased drag and may disrupt the boundary layer resulting in a significantly higher stall speed. EFFECT OF HEAVY RAIN ON STALL SPEED - Weight Heavy rain will form a film of water on an aircraft and increase its weight slightly, maybe as much as 1 - 2% this in itself will increase stall speed. - Aerodynamic Effect The film of water will distort the aerofoil, roughen the surface and alter the airflow pattern on the whole aircraft. CLMAX will decrease causing stall speed to increase. - Drag The film of water will increase interference drag, profile drag and form drag. In light rain, drag may increase by 5%, in moderate by 20% and in heavy rain by up to 30%. - Impact An additional consideration, while not affecting stall speed, is the effect of the impact of heavy rain on the aircraft. Momentum will be lost and airspeed will decrease, requiring increased thrust. At the same time, heavy rain will also be driving the aircraft downwards. The volume of rain in any given situation will vary, but an aircraft on final approach which suddenly enters a torrential downpour of heavy rain will be subject to a loss of momentum and a decrease in altitude, similar to the effect of microburst windshear.

content.question: An inexperienced pilot inadvertently flies a light aircraft into a cloud, and due to lack of visual references allows the aircraft to enter a spiral dive. As the aircraft flies out of the cloud the pilot pulls hard on the control column to recover. The aircraft can still stall in this attitude due to the…

options.A: wing exceeding the critical angle of attack.
options.B: aircraft IAS being below the published stall speed.
options.C: aircraft being above manoeuvre speed.
options.D: wing exceeding best L/D angle of attack.

key_points: When the lift developed by an aeroplane wing is no longer sufficient to sustain the mass of the aeroplane in flight, in the configuration being considered, the wing is stalled
A stall is caused by airflow separation
Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great
learning.explanation: When the lift developed by an aeroplane wing is no longer sufficient to sustain the mass of the aeroplane in flight, in the configuration being considered, the wing is stalled. A stall is caused by airflow separation. Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great. STALLING ANGLE OF ATTACK At a constant mass and air density, the coefficient of lift (CL), and consequently the total amount of lift, is dependent on the angle of attack. Graphically, lift increases almost linearly from an angle of attack of 0º to 4º, and then at an increasing rate to 15º. Lift cannot be obtained without incurring the penalty of drag. At a specific angle of attack, depending on circumstances, the lift generated is insufficient to sustain the aircraft in level flight. The angle of attack at which this occurs is the stalling angle or critical angle and is the point at which CLMAX is attained. An aeroplane will not stall unless the critical angle is exceeded.

Boundary Layer is defined as a region where the velocity of the flow reaches a certain percentage (i

learning.explanation: BOUNDARY LAYER When a solid is placed into a flow, there will be a layer, where the velocity is smaller than in the undisturbed stream, reducing to 0 at the surface of the body. Boundary Layer is defined as a region where the velocity of the flow reaches a certain percentage (i.e. 90% or 99%) of the undisturbed stream velocity from zero. Inside the boundary layer, the viscosity of the fluid alters the flow, while outside of this layer viscosity can be neglected. The boundary layer will exist in two forms, either laminar or turbulent. In general, the flow at the front will be laminar and become turbulent some distance back, known as the transition point.

content.question: One important advantage a turbulent boundary layer has over a laminar layer is that the turbulent boundary layer:

options.A: is thinner.
options.B: has less tendency to separate from the surface.
options.C: has less energy.
options.D: has a lower skin friction drag.

key_points: The boundary layer is the layer of fluid (in our case this fluid is the atmosphere) in the immediate surface of a bounding surface (the airfoil) where the effects of viscosity are significant
There are two types of boundary layer; the laminar and the turbulent boundary layer
In the laminar boundary layer, the flow moves parallel to the surface over which it flows
learning.explanation: The boundary layer is the layer of fluid (in our case this fluid is the atmosphere) in the immediate surface of a bounding surface (the airfoil) where the effects of viscosity are significant. There are two types of boundary layer; the laminar and the turbulent boundary layer. In the laminar boundary layer, the flow moves parallel to the surface over which it flows. In the laminar boundary layer, the air flows very smoothly. The velocity increases with distance from the airfoil and there is no movement of air perpendicular to the surface of the airfoil. Laminar flow creates less friction drag than the turbulent flow, but is less stable. At a distance from the leading edge of the airfoil, the air transitions from a laminar flow to a turbulent flow. This air does not flow smoothly, it contains swirls. There is flow in parallel and perpendicular direction. This air creates more drag than the laminar air flow, has more kinetic energy and breaks down from the surface less easily and is therefore more stable.

content.question: A pilot is flying an aeroplane manually, in a turn, but forgets to add thrust and enters a stall. As a first action in order to initiate stall recovery, the pilot should...

options.A: Bring the wings level to direct the lift upwards.
options.B: Add thrust to increase speed past the stalling speed.
options.C: Apply rudder to raise that dropped wing.
options.D: Apply nose-down pitch to reduce the angle of attack.

key_points: The CL of an aerofoil increases with angle of attack up to a maximum (CLMAX)

Any further increase above this stalling angle, or critical angle of attack, will make it impossible for the airflow to smoothly follow the upper wing contour, and the flow will separate from the surface, causing CL to decrease and drag to increase rapidly
A stall is caused by airflow separation
learning.explanation: The CL of an aerofoil increases with angle of attack up to a maximum (CLMAX). Any further increase above this stalling angle, or critical angle of attack, will make it impossible for the airflow to smoothly follow the upper wing contour, and the flow will separate from the surface, causing CL to decrease and drag to increase rapidly. A stall is caused by airflow separation. Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great. STALL RECOVERY To recover from a stall or prevent a full stall, the angle of attack must be decreased to reduce the adverse pressure gradient. This may consist of merely releasing back pressure, or it may be necessary to smoothly move the pitch control forward, depending on the aircraft design and severity of the stall. Allow airspeed to increase and recover lost altitude with moderate back pressure on the pitch control. Pulling too hard could trigger a secondary stall, or worse, could exceed the limit load factor and damage the aircraft structure. As angle of attack reduces below the critical angle, the adverse pressure gradient will decrease, airflow will re-attach, and lift and drag will return to their normal values.

content.question:
A “stall warning” can be produced synthetically by electronic means, by a system that may malfunction. What are the natural stall warnings confirming an approaching stall?
(1) Aerodynamic buffeting
(2) Increased aileron effectiveness
(3) Inability to arrest a rate of descent
(4) Stick pusher activation

options.A: 1 and 3.
options.B: 1 and 4.
options.C: 2 and 4.

key_points: STALL A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift
Specifically, a stall occurs when the AOA—the angle between the chord line of the wing and the relative wind—exceeds the wing’s critical AOA
It is possible to exceed the critical AOA at any airspeed, at any attitude, and at any power setting
learning.explanation: STALL A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift. Specifically, a stall occurs when the AOA—the angle between the chord line of the wing and the relative wind—exceeds the wing’s critical AOA. It is possible to exceed the critical AOA at any airspeed, at any attitude, and at any power setting. Impending Stall—an impending stall occurs when the AOA causes a stall warning, but has not yet reached the critical AOA. Indications of an impending stall can include buffeting, stick shaker, or aural warning. Full Stall—a full stall occurs when the critical AOA is exceeded. Indications of a full stall are typically that an uncommanded nose-down pitch cannot be readily arrested, and this may be accompanied by an uncommanded rolling motion. The flying controls will feel unresponsive or “mushy”. For airplanes equipped with stick pushers, its activation is also a full stall indication. Note: The question asks for natural stall warnings.

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting

Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. The aircraft must therefore be operated in such a manner that a (safety) margin exists before aerodynamic buffet will occur. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved. content.question: The load factor is less than 1 (one):

options.B: during a steady horizontal turn.
options.C: during a wings level stall before recovery.

key_points: The balance of forces in steady climb show thrust is partly acting upwards and weight is partly adding to the drag
Because the thrust is now assisting lift, there is less lift required than in level flight
For steady speed, the thrust and two effects of aerodynamic drag and weight must be equal
learning.explanation: The balance of forces in steady climb show thrust is partly acting upwards and weight is partly adding to the drag. Because the thrust is now assisting lift, there is less lift required than in level flight. For steady speed, the thrust and two effects of aerodynamic drag and weight must be equal. T= Thrust W= Weight D= Drag T= D + W sin(gamma) This means that the climb angle (sin gamma) depends on excess thrust and weight. In descent the formula will become T= D – W sin(gamma) The load factor is the relationship between lift and weight. As the lift in a stall is decreased and the load factor in straight and level flight is 1, the load factor will now be less than 1.

content.question: Low speed pitch up can be caused by the:

options.A: outward drift of the boundary layer on a swept-back wing.
options.B: dihedral effect.
options.C: boundary layer separation at the wing tip of a forward swept wing.
options.D: wing tip vortices on high aspect ratio wings.

key_points: The lift from a wing is generated by airflow over it from front to back
If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer
This causes them to be thicker and more susceptible to transition to turbulence or flow separation
learning.explanation: The lift from a wing is generated by airflow over it from front to back. If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer. This causes them to be thicker and more susceptible to transition to turbulence or flow separation. The normal tip vortice on a swept wing joins up with a leading edge separation bubble, creating a larger vortex called the Ram’s horn vortex. This vortex goes inboard along the wing’s leading edge. The downward flow from the vortex induces pressure on the boundary layer at the wingtip, whereas on straight wings the exact opposite occurs. With a swept wing, this creates a slow-moving layer of air at the wing tip. This slow-moving air will separate into disturbed flow and will then stall the tip. As the wingtips for a swept wing are positioned aft of the center of pressure (CP), the center of pressure upon a wing tip stall will move forward, creating a nose up moment. This nose up moment will further increase the Angle of Attack if not corrected in time, increasing the layer of slow-moving air, worsening the situation. Due to the decreased downwash on the elevator, the elevator could be less responsive, creating a so called deep stall. Unswept wings do not have this problem. The pitch up phenomenon is a dangerous characteristic of swept wing aircraft (with a T-tail) that move at high speed. It could result in a quickly worsening stalling situation, making it very hard to recover.

content.question: An aeroplane is flying in steady, straight and level flight at its 1g stall speed. If the pilot intends to turn left using the ailerons, the aeroplane will…

options.A: bank to the left provided the speed does NOT decrease below the stalling speed.
options.B: bank to the right, because the wing with the down going aileron will exceed the critical angle of attack.
options.C: maintain straight and level flight because the ailerons will be unresponsive due to flow separation.
options.D: Yaw to the left, because of increased drag due to flow separation on the downgoing aileron.

key_points: USE OF FLIGHT CONTROLS CLOSE TO THE STALL At low speeds normally associated with stalling, dynamic pressure is at a very low value and greater control deflection will be required to achieve the same response; also, the flying controls will feel unresponsive or “mushy”
If an accidental stall does occur, it is vitally important that the stall and recovery should occur without too much wing drop
Moving a control surface modifies the chord line and, hence, the angle of attack
learning.explanation: USE OF FLIGHT CONTROLS CLOSE TO THE STALL At low speeds normally associated with stalling, dynamic pressure is at a very low value and greater control deflection will be required to achieve the same response; also, the flying controls will feel unresponsive or “mushy”. If an accidental stall does occur, it is vitally important that the stall and recovery should occur without too much wing drop. Moving a control surface modifies the chord line and, hence, the angle of attack. An aircraft being flown close to the stall angle may have one wing that produces slightly less lift than the other; that wing will tend to drop. Trying to lift a dropping wing with aileron will increase its angle of attack, and may cause the wing to stall completely, resulting in that wing dropping at an increased rate. At speeds close to the stall, ailerons must be used with caution. On straight wing aircraft the rudder should be used to yaw the aircraft just enough to increase the speed of a dropping wing to maintain a wing’s level attitude. Swept wing aircraft basic stall requirements are designed to enable the ailerons to be used successfully up to ”stall recognition”, but small amounts of rudder can be used if smoothly applied and co-ordinated with the ailerons. If an aileron is lowered when flying at high angles of attack, that wing could possibly stall. In that case the wing will drop instead of rising as intended.

content.question: Aircraft certified under CS-23 and CS-25 must be able to show that they are able to retain control at and just after the critical angle of attack. Which of the following design features may influence this controllability and why?

options.A: Aft mounted engines, as an increase in thrust produces a nose down moment.
options.B: Position of horizontal stabiliser, e.g. a T-tail makes it harder to recover from a stall.
options.C: Supercritical wings increase nose up tendency in a stall.
options.D: Using roll spoilers increases the chance of aileron reversal near the stall.

key_points: Note: The feedback for this question is quite limited, and there is another option that is very close to being correct, but we are happy with our choice of correct answer

Please send us any further exam feedback you have about this question, thank you! The vast majority of aircraft are never meant to stall, but it is always a possibility, no matter how many measures the designers put in to stop it occurring
This is why aircraft must be made to be controllable and predictable at stalling
learning.explanation: Note: The feedback for this question is quite limited, and there is another option that is very close to being correct, but we are happy with our choice of correct answer. Please send us any further exam feedback you have about this question, thank you! The vast majority of aircraft are never meant to stall, but it is always a possibility, no matter how many measures the designers put in to stop it occurring. This is why aircraft must be made to be controllable and predictable at stalling. In particular, we want the aircraft to have a nose down moment at the stall, and we want the controls to be effective at the stall. One way the controls could become ineffective at the stall is with a T-tail horizontal stabiliser design. Whilst a T-tail design usually takes the horizontal stabiliser away from the wake of the main wing, when the aircraft is pitched at the stalling angle of attack, often the horizontal stabiliser is in the zone of stalled airflow, where little to no lift can be gained. This is called a "deep stall" (or a super-stall) and makes the elevators quite useless, and even an all moving tailplane (which you would not usually find in a T-tail configuration) would be quite useless too. This is why most T-tail aircraft have a stall prevention device fitted called a stick pusher, which will put in a very strong pitch down control force just before the "deep stall" is reached. As we have already mentioned, there is another option present that is very close to correct. "Aft mounted engines, as an increase in thrust produces a nose down moment." We call this a stabilising thrust line, because the addition of thrust helps us gain airspeed by causing a pitch down moment as well as an increase in thrust. In our opinion it would be useful to have during stall. However, the controllability during and after the stall would not strictly be affected by this, only the ability to recover from the stall. If you interpret the question slightly differently, then this could be considered correct, but we would say it is not quite correct. "Position of horizontal stabiliser, e.g. a T-tail makes it harder to recover from a stall." As discussed above, this makes a huge difference to stall controllability, especially due to the ability of a T-tail design to go into a "deep stall". "Supercritical wings increase nose up tendency in a stall." Supercritical wings do stall slightly differently (much faster and less gradual), but this does not really relate to a nose up tendency. Also, this option does not really answer the question above, so it is incorrect. "Using roll spoilers increases the chance of aileron reversal near the stall." This one filled in incomplete feedback. Do not expect it in the exam. Aileron reversal (low speed) can happen if an aileron drops near the stall, increasing the AoA passed the stalling AoA and causing a reversal of the requested turn direction.

We also only know 2 options, the correct one and one incorrect one, and the other two incorrect options are likely to be different in the exam. DEEP STALL A deep stall is a dangerous phenomenon that occurs when the turbulence created by the main wing encompasses the horizontal stabilizer of the aircraft, preventing the aircraft from recovering from the stall. T-tail aircraft are most likely to have deep stall characteristics. When the main wing stalls, the stabilizer becomes ineffective because it is situated in the separated turbulent flow of the wing and sometimes the fuselage. This can lead to a very dangerous scenario where the aircraft can sit stable in the deep stall, with no control surface left working to get out of the situation. A common way to prevent deep stall in these types of aircraft is a stick pusher device, which detects high angles of attack, approaching the stall, and instead of notifying the pilots of this (a stick shaker, stall warner, etc.), it actually pushes the stick forwards without any pilot intervention.

content.question:
Thunderstorms are reported in the vicinity of an aerodrome when a heavy jet transport is about to commence an approach. Which combination of these methods could be used by the crew to mitigate the risk of buffet or stall?
1. Delay the approach, and divert if necessary.
2. Plan a flapless approach and landing.
3. Maintain a speed at least 30 kts above normal approach speed.
4. Delay landing flap selection until 200 ft.
5. Expect and prepare for a windshear warning and a go-around.

options.A: 1 and 5
options.B: 1, 3 and 4
options.C: 2, 4 and 5

key_points: ALL EFFORTS SHALL BE MADE TO AVOID THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY AS IT POSES RISK TO FLIGHT SAFETY Microbursts are associated with thunderstorms and are one of the most dangerous sources of windshear
A windshear encounter is a very dynamic event which can strike suddenly and with devastating effect which has been beyond the recovery powers of experienced pilots flying modern and powerful aircraft
The first and most vital defence is avoidance
learning.explanation: ALL EFFORTS SHALL BE MADE TO AVOID THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY AS IT POSES RISK TO FLIGHT SAFETY Microbursts are associated with thunderstorms and are one of the most dangerous sources of windshear. A windshear encounter is a very dynamic event which can strike suddenly and with devastating effect which has been beyond the recovery powers of experienced pilots flying modern and powerful aircraft. The first and most vital defence is avoidance. AWARENESS AND AVOIDANCE Awareness of the weather conditions that cause windshear will reduce the risk of an encounter. If a windshear encounter is likely, the takeoff or landing should be delayed until the conditions improve, e.g. until a thunderstorm has moved away from the airport. Windshear represents a severe threat to aviation safety, the best option is to avoid it whenever possible. Nevertheless, in the case of an actual encounter with windshear, it is essential to be to quickly recognize it and then recover from it. PREVENTION A key element of adverse weather avoidance strategies is the active monitoring of the overall meteorological situation by the crew, in addition to the optimum use of the weather radar and correct understanding of the information displayed. The take-off, initial climb, final approach and landing phases of flight in the vicinity of thunderstorms may present the pilot with additional problems because of the airplane‘s proximity to the ground. To maintain a safe flight path in these phases can be very difficult. Do not take off if a thunderstorm is overhead or approaching. At destination, hold if a thunderstorm is overhead or approaching or divert if necessary. On the approach, if there is ever any doubt that you can regain a reasonable rate of descent, and land without abnormal manoeuvres, you should apply full power and go-around or make a missed approach. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Delay the approach, and divert if necessary. CORRECT: As the explanation suggests, in case of thunderstorm activity, the first mitigating action should be to avoid and therefore delay take-off/landing or divert if necessary. 2. Plan a flapless approach and landing. INCORRECT: Flaps/slats should be used for every normal approach, including those with thunderstorms present as they lower the stall speed and in the case of slats increase the critical angle of attack. 3. Maintain a speed at least 30 kt above normal approach speed. INCORRECT: Choosing to fly at a speed slightly higher than normal approach speed is a good technique to aid with speed fluctuations characteristic of thunderstorm activity. However, this would be type specific, and there is no general rule for an approach to be flown 30 knots faster than normal. 4. Delay landing flap selection until 200 ft. INCORRECT: Delaying the configuration of the aircraft is not a recommended for this type of approach, specially to as low as 200 ft. 5. Expect and prepare for a windshear warning and a go-around. CORRECT: As stated above, the first mitigating action should be to avoid the thunderstorms. On the approach, if avoiding is not possible, the crew should be prepared to perform a go-around.

This results in a smaller suction, smaller lift and high drag
If AOA is increased further beyond this AOA, lift will reduce
learning.explanation: There is a certain angle of attack (AOA), at which the flow cannot follow the shape of the profile, the flow separates from the surface and vortices are created. This results in a smaller suction, smaller lift and high drag. If AOA is increased further beyond this AOA, lift will reduce. This angle of attack is called critical angle of attack. The critical angle of attack will remain the same regardless of gross weight. A given wing will always stall at the same AOA, regardless of weight, load factor, density altitude and airspeed. However, increased weight, a higher load factor and increased density altitude do increase the airspeed at which the aircraft reaches its critical AOA.

Holdover Time (HOT) is the estimated time the anti-icing fluid will prevent the formation of ice and frost and the accumulation of snow on the protected (treated) surfaces of an aeroplane. The HOT begins whenever the anti-icing stage begins, in single stage de/anti-icing, that is the beginning of the first stage, for 2 stage de/anti-icing, that is the beginning of the second stage. The responsibility regarding HOT and subsequent re-application of de-ice/anti-ice (if applicable) rests with the Commander from the time he has received the final report about the treatment from the Anti/De-icing person in charge. Hold-over Times are only guidelines because a variety of factors can change the effectiveness of the fluid. These factors include high winds, jet blasts, wet snow heavy precipitation, aircraft skin temperature lower than outside air temperature, direct sunlight, etc. Monitoring of the environmental conditions is therefore essential. If in doubt, a visual or tactile check must be performed before take-off to make sure the airframe is clean. learning.explanation: High-speed buffet is the rapid movement of the control surfaces caused by turbulent airflow passing over them. It can only occur when the Mach number is above the critical Mach number and is likely to be accompanied by a tendency for the airplane to pitch nose-down. Above that altitude any turbulence may induce Mach buffet, which could cause the airplane to exceed the maximum permitted load factor. learning.explanation: STALL A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift. Specifically, a stall occurs when the AOA—the angle between the chord line of the wing and the relative wind—exceeds the wing’s critical AOA. It is possible to exceed the critical AOA at any airspeed, at any attitude, and at any power setting. Impending Stall—an impending stall occurs when the AOA causes a stall warning, but has not yet reached the critical AOA. Indications of an impending stall can include buffeting, stick shaker, or aural warning. Full Stall—a full stall occurs when the critical AOA is exceeded. Indications of a full stall are typically that an uncommanded nose-down pitch cannot be readily arrested, and this may be accompanied by an uncommanded rolling motion. The flying controls will feel unresponsive or “mushy”. For airplanes equipped with stick pushers, its activation is also a full stall indication.

content.question: Which of these statements about boundary layers is correct?

options.A: Compared with a turbulent boundary layer, a laminar boundary layer is better able to resist a positive pressure gradient before it separates.
options.B: A turbulent boundary layer turns into a laminar one at the transition point.
options.C: A laminar boundary layer is thicker than a turbulent one.
options.D: A turbulent boundary layer produces more friction drag than a laminar one.

key_points: There is a layer of air that clings to the surface of an object and resists movement
This characteristic of the air is its viscosity, which although very small, is enough for the molecules of the air in contact with a surface to stick to the surface
It is static and therefore causes the laminar streamline flow adjacent to this layer to slow down, which in turn produces turbulence
learning.explanation: There is a layer of air that clings to the surface of an object and resists movement. This characteristic of the air is its viscosity, which although very small, is enough for the molecules of the air in contact with a surface to stick to the surface. It is static and therefore causes the laminar streamline flow adjacent to this layer to slow down, which in turn produces turbulence. The speed of the airflow changes from zero at the surface of the airfoil to the full speed of the free flow airstream a few millimeters away from the surface. This thin layer of sluggish air that clings to the surface of the object and in which the speed change of the airflow takes place is the boundary layer. In aerodynamics the boundary layer is important when considering wing stall, skin friction drag and heat transfer in high-speed flight. Boundary layers may be laminar (layered) or turbulent (disordered). The boundary layer increases in thickness as it moves rearward over an aircraft wing, with the turbulent boundary layer being proportionally thicker than the laminar boundary layer under the same free stream velocity conditions. The turbulent boundary layer has much higher local velocities immediately adjacent to the surface. The airflow in this region therefore possesses much higher kinetic energy than the laminar boundary layer at the same distance above the surface. The rapid velocity change associated with the turbulent boundary layer is evidence of high skin friction drag. The turbulent boundary has less tendency to separate from the airfoil surface over which it is flowing than the laminar boundary layer because it is better able to withstand the positive pressure gradient.

learning.explanation: The boundary layer is the layer of fluid (in our case this fluid is the atmosphere) in the immediate surface of a bounding surface (the airfoil) where the effects of viscosity are significant. There are two types of boundary layer; the laminar and the turbulent boundary layer. In the laminar boundary layer, the flow moves parallel to the surface over which it flows. In the laminar boundary layer, the air flows very smoothly. The velocity increases with distance from the airfoil and there is no movement of air perpendicular to the surface of the airfoil. Laminar flow creates less friction drag than the turbulent flow, but is less stable. At a distance from the leading edge of the airfoil, the air transitions from a laminar flow to a turbulent flow. This air does not flow smoothly, it contains swirls. There is flow in parallel and perpendicular direction. This air creates more drag than the laminar air flow, but breaks down less easily and is therefore more stable.

content.question: How does stall speed (IAS) vary with altitude?

options.A: It remains constant.
options.B: It increases with increasing altitude, because the density decreases.
options.C: It remains constant at lower altitudes but increases at higher altitudes due to compressibility effects.
options.D: It remains constant at lower altitudes but decreases at higher altitudes due to compressibility effects.

key_points: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1 / 2 ρV2

Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes
If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes
learning.explanation: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1 / 2 ρV2. Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes. If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes. At a constant EAS, Mach number will increase as altitude increases. Figure 1 shows the variation of stalling speed with altitude at constant load factor (n). Such a curve is called the stalling boundary for the given load factor, in which altitude is plotted against equivalent airspeed. At this load factor (1g), the aircraft cannot fly at speeds to the left of this boundary. Over the lower range of altitude, stall speed does not vary with altitude. This is because at these low altitudes, the Mach number at VS is too low for compressibility effects to be present. Eventually (approximately 30000 ft), Mach number at VS has increased with altitude to such an extent that these effects are important, and the rise in stalling speed with altitude is apparent. As altitude increases, stall speed is initially constant then increases, due to compressibility.

Whilst this will even out some of the common issues with different angles of attack, the inside wing of the turn will still be going slightly slower than the outside wing, and will have a higher angle of attack, especially when descending, so will be more prone to entering the stall if the airspeed drops too low
This is a common problem on the turn from base to final in the circuit, and a killer of many pilots who didn't watch their airspeed
learning.explanation: In any turn, it is better to be coordinated, which means the airflow is hitting the aircraft exactly upon the nose, and the aircraft is not skidding or slipping into the turn. Whilst this will even out some of the common issues with different angles of attack, the inside wing of the turn will still be going slightly slower than the outside wing, and will have a higher angle of attack, especially when descending, so will be more prone to entering the stall if the airspeed drops too low. This is a common problem on the turn from base to final in the circuit, and a killer of many pilots who didn't watch their airspeed. The slower inside wing will be quite likely to stall first. This is particularly bad as the aircraft is already banked in this direction, so will be quick to lose even more control and possibly even go inverted. As a side note; slipping in the turn will make it more likely to stall the outside wing, which is slightly better. Skidding turns are especially bad, as they amplify the problems mentioned above, and make it very probable that the inner wing will stall first, which will quickly become a spin.

This leaves the aircraft in a low-power, nose-low configuration, making it difficult to recover when the wind switches to a tailwind

learning.explanation: A microburst during takeoff or landing is particularly dangerous if the pilot has reduced power and lowered the nose in response to the headwind. This leaves the aircraft in a low-power, nose-low configuration, making it difficult to recover when the wind switches to a tailwind. Due to the potential of a 30-90 knot loss in headwind, the airplane could stall or land short of the runway. Flying through a Microburst 1. Imagine you're approaching a microburst at 80 knots. As you enter the vortex ring, you experience turbulence and a rapid increase in IAS as you pick up a headwind. You start to climb as your performance increases. 2. As you enter the strongest part of the horizontal shaft, your airspeed peaks at 100 knots, an increase of 20 knots. You're still climbing as you enter the downdraft. 3. Inside the downdraft, your headwind starts to switch to a tailwind. You're caught in the downdraft, sinking quickly toward the ground. Your airspeed begins to decrease. 4. As you exit the downdraft, your tailwind increases rapidly. The shear drops your airspeed to 60 knots, which is 20 knots below your original speed. You're at a high angle-of-attack, and still descending. 5. You encounter more turbulence as you enter the final vortex. If you haven't already hit the ground, you may begin to climb again as you exit the vortex.

content.question: What is the significance of the maximum allowed cruising altitude, based on the 1.3 g margin? At this altitude:

options.A: exceeding a load factor of 1.3 will cause permanent deformation of this aeroplane.
options.B: a manoeuvre with a load factor of 1.3 will cause a Mach number at which accelerated low speed stall occurs.
options.C: a manoeuvre with a load factor of 1.3 will cause MCRIT to be exceeded.
options.D: a manoeuvre with a load factor of 1.3 will cause buffet onset.

key_points: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor
In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range
The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries
learning.explanation: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor. In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range. The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries. The margin between the two types of stall narrows with increasing altitude. Notably the true airspeed of the low-speed stall increases with increasing altitude for a given indicated airspeed, whilst the true airspeed of the shock stall reduces up to the base of the tropopause, above which it remains constant. The point at which the two stalls coincide is referred to as the 'coffin corner'. The altitude at which an aircraft can fly at one airspeed in a 1g maneuver is called the aerodynamic ceiling. For any given combination of mass, center of gravity position and airspeed, the maximum operating altitude is that altitude at which a normal positive acceleration increment of 0.3g, without exceeding the buffet onset boundary, is possible. It is, therefore, common practice to draw the ‘buffet-onset boundary chart’ for a range of cruise masses at 1.3g. Any maneuver having a load factor exceeding 1.3g will initiate the buffet onset.

content.question: Which of the following may occur when taking off in icing conditions?

options.A: The aeroplane will develop a nose down moment and the effect is worse with flaps extended.
options.B: The aeroplane will develop a nose up moment and the effect is worse with flaps retracted.
options.C: The aeroplane will develop a nose up moment and the effect is worse with flaps extended.
options.D: The aeroplane will develop a nose down moment and the effect is worse with flaps retracted.

key_points: Note: Our initial feedback said that this came from a Performance exam, but we think that may be incorrect, as there are no Performance LOs close to this topic, but in Principles of Flight, the LO 081
learning.explanation: Note: Our initial feedback said that this came from a Performance exam, but we think that may be incorrect, as there are no Performance LOs close to this topic, but in Principles of Flight, the LO 081.03.01.05.08 pertains to it exactly. Please let us know if you see it in your exam, and which exam that is, thank you! TAILPLANE STALL Whilst it is not immediately identifiable by the question, this is asking about tailplane stalls due to icing. The tailplane (or horizontal stabiliser) is a second wing mounted at the rear of the aircraft to allow for stability, and for control (with the elevator), and in fact, is usually used to provide downwards lift to keep the aircraft's nose up, and counteract the weight/lift couple (which pushes the nose down). The tailplane is often quite a lot thinner than the main wing, so it builds up ice quicker, and means that tailplane stall due to icing can occur when there is little to no main wing ice accretion. A tailplane stall is made worse by the extension of flaps, as they increase the downwash from the main wing, which causes a larger negative angle of attack on the tailplane, which is more likely to stall the tailplane. Flaps also move the centre of pressure further back, which increases the Cg/Cp (Weight/Lift) couple, which means the elevator needs to create more downforce to keep the nose up. As the downforce from the tail decreases due to tail stall, there is a strong nose-down moment created. This is made worse - as mentioned above - by the use of flaps. The worst speed/configuration for this type of stall is just under the maximum flap speed (VFE), with flaps extended.
