content.question: The pitch-up stall behaviour of a swept wing aircraft at subsonic speed is due to the centre of pressure moving:

options.A: Forward when the wing tips stall first.
options.B: Backward when the wing roots stall first.
options.C: Backward when the wing tips stall first.
options.D: Forward when the wing roots stall first.

key_points: A swept wing is designed to allow a higher maximum speed with better transonic flight characteristics, but this does mean that it sacrifices some of its low-speed flight characteristics
When swept wings are unmodified, they have a strong tendency to stall first near the tips
Loss of lift at the tips moves the CP forward, giving a nose-up pitching moment as the lift is being produce from further forwards
learning.explanation: A swept wing is designed to allow a higher maximum speed with better transonic flight characteristics, but this does mean that it sacrifices some of its low-speed flight characteristics. When swept wings are unmodified, they have a strong tendency to stall first near the tips. Loss of lift at the tips moves the CP forward, giving a nose-up pitching moment as the lift is being produce from further forwards. This tendency to tip stall is due to the induced spanwise flow of the boundary layer from root to tip. During a tip stall, all the lift production is concentrated inboard and the maximum downwash now impacts the tail plane, adding to the nose-up pitching moment. As soon as a swept wing begins to stall, both forward CP movement and increased downwash at the tail plane cause the aircraft nose to rise rapidly, further increasing the angle of attack. This is a very undesirable and unacceptable response at the stall and can result in complete loss of control in pitch from which it may be very difficult, or even impossible, to recover. This is a very dangerous characteristic of many high speed, swept wing aircraft. For this reason, commercial swept wing aircraft are fitted with modifications to ensure the root stalls first. These can be vortex generators, or washout of the wing to reduce the tip angle of incidence, etc.

content.question: A pilot is testing the slow flight characteristics of an aeroplane with tapered (non swept) wings. Which of the following could they expect to experience approaching the stall?

options.A: A light buffet on the ailerons.
options.B: A heavy buffet through the elevators.
options.C: An aggressive pitch up moment.
options.D: The controls feeling light and ineffective.

key_points: Tapered wings are when the tips of the wing have a shorter chord than the root of the wing
This can lead to efficiencies in terms of lift distribution and induced drag, but when they are unmodified, produce less than ideal stalling characteristics
Wings on large aircraft are usually tapered and swept back, but here we are talking of unswept wings only
learning.explanation: Tapered wings are when the tips of the wing have a shorter chord than the root of the wing. This can lead to efficiencies in terms of lift distribution and induced drag, but when they are unmodified, produce less than ideal stalling characteristics. Wings on large aircraft are usually tapered and swept back, but here we are talking of unswept wings only. Tapered wings are prone to stalling first near the wing tips, and this stall spreads out forwards and inwards towards the root. This is undesireable as the stall affects the ailerons first, and makes this planform very susceptible to a violent wing drop. The first sign of stall on these aeroplanes often comes as a buffet through the ailerons, starting light and getting heavier, until the ailerons are fully stalled and have either a reverse effect or very little effect on aircraft control. Given where the stall occurs, and the likelihood of an early wing drop, elevator buffet is unlikely and pitching moments are quite limited. There is sometimes a pitch down moment due to the Centre of Pressure moving rearwards during the stall, but it is often not enough to avoid the formation of a spin. Hence, these aircraft wing planforms are usually modified in some way to avoid tip stalls and encourage the wing roots to stall first.

content.question:
A pilot is flying an aeroplane whose clean configuration stall speed is 60 kt. While cruising at 95 kt the pilot has to take avoiding action against another aeroplane.
The pilot banks the aeroplane sharply and during this manoeuvre, the aeroplane stalls.
Why did the aeroplane stall at 95 kt?

options.A: A large movement of the ailerons causes both wings to stall at the tips.
options.B: In a turn, the aeroplane weight increases, which increases the stall speed.
options.C: A wing stalls when its critical angle of attack is exceeded, regardless of speed.
options.D: The change in airflow due to rapid rolling causes the up-moving wing to stall.

key_points: The low-speed stall occurs at a particular angle of attack of the wing to the relative airflow, not at a specific airspeed
In a manoeuvre such as the one described in the question, the load factor on the wing will increase as the pilot pulls back on the stick, requiring more lift from the wing
This required a higher angle of attack, and obviously the pilot has exceeded the critical angle of attack in this case, and stalled the aeroplane
learning.explanation: The low-speed stall occurs at a particular angle of attack of the wing to the relative airflow, not at a specific airspeed. In a manoeuvre such as the one described in the question, the load factor on the wing will increase as the pilot pulls back on the stick, requiring more lift from the wing. This required a higher angle of attack, and obviously the pilot has exceeded the critical angle of attack in this case, and stalled the aeroplane. The low-speed stall occurs because boundary layer becomes detached from the upper surface of the wing. This happens because the low pressure at the front of the wing upper surface becomes too strong, and the airflow gets too slow (de-energised), so the strong adverse pressure gradient pulls back the low speed air within the boundary layer, and eventually the air current starts to flip, and the boundary layer separates completely, causing turbulent, stalled airflow. See the last two images above.

content.question:
Which of these statements about the buffet free range in a buffet onset boundary graph are correct or incorrect?
1. During a push-over manoeuvre the buffet free range decreases.
2. When the mass increases the buffet free range decreases.

options.A: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor
In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range
The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries
learning.explanation: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor. In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range. The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries. For a given aircraft there is a Mach number which, even at low angle of attack, cannot be exceeded because of the onset of shock stall. The EAS corresponding to this Mach number falls as altitude increases, so the range of operating speeds is reduced at both ends. Also, an increase in load factor (bank angle) requires an increase in lift at a given EAS, hence an increase in angle of attack and a further reduction in limiting Mach number. Thus, the greater the load factor (bank angle or gust), the more severe the limitation due to buffeting. We can then conclude that decreasing load factor (push-over maneuver) increases the buffet margin, therefore statement 1 is incorrect. The weight of the aircraft also affects the envelope. An increase in weight results in an increase in stall speed, and the stall boundary is moved to the right. It also results in an increase in angle of attack at any given speed, so that the Mach number at which buffeting occurs is reduced, and the buffet boundary is moved to the left. Finally, increase in weight implies a reduction in the maximum permissible ‘g’. Thus, all the boundaries are made more restrictive by an increase in weight. We can then conclude that increasing weight (mass) decreases the buffet margin, therefore statement 2 is correct.

learning.explanation: Note: this is based on incomplete feedback on questions 819856 and 815947, please put any further exam feedback in the comments or email it to us at info@atplquestions.com so we can verify the question, thanks! The ITCZ (Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone) is an area of very large uplift and often violent thunderstorms due to converging air at the surface. It is also a region where the tropopause will be incredibly high, sometimes in the region of 55-60,000 ft. This makes it often impossible to climb away from the turbulence experienced in that region. The turbulence can cause lots of passenger distress and potential for airframe fatigue and damage when it gets severe enough. It can also change our airspeed enough to put us into either the high- or low-speed buffeting region, so we should instead descend to a lower altitude, out of the potential “coffin corner” and fly at turbulence penetration speed (this usually means slowing down from cruise speed) to get the best safety margin for turbulence.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.03.01.02.06: Explain why the load factor increases in a pull-up and decreases in a push-over manoeuvre. A push-over manoeuvre is where the pilot pushes the controls forward and the load factor is reduced (usually to around zero G, but the manoeuvre is whenever the load factor is temporarily pushed below 1G). It is highly useful for reducing the load on the wings, and can break a stall immediately, as an aircraft cannot stall when the load factor is zero, allowing control to be regained temporarily to allow the aircraft to be stabilised and the airspeed to be increased. The angle of attack is reduced during a push-over manoeuvre, and this is a key part of unloading the wings.

The correct symbol for load factor is (n), but it is colloquially known as (g)
Load Factor = Lift / Weight LOAD FACTOR IN A TURN When an aircraft is in a banked turn, lift must be increased so as to maintain the vertical component of lift equal to weight
learning.explanation: Load Factor - The ratio of the weight of an aircraft to the load imposed by lift. The correct symbol for load factor is (n), but it is colloquially known as (g). learning.explanation: The critical angle of attack is the angle of attack producing the maximum lift coefficient. If the aircraft increases angle of attack above this value, it will enter a stall. This value can be increased with the use of slats. Slats delay the separation of the boundary layer, by adding kinetic energy into it. A clean wing has a lower value of CLMAX, causing the Angle of Attack for a clean wing to be lower than for a wing with slats extended. A wing with flaps extended has the lowest value of CLMAX. In straight and level flight, prior to the stall, lift remains constant. Speed decreases and CL increases. In the stall (so after CLMAX has passed) the CL decreases again and speed is still low. Therefore lift decreases. The increased turbulent flow over the wing during the stall, the drag will be increased during the stall compared to the flight prior to the stall.

content.question: An aeroplane slows down at high altitude towards the stall. The aircraft might be considered to have stalled even below the critical angle of attack if…

options.A: maximum continuous thrust is required to remain in level flight.
options.B: control effectiveness reduces, such that large deflection is needed to maintain wings level.
options.C: the coefficient of lift decreases with increased angle of attack.
options.D: buffet is so strong that it deters the pilot from further speed reduction.

key_points: When an airplane is flying, the airflow over the wings creates lift
As the angle of attack (AOA) increases, the lift generated by the wings also increases
However, at a certain AOA, the smooth flow of air over the wings is disrupted, and the airflow separates from the wing's surface
learning.explanation: When an airplane is flying, the airflow over the wings creates lift. As the angle of attack (AOA) increases, the lift generated by the wings also increases. However, at a certain AOA, the smooth flow of air over the wings is disrupted, and the airflow separates from the wing's surface. This leads to a sudden loss of lift, which is known as a stall. Option a) "maximum continuous thrust is required to remain in level flight." is not correct because the need for maximum continuous thrust to maintain level flight is not necessarily an indication of a stall. Option b) "control effectiveness reduces, such that large deflection is needed to maintain wings level." is also not correct because while control effectiveness may reduce as the AOA increases, it is not a definitive indicator of a stall. Option c) "the coefficient of lift decreases with increased angle of attack." is a true statement about the coefficient of lift, but it does not necessarily indicate a stall. Option d) "buffet is so strong that it deters the pilot from further speed reduction." is the correct answer because when an airplane approaches a stall, the airflow over the wings becomes turbulent, which can cause buffeting or vibration of the aircraft. If the buffeting is strong enough, it can deter the pilot from further reducing the speed, as it is an indication that the airplane is approaching a stall. Therefore, strong buffeting is a definitive indicator of an imminent stall.

Following stall warning activation, what indicates that the warning is not false, and that recovery action is required?

key_points: STALL A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift
Specifically, a stall occurs when the AOA—the angle between the chord line of the wing and the relative wind—exceeds the wing’s critical AOA
It is possible to exceed the critical AOA at any airspeed, at any attitude, and at any power setting
learning.explanation: STALL A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift. Specifically, a stall occurs when the AOA—the angle between the chord line of the wing and the relative wind—exceeds the wing’s critical AOA. It is possible to exceed the critical AOA at any airspeed, at any attitude, and at any power setting. Impending Stall—an impending stall occurs when the AOA causes a stall warning, but has not yet reached the critical AOA. Indications of an impending stall can include buffeting, stick shaker, or aural warning. Full Stall—a full stall occurs when the critical AOA is exceeded. Indications of a full stall are typically that an uncommanded nose-down pitch cannot be readily arrested, and this may be accompanied by an uncommanded rolling motion. The flying controls will feel unresponsive or “mushy”. For airplanes equipped with stick pushers, its activation is also a full stall indication.

options.C: In a coordinated turn, the angle of attack decreases.
options.D: In a coordinated turn, the aircraft experiences a decrease in weight.

key_points: Load factor is the ratio of the weight of an aircraft to the lift
In a 45° level turn, weight always acts vertically downwards and lift acts perpendicular on the main wing
For the aircraft to maintain altitude, the vertical force components must be balanced
learning.explanation: Load factor is the ratio of the weight of an aircraft to the lift. In a 45° level turn, weight always acts vertically downwards and lift acts perpendicular on the main wing. For the aircraft to maintain altitude, the vertical force components must be balanced. Lift is inclined from the vertical by the bank angle φ of 45° and must be increased in order to balance the weight and produce a force to perform the turn. More lift compared to the same weight increases the load factor n. Influence of the Load Factor (n) on Stall Speed VS = VS1G x √ n Because the load factor (n) increases in a turn, stall speed will increase accordingly. An accelerated stall is caused by abrupt or excessive control movements inducing an increased load factor. An accelerated stall can occur during a sudden change in the flight path, during manoeuvres such as steep turns or a recovery from a descent. It is called an accelerated stall because it occurs at a load factor greater than 1g. The stall is more violent than a 1g stall and is often unexpected because of the relatively high airspeed.

Some in-service incidents have revealed corners of the operating envelope where turbulence or additional manoeuvre loads can result in momentary nuisance stall warning events

learning.explanation: NUISANCE STALL WARNING A nuisance stall warning event is one in which the stall warning activates although the airplane is not near a stall condition. Some in-service incidents have revealed corners of the operating envelope where turbulence or additional manoeuvre loads can result in momentary nuisance stall warning events. Most of the conditions leading to nuisance stall warning events are related to moderate to severe turbulence when operating at or near the Maximum Operating Altitude. In this scenario, the crew should confirm the stall with other indications and flight instruments such as airspeed, altitude and attitude. In general, every stall warning should be taken seriously and the response appropriate to the phase of flight and flight conditions.

key_points: When an airplane is flying, the wings generate lift to keep it in the air
The horizontal stabilizer, located at the tail of the aircraft, helps control the pitch or the up-and-down motion of the plane
Now, if ice accumulates on the horizontal stabilizer, it can disrupt the smooth airflow over the tail
learning.explanation: When an airplane is flying, the wings generate lift to keep it in the air. The horizontal stabilizer, located at the tail of the aircraft, helps control the pitch or the up-and-down motion of the plane. Now, if ice accumulates on the horizontal stabilizer, it can disrupt the smooth airflow over the tail. This disruption can lead to a stall, which is a situation where the wings or tail lose their lift due to the disrupted airflow. When a stall occurs, the normal balance between the wings and the tail is disturbed. In the case of a horizontal stabilizer stall, there will be a large decrease in nose up pitching moments, causing the nose to drop.

content.question: The load factor is less than 1 (one):

options.A: in steady wings level horizontal flight.
options.B: during a push-over manoeuvre.
options.C: during recovery after a wings level stall.
options.D: during a steady horizontal turn.

key_points: The balance of forces in steady climb show thrust is partly acting upwards and weight is partly adding to the drag
Because the thrust is now assisting lift, there is less lift required than in level flight
For steady speed, the thrust and two effects of aerodynamic drag and weight must be equal
learning.explanation: The balance of forces in steady climb show thrust is partly acting upwards and weight is partly adding to the drag. Because the thrust is now assisting lift, there is less lift required than in level flight. For steady speed, the thrust and two effects of aerodynamic drag and weight must be equal. T= Thrust W= Weight D= Drag T= D + W sin(alfa) This means that the climb angle (sin alfa) depends on excess thrust and weight. In descent the formula will become T= D – W sin(alfa) The load factor is the relationship between lift and weight. As the lift in a stall is decreased and the load factor in straight and level flight is 1, the load factor will now be less than 1. The steeper the climb-/descent angle, the lower the load factor. A push-over manoeuvre is a manoeuvre where there is more weight than lift. A negative G-force is therefore generated and the load factor is less than 1.

content.question: During a turn from base to final, the pilot applies more rudder to the inside of the turn, skidding the aircraft, to avoid overshooting the runway. The risk is:

options.A: Exceeding the limit load factor.
options.B: Spin towards the low wing.
options.C: Over-speeding the aircraft.
options.D: Spin towards the high wing.

key_points: Most stall-spin accidents don't happen during an intentional stall
They usually happen unintentionally and down low - like when you're turning base to final
During a skid, the aircraft is turning too fast for the bank angle, and yaws into the turn
learning.explanation: Most stall-spin accidents don't happen during an intentional stall. They usually happen unintentionally and down low - like when you're turning base to final. During a skid, the aircraft is turning too fast for the bank angle, and yaws into the turn. (Most likely, you're pushing too much rudder and causing the skid.) That causes the outside wing to move faster, increasing its lift, and causing the aircraft to roll into the turn. You compensate by adding opposite aileron - increasing the angle of attack on the inside, low wing. As the inside wing exceeds the critical angle of attack, it stalls and drops. The downward deflected aileron on the low wing is still generating drag, which pulls the aircraft's nose further into the turn. And, the aircraft is still yawing into the turn from the rudder, which accelerates the roll. The result is a quick roll into the turn, and your entry into an incipient spin => In a skidding spin, the low/inside wing stalls first, which rolls the plane into the turn, flipping it "inside" or "underneath".

content.question: An aircraft with a far aft CG location enters a spin, which becomes fully developed. Which of the following aircraft attitudes would be most likely in this scenario?

options.B: Increasing nose down pitch with increasing speed.
options.C: Nose level.

key_points: Flat spins are the worst and most dangerous type of spin
In a flat spin, the aircraft has no forward airspeed
It spins around its vertical axis as it sinks straight towards the ground
learning.explanation: Flat spins are the worst and most dangerous type of spin. In a flat spin, the aircraft has no forward airspeed. It spins around its vertical axis as it sinks straight towards the ground. Due to the high angle of attack of a flat spin, it is nearly impossible to recover, as the horizontal stabilizer is most likely in stall, too. The only possibility then is to move the CG forward. In small aircraft what you can do is to lean forward and hope for the best. The type of spin a plane enters depends mainly on the CG Position (and thrust setting): CG towards the forward limit makes an aircraft more stable, and control forces will be higher which makes it less likely that large, abrupt control movements will be made. When trimmed, the aeroplane will tend to return to level flight if the controls are released, but the stall speed will be higher. CG towards the aft limit decreases longitudinal static stability and reduces pitch control forces, which tends to make the aeroplane easier to stall. Once a spin is entered, the further aft the CG, the flatter the spin attitude. All in all, do not spin with an aircraft that is not designed for that or with too aft CG position. learning.explanation: The buffet onset boundary chart has both high and low speed limits. The low speed buffet boundary marks the onset of the pre stall buffet with a 10% margin above stall speed. The high speed buffet boundary marks the onset of high speed buffeting. This speed is Mmo most of the time, sometimes it is slightly below. These speeds come closer together as altitude increases. At a certain altitude the aircraft can encounter the so called “Coffin corner”. The speeds for high and low speed buffeting are very close together here, and thus it is easy to stall or hit Mmo. The coffin corner is a dangerous situation and is supposed to be avoided, as a slight amount of turbulence could cause the aircraft to stall. The speeds for high and low speed buffeting are dependent on weight, altitude, load factor and CG position. On the buffet onset boundary chart we will find the variables for altitude, weight and load factor. The margins between high and low speed buffeting can be decreased by: Higher aircraft weight Higher altitude Higher load factor More forward CG position

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Regarding the Buffet Onset Boundary Chart in the annex, which of these statements are correct or incorrect?
1. Flying at M = 0.8 provides the optimum margin with respect to buffet onset.
2. The maximum altitude that can be achieved with respect to buffet onset, according to Certification Specifications, is higher at M = 0.82 than at M = 0.75.

options.A: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting
Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure
Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage
learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. The aircraft must therefore be operated in such a manner that a (safety) margin exists before aerodynamic buffet will occur. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved. This is called a ‘Buffet Onset’ chart which is used by flight crews to ensure their aircraft is always operated with a specified minimum buffet margin. For any given combination of mass, center of gravity position and airspeed, the maximum operating altitude is that altitude at which a normal positive acceleration increment of 0.3g, without exceeding the buffet onset boundary, is possible. It is, therefore, common practice to draw the ‘buffet-onset boundary chart’ for a range of cruise masses at 1.3 g. Any maneuver having a load factor exceeding 1.3 g will initiate the buffet onset. In this exercise: This chart is specific to an aircraft, and shows the relationship of altitude, load factor, cruise data, weight, Mach number, and IAS. The optimum speed can be found by intersecting the top of the altitude curve. In this case it is M0.80, therefore statement 1 is correct. Start by drawing a vertical line from M0.82 and M0.75 to the FL410 curve (first altitude curve). From here, draw a straight line from left to right that intersects the weight curves. Finally, draw a vertical up from 1.3 g load factor that intersects the lines drawn in step 2. As we can see, flying at M0.82 gives us the ability to carry a greater weight. We can then conclude that it also gives us a higher buffet onset margin, therefore statement 2 is correct.

content.question:
What sort of characteristics should a pilot expect from a swept-back wing when it begins to stall, and why?
The aeroplane will:

options.A: Pitch up, due to forward movement of the centre of pressure, caused by the wing tips stalling first.
options.B: Pitch down, due to aft movement of the centre of pressure, caused by the wing root stalling first.
options.C: Pitch up, due to reduced downwash at the tailplane, caused by the wing root stalling first.
options.D: Pitch down, due to increased downwash at the tailplane, caused by the wing tips stalling first.

key_points: A simple swept-wing will stall at the wing tip first if not induced/controlled to stall at another wing section first by the designer

This is so because the outer wing section experiences a higher aerodynamic loading due to the wing taper, which causes a greater angle of incidence to be experienced to a degree where the airflow stalls at the wing tips
The boundary layer span-wise airflow, also a result of sweep, further contributes to the airflow stalling at the wing tips
learning.explanation: A simple swept-wing will stall at the wing tip first if not induced/controlled to stall at another wing section first by the designer. This is so because the outer wing section experiences a higher aerodynamic loading due to the wing taper, which causes a greater angle of incidence to be experienced to a degree where the airflow stalls at the wing tips. The boundary layer span-wise airflow, also a result of sweep, further contributes to the airflow stalling at the wing tips. A stall at the wing tip causes a loss of lift outboard and therefore aft (due to the wing sweep), which moves the center of pressure inboard and therefore forward; this produces a pitch-up tendency that continues as the wing stalls progressively further inboard.

content.question: Incipient spin is the term assigned to the phase of a spin:

options.A: After the initial couple of rotations and the aerodynamic forces present are in balance.
options.B: After the initial couple of rotations but the aerodynamic forces present are not yet fully balanced.
options.C: When the initial rotation starts and the aerodynamic forces present are in balance.
options.D: When the initial rotation starts but the aerodynamic forces present are not yet fully balanced.

key_points: SPIN
A stall must occur before a spin can take place
A spin occurs when one wing stalls more than the other
learning.explanation: SPIN. A stall must occur before a spin can take place. A spin occurs when one wing stalls more than the other. There are three phases of spin: INCIPIENT phase - exists from the time the aeroplane stalls and rotation starts until the spin is fully developed. This may not occur until 2 to 4 rotations have been completed - however, according to EASA, incipient spin starts already whenever, in the post stall regime, there is an uncommanded roll in excess of 45 degrees which is the result of yaw assymetry during a stall. During this phrase, the aerodynamic forces are not balanced and the aircraft is more or less tumbling. DEVELOPED phase - begins when the aerodynamic forces are in balance (the angular rotation rates, airspeed and vertical descent rate are stabilized from one turn to the next). The spin, although chaotic looking from inside the cockpit, has been established and recovery procedures are now necessary to break the spin. RECOVERY phase - controls are applied to stop spin, recover from the unusual attitude and maintain straight and level.

options.C: There will be no adverse effects as the aircraft systems are designed to compensate for such discrepancies automatically.
options.D: The aircraft will begin descending and experience a subsequent loss of speed control.

key_points: If the pitot tubes get blocked in the climb, but the static ports remain free, then the indicated airspeed will initially stop changing with airspeed, and will now gradually increase with altitude as the static pressure reduces (the airspeed indicator now acts like an altimeter)

In the climb, this may not be noticeable for a while, and might not be noticed at all if the autopilot was in certain modes, such as those which maintain a constant rate of climb (assuming constant thrust)
Whatever happens, as the aircraft continues to climb, the actual airspeed is unknown whilst the indicated airspeed (IAS) is showing a continuous increase
learning.explanation: If the pitot tubes get blocked in the climb, but the static ports remain free, then the indicated airspeed will initially stop changing with airspeed, and will now gradually increase with altitude as the static pressure reduces (the airspeed indicator now acts like an altimeter). In the climb, this may not be noticeable for a while, and might not be noticed at all if the autopilot was in certain modes, such as those which maintain a constant rate of climb (assuming constant thrust). Whatever happens, as the aircraft continues to climb, the actual airspeed is unknown whilst the indicated airspeed (IAS) is showing a continuous increase. This is particularly dangerous in modes such as level change or flight level change, which maintain a constant airspeed/Mach No. in the climb, as the aircraft would pitch up more and more to try to reduce the "increasing airspeed", stalling the aircraft quite quickly. If the aircraft does not stall beforehand, then when maximum airspeed is reached, the pilots or autopilot/autothrottle will either reduce thrust or pitch up to avoid further airspeed increase, which will very quickly lead to a stall. As for the other options, the air data computer, autopilot and autothrottle systems have the same pitot inputs as the pilots do, so will not be able to protect the aircraft from this condition, that is one of the reasons that probe icing and blockages are so dangerous.

content.question: An aircraft comes out of a large maintenance overhaul which included both wings being disassembled and reassembled, but they were accidentally reassembled with slightly different angles of incidence. During the post-maintenance check flight, the pilot must fly close to the stall speed. Which of the following may happen in this situation?

options.A: The stall behaviour is not affected by the angle of incidence, so the aircraft will stall as intended.
options.B: Both wings will stall simultaneously, so there will be no wing drop.
options.C: The wing that was reassembled with a lower angle of incidence stalls first, causing a wing drop.
options.D: The wing that was reassembled with a higher angle of incidence stalls first, causing a wing drop.

key_points: A wing stalls at or above a particular angle of attack, called the critical angle of attack
This is the angle between the relative airflow and the chord line of the wing
The angle of incidence is the angle between the longitudinal axis of the aircraft (forward/backward axis)
learning.explanation: A wing stalls at or above a particular angle of attack, called the critical angle of attack. This is the angle between the relative airflow and the chord line of the wing. The angle of incidence is the angle between the longitudinal axis of the aircraft (forward/backward axis). If the wings have been mounted with different angles of incidence, then they will constantly be at a different angles of attack. The wing with the higher angle of incidence will always be at a higher angle of attack. Whilst this could be quite noticeable in normal flight, it would likely be most noticeable at or near the stall speed, where the wing with a slightly higher angle of attack will be the one to stall first, but whilst the other wing is still producing a lot of lift. This would cause a violent wing drop towards the side of the stalled wing. This theory is used on some wings to make sure that the wing root stalls first, by twisting the wing to give the root a higher angle of incidence than the wing tip. This is called "washout".

content.question: Two methods to increase the critical Mach number are:

options.A: thin aerofoils and dihedral of the wing.
options.B: thick aerofoils and dihedral of the wing.
options.C: thin aerofoils and sweepback of the wing.
options.D: positive cambering of the aerofoil and sweepback of the wing.

key_points: Above MCRIT speeds, a shock wave develops on the upper surface of the wing
This causes the boundary layer to separate behind the shock wave, leading to a loss of lift and reduction in the lift coefficient (CL) (shock stall)
The shock stall occurs when the lift coefficient, as a function of Mach number, reaches its maximum value for a given angle of attack
learning.explanation: Above MCRIT speeds, a shock wave develops on the upper surface of the wing. This causes the boundary layer to separate behind the shock wave, leading to a loss of lift and reduction in the lift coefficient (CL) (shock stall). The shock stall occurs when the lift coefficient, as a function of Mach number, reaches its maximum value for a given angle of attack. Wings not specifically designed for high speeds may experience significant lift loss at speeds above MCRIT. However, wings designed for high-speed flight, incorporating features like sweepback, thinner sections, and reduced camber, exhibit much less variation in lift throughout the transonic region. Sweeping the wing back is a widely employed method to increase MCRIT, the critical Mach number. By employing a swept wing, the free stream velocity is effectively divided into two components: one perpendicular to the leading edge and the other parallel to it. The component perpendicular to the leading edge is less than the free stream velocity and it is this velocity component which determines the magnitude of the pressure distribution and hence MCRIT. Due to this reduced velocity component affecting the pressure distribution, MCRIT increases. Furthermore, on wings with low thickness to chord ratios, the airflow acceleration over the upper wing surface is diminished. Consequently, the value of MCRIT is raised on such wings.

content.question:
(For this question use annex 081-001 issue date July 2009).
Determine the maximum mass with respect to buffet onset according to Certification Specifications for FL400?

options.A: 110 tons.
options.B: 104 tons.
options.C: 91 tons for a 45 degree banked turn.
options.D: 121 tons for a 30 degree banked turn.

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting
Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure
Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage
learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. The aircraft must therefore be operated in such a manner that a (safety) margin exists before aerodynamic buffet will occur. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved. This is called a ‘Buffet Onset’ chart which is used by flight crews to ensure their aircraft is always operated with a specified minimum buffet margin. For any given combination of mass, center of gravity position and airspeed, the maximum operating altitude is that altitude at which a normal positive acceleration increment of 0.3 g, without exceeding the buffet onset boundary, is possible. It is, therefore, common practice to draw the ‘buffet-onset boundary chart’ for a range of cruise masses at 1.3 g. Any maneuver having a load factor exceeding 1.3 g will initiate the buffet onset. In this exercise: Start by drawing a vertical line from M0.80 to the FL400 curve. From here, draw a straight line from left to right that intersects the weight curves. Finally, draw a vertical up from 1.3 g load factor to asset the limiting weight. In this case, the limiting weight is 110 tons.

content.question: Consider a conventional aircraft. Which of the following may occur if the tailplane stalls?

options.A: A pitch-up moment.
options.B: A pitch-down moment.
options.C: No effect in pitch.
options.D: An increase in roll rate.

key_points: The tailplane is a smaller lifting surface found aft of the main wing, on the tail of many fixed wing aircraft
Like the main wing, a tailplane is designed to operate with smooth airflow along its surface
When the airflow separates from the tailplane, this is referred to as a tailplane stall
learning.explanation: The tailplane is a smaller lifting surface found aft of the main wing, on the tail of many fixed wing aircraft. Like the main wing, a tailplane is designed to operate with smooth airflow along its surface. When the airflow separates from the tailplane, this is referred to as a tailplane stall. This could be caused by ice build-up, by unusual attitudes, or during aggressive manoeuvres when the angle of attack (usually negative for the tail) becomes extreme. The tailplane is designed to produce a downward force (resulting in "negative" lift) in normal operation. Therefore, when the tailplane stalls, this downforce will no longer exist, resulting in a sudden uncommanded nose-down pitching moment.

content.question: You are the pilot flying a light aeroplane with a clockwise turning propeller. While you are distracted by having to deal with a minor equipment failure, the stall warning horn activates. Which of the following would indicate that the aircraft had entered a full stall, if you do NOT respond to the warning and try to maintain level flight using the elevator?

options.A: The nose pitching down with a full pitch-up elevator.
options.B: The aileron controls give a feeling of a heavy buffet.
options.C: The effect of the rudder control being reversed.
options.D: The nose yaws to the right regardless of the rudder input.

key_points: When the lift developed by an aeroplane wing is no longer sufficient to sustain the mass of the aeroplane in flight, in the configuration being considered, the wing is stalled
A stall is caused by airflow separation
Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great
learning.explanation: When the lift developed by an aeroplane wing is no longer sufficient to sustain the mass of the aeroplane in flight, in the configuration being considered, the wing is stalled. A stall is caused by airflow separation. Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great. STALLING ANGLE OF ATTACK At a constant mass and air density, the coefficient of lift (CL), and consequently the total amount of lift, is dependent on the angle of attack. Graphically, lift increases almost linearly from an angle of attack of 0º to 4º, and then at an increasing rate to 15º. Lift cannot be obtained without incurring the penalty of drag. At a specific angle of attack, depending on circumstances, the lift generated is insufficient to sustain the aircraft in level flight. The angle of attack at which this occurs is the stalling angle or critical angle and is the point at which CLMAX is attained. An aeroplane will not stall unless the critical angle is exceeded. The aeroplane may be considered stalled when the behaviour of the aeroplane gives a clear distinctive indication of an unacceptable nature to the pilot that the aeroplane is stalled. Acceptable indications of a stall, occurring either individually or in combination are: a. A nose-down pitch that cannot be readily arrested. b. Buffeting, of a magnitude and severity that is a strong and effective deterrent to further speed reduction. c. The pitch control reaches the aft stop and no further increase in pitch attitude occurs when the control is held full aft for a short time before recovery is initiated. d. Unresponsive flight controls.

content.question:
Which statement is correct?
I. Stall speeds are determined with the CG at the forward limit.
II. Minimum control speeds are determined with the CG at the aft limit.

options.A: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.B: I is correct, II is correct.
options.C: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is correct.

key_points: Stall speeds are determined with the least favourible CG position
For an aircraft, this is the most forward point because then the main wing will be producing the most lift
With the CG furthest ahead of the centre of pressure, the horizontal stabilizer will be producing a downwards force, which the main wings will have to compensate for by producing more lift
learning.explanation: Stall speeds are determined with the least favourible CG position. For an aircraft, this is the most forward point because then the main wing will be producing the most lift. With the CG furthest ahead of the centre of pressure, the horizontal stabilizer will be producing a downwards force, which the main wings will have to compensate for by producing more lift. The main wings will therefore have to be at a higher angle of attack and therefore be closer to the stall. Hence the stall will occur at higher speeds with a forward CG then with a rearward CG. Minimum control speeds are also determined with the least favourible conditions. When considering an engine failure, we know that the aircraft will rotate around its CG, but the distance of the moment doesn’t change when it moves fore or aft, the engines moment would only change when we move it along the lateral axis of the aircraft. However, the position of the CG will influence the rudder arm, and hence the rudder moment. A CG on the af limit will provide a small arm and therefore the least ability to oppose the yawing moment of the engine failure.

3g (corresponding to 40° of bank angle in level fl ight)

The buffet onset corresponds by defi nition to 1.3g (corresponding to 40° of bank angle in level fl ight). The “deterrent buffet” is so strong that any pilot will feel he/she needs to leave these buffet conditions. It corresponds to one of the definitions of stall and is considered to be the stall limit on a jet transport aircraft. Deterrent Buffet - the airplane exhibits sufficient buffet that the flight crew will be deterred from commanding even higher AOA.

content.question: What are the possible consequences for an aircraft encountering wind shear on final approach?

options.A: The aeroplane stalls when tailwind increases.
options.B: The aeroplane stalls when headwind increases.
options.C: The aeroplane tends to dive when crosswind increases.
options.D: Turbulence will be felt but there are no other hazards.

key_points: MICROBURSTS These are the most lethal forms of windshear

They normally occur in the vicinity of thunderstorms and are mainly associated with cumulonimbus clouds THE EFFECT OF A MICROBURST ENCOUNTER DURING THE APPROACH The attached depicts how an aircraft typically reacts when subject to a microburst during the approach: - Increasing headwinds, causing the IAS to rise (temporary energy gain) and the aircraft to climb above the glidepath
- A downdraught that increases the rate of descent and decreases the IAS, thereby causing the aircraft to drop further below the glidepath
learning.explanation: MICROBURSTS These are the most lethal forms of windshear. They normally occur in the vicinity of thunderstorms and are mainly associated with cumulonimbus clouds THE EFFECT OF A MICROBURST ENCOUNTER DURING THE APPROACH The attached depicts how an aircraft typically reacts when subject to a microburst during the approach: - Increasing headwinds, causing the IAS to rise (temporary energy gain) and the aircraft to climb above the glidepath. - A downdraught that increases the rate of descent and decreases the IAS, thereby causing the aircraft to drop further below the glidepath. The situation worsens if the nose is still high and the thrust setting low. - On leaving the downdraught, increasing tail winds cause a further reduction in IAS (Temporary Energy Loss). The rate of descent may lessen due to increased thrust availability. This may lead to a reduction in airspeed below the stalling speed and if operating at high angles of attack, which are normally associated with the approach and landing phases of flight, the wing may stall. A successful recovery from a microburst encounter depends on the altitude, thrust, and speed reserves available. In addition to these effects, severe wind, turbulence, heavy rain, and blinding flashes of lightning often accompany microbursts.

content.question: Which stall-detection device uses the movement of the leading-edge stagnation point to detect a stall?

options.A: A flapper switch.
options.B: A stick shaker.
options.C: An angle of attack vane.
options.D: An angle of attack probe.

key_points: To augment pre-stall buffet, light aircraft normally have an audible stall-warning device that operates just before the stall
This device is activated by a moving vane (Flapper Switch), positioned approximately midway along the wing, just below the leading edge as seen in figure 1
Airflow holds down the vane at normal operating angles of attack, but just before the wing stalls, movement of the stagnation point around the leading edge lifts the vane (figure 2)
learning.explanation: To augment pre-stall buffet, light aircraft normally have an audible stall-warning device that operates just before the stall. This device is activated by a moving vane (Flapper Switch), positioned approximately midway along the wing, just below the leading edge as seen in figure 1. Airflow holds down the vane at normal operating angles of attack, but just before the wing stalls, movement of the stagnation point around the leading edge lifts the vane (figure 2). This closes a micro-switch and sounds a buzzer in the cockpit, giving warning of an impending stall. On some light aircraft, a flashing red light on the instrument panel replaces the aural warning. On aircraft cleared to operate in icing conditions, the sensing device is electrically heated. Stall warning normally activates 5 to 10 knots above the stalling speed.

content.question: You are the pilot flying of a commercial jet aircraft and just started your descent by using the autopilot, which controls the speed with pitch control. Passing FL340, the aeroplane passes through a jet stream and experiences a sudden positive wind shear. The speed increases momentarily to M0.85 causing the autopilot to demand a pitch up to arrest the speed increase. Since M0.85 is approximately 5 kt faster than MMO, you may...

options.A: feel a slight vibration as a result of the increased positive load factor creating some buffet, due to shock waves during the overspeed.
options.B: experience a slight “Mach tuck” effect as shock waves increase in strength, leading to further speed increase and loss of speed control.
options.C: experience momentary loss of control due to incipient shock stall until the aeroplane recovers and speed reduces below MMO.
options.D: feel significant buffeting from the shock waves, which from at speeds above MMO, further enhanced by the increased load factor.

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting
Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure
Aircraft must therefore be operated with a (safety) margin to aerodynamic buffet
learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Aircraft must therefore be operated with a (safety) margin to aerodynamic buffet. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved: - Load factor. - Mach number. - Angle of attack. - Pressure altitude. - Weight. - CG position. Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor. In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range. The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries.

content.question: Often, the tip of a wing will have a lower angle of incidence than the wing section near the root. Why?

options.A: To encourage the wingtip to stall first, keeping the aircraft controllable at high angles of attack.
options.B: To prevent tip stall.
options.C: To extend the boundary layer towards the wingtip.
options.D: To reduce induced drag, aiding with supersonic flight characteristics.

key_points: In some wing designs, separation tends to occur first in the region of the tip, reducing lift in those areas
If an actual wing were allowed to stall in this way, stalling would give aileron buffet and perhaps violent wing drop
The ailerons would become uncontrollable, so designers make modifications to stop this
learning.explanation: In some wing designs, separation tends to occur first in the region of the tip, reducing lift in those areas. If an actual wing were allowed to stall in this way, stalling would give aileron buffet and perhaps violent wing drop. The ailerons would become uncontrollable, so designers make modifications to stop this. To give favourable stall characteristics, many wing types must be modified using one or more of the following: Geometric twist (washout), a decrease in incidence from root to tip. This decreases the angle of attack at the tip, and the root will tend to stall first, which is desirable. The aerofoil section may be varied throughout the span such that sections with greater thickness and camber are located near the tip. The higher CLMAX of such sections delays stall earlier, so that the root will tend to stall first.

content.question: A go-around is performed by the crew of a commercial jet aircraft with under-wing-mounted engines and conventional controls. Which of the following is correct?

options.A: Nose-down elevator deflection must be applied in order to counteract the large thrust pitch-up couple and to avoid a stall.
options.B: The size of the elevator is sufficient to give enough pitch control regardless of the trim position and applied thrust.
options.C: To counteract the thrust-pitch couple, application of nose-up trim will be required to regain elevator authority.
options.D: The engine's line-of-thrust offset, relative to the fuselage centreline, will produce a nose-down pitch couple.

key_points: When applying TOGA (takeoff go-around power or thrust) a significant increase in thrust occurs
With underwing mounted engines, as most jet transport category aeroplanes, the engines will create a pitch up moment around the CG
Combined with the commanded pitch-up by the pilot, the pitch attitude can increase too much
learning.explanation: When applying TOGA (takeoff go-around power or thrust) a significant increase in thrust occurs. With underwing mounted engines, as most jet transport category aeroplanes, the engines will create a pitch up moment around the CG. Combined with the commanded pitch-up by the pilot, the pitch attitude can increase too much. This can exceed the critical angle of attack, resulting in a stall. The acceleration forces felt by the pilot can trigger a sensation of too much pitch-up, resulting in the pilot commanding a pitch-down. Mitigation during a go-around consists of a good scanning of all the flight parameters by the pilot and giving priority on the instruments instead of sensations. The aeroplane manufacturer can improve this by integrating active flight envelope protection.

content.question:
An aircraft is flying through the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) at the planned cruising altitude when it experiences severe turbulence, which causes buffeting. Which action(s) should be taken?
1. Accurately maintain altitude,
2. Increase altitude,
3. Set turbulence speed,
4. Descend to a lower level.

options.A: 1 and 3
options.B: 3 and 4
options.C: 2 and 3
options.D: 2 only

key_points: The ITCZ The ITCZ in known for a trough that is centred on the thermal equator
High temperatures cause low pressure, The main feature of the ITCZ is extensive Cu, Cb, and thunderstorms
The cloud tops are sometimes as low as 20,000 ft but more frequently 50,000 ft or more
learning.explanation: The ITCZ The ITCZ in known for a trough that is centred on the thermal equator. High temperatures cause low pressure, The main feature of the ITCZ is extensive Cu, Cb, and thunderstorms. The cloud tops are sometimes as low as 20,000 ft but more frequently 50,000 ft or more. Turbulence is usually severe, as is icing, which can be from 16,000 ft upwards. Buffet Onset Chart In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. The ‘Buffet Onset’ chart is used by flight crews to ensure their aircraft is always operated with a specified minimum buffet margin. Turbulence Penetration Speed For flight in turbulence an airspeed must be chosen to give margin against stalling and overstressing the aircraft structure. This speed is VRA/MRA (the rough-air speed) or turbulence penetration speed. VRA/MRA will give adequate protection from over-stressing the aircraft with maximum protection from an inadvertent stall. In conclusion, clear air turbulence (CAT) can be caused by jetstreams, Cb’s, mountain waves, etc. with the same consequences as the ITCZ or jetstreams. Thunderstorms should be circumnavigated and preferably upwind. Extensive use of weather radar scanning is useful. A turbulence penetration speed should be selected to minimise the gust loads on the aircraft. When possible, descent to a lower altitude should be considered as it gives more performance and buffet margin to cope with gusts.

content.question: While flying slightly above the critical Mach number (MCRIT), a control surface is deflected down by a pilot input. What could happen?

options.A: The control surface’s efficiency might be reduced due to shock-induced separation.
options.B: The shock wave will disappear due to the downwards deflection of the control surface.
options.C: The control surface’s efficiency might be increased due to the shock wave itself.
options.D: Low speed buffet could take place due to shock-induced separation.

key_points: When shock waves form on the aircraft's wing, the shock induced separation behind them can lead to vibration and control surface ineffectiveness

The disturbed airflow over the control surfaces may cause uncommanded erratic movements, although this will not directly affect the air ahead of the shock wave, because the resulting pressure disturbances are prevented from travelling forward
The pressure distribution over the front of the wing is, however, altered, which varies the position of the wing’s center of pressure and its overall pitching moment
learning.explanation: When shock waves form on the aircraft's wing, the shock induced separation behind them can lead to vibration and control surface ineffectiveness. The disturbed airflow over the control surfaces may cause uncommanded erratic movements, although this will not directly affect the air ahead of the shock wave, because the resulting pressure disturbances are prevented from travelling forward. The pressure distribution over the front of the wing is, however, altered, which varies the position of the wing’s center of pressure and its overall pitching moment. This alters the wing’s angle of attack and results in rapid backward and forward movements of the shock waves. A kind of instability is set up, and the rapid changes in the pressure distribution result in vibration of the whole aircraft. This is primarily due to the distributed airflow behind the shock wave hitting the tail plane. If shock waves form on the control surfaces, it will also affect the stick forces by altering their hinge moments.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The pilot currently follows flight path 2 but desires to follow flight path 3. Despite having a bank angle of 25 degrees, the operator restricts the bank angle to 30 degrees for passenger comfort. What action should the pilot take?

options.A: Increase the bank angle to 30º and decrease speed to have a smaller radius.
options.B: Increase the bank angle to 30º and pull back on the stick.
options.C: Maintain bank angle 30º to maintain a margin but increase speed to increase the rate of turn.
options.D: Reduce bank angle to 15º to maintain a margin but increase speed to increase the rate of turn.

key_points: The formula for turn radius R is given by R = V2 / (g x tan Φ), where V is the true airspeed, g is the acceleration due to gravity, and Φ is the bank angle
The radius of turn at any given airspeed is inversly proportional to the bank angle, which means that a larger angle of bank will result in a smaller turn radius
The turn radius is dependent solely on the TAS for a given bank angle
learning.explanation: The formula for turn radius R is given by R = V2 / (g x tan Φ), where V is the true airspeed, g is the acceleration due to gravity, and Φ is the bank angle. The radius of turn at any given airspeed is inversly proportional to the bank angle, which means that a larger angle of bank will result in a smaller turn radius. The turn radius is dependent solely on the TAS for a given bank angle. To reduce the turn radius along flight path 3, the TAS can be decreased while maintaining the bank angle, or the bank angle can be increased while keeping the TAS constant. "bank 30 and pull back on stick" This option is partially correct. By increasing the bank angle, the turn radius will reduce. If we increase the bank angle, a pull force on the stick will be required to maintain the same altitude. However, if no action is taken to maintain the airspeed, it will decrease and may lead to a stall. "bank 25 degrees to maintain a margin but increase speed to increase the rate of turn" This option is incorrect. Maintaining the same bank angle while increasing speed will actually increase the turn radius.

content.question: Which one of the following statements is true with regards to the first stage of spin?

options.A: Spinning motion and the forces have not been equalized yet.
options.B: The forces have been stabilized.
options.C: Spinning motion decrease and forces stabilize.
options.D: Spinning motion will increase exponentially until the aircraft crashes.

key_points: SPIN
A stall must occur before a spin can take place
A spin occurs when one wing stalls more than the other
learning.explanation: SPIN. A stall must occur before a spin can take place. A spin occurs when one wing stalls more than the other. There are three phases of spin: INCIPIENT phase - exists from the time the aeroplane stalls and rotation starts until the spin is fully developed. During this phrase, the aerodynamic forces are not balanced and the aircraft is more or less tumbling. DEVELOPED phase - begins when the aerodynamic forces are in balance (the angular rotation rates, airspeed and vertical descent rate are stabilized from one turn to the next). The spin, although chaotic looking from inside the cockpit, has been established and recovery procedures are now necessary to break the spin. RECOVERY phase - controls are applied to stop spin, recover from the unusual attitude and maintain straight and level.

content.question: What could happen if there is ice accumulation on the elevator or stabiliser and the flaps are lowered?

options.A: Increased downwash.
options.B: Decreased drag, leading to better fuel efficiency.
options.C: Increased lift due to improved aerodynamics.
options.D: Improved stall characteristics, making stalls less likely.

key_points: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does
The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack

The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost
learning.explanation: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does. The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack. The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost. Stalling of an ice contaminated tailplane could be precipitated by extension of the wing flaps. Lowering the flaps increases the downwash, and this increases the negative angle of attack of the tailplane. If the tailplane has ice contamination, this could be sufficient to cause it to stall. Recovery procedure in this situation would be to retract the flaps again, thus reducing the downwash. Take care when increasing an aircraft's forward airspeed to compensate for ice on the wings, since every knot of airspeed added to prevent wing stall brings the aircraft a knot closer to tailplane stall. Consequently, it is vital that the tailplane, like the wing, is free from contamination. This type of stall does not usually occur, but if it does, recovery is normally impossible.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Regarding the Buffet Onset Boundary Chart in the annexe, which of these statements are correct or incorrect?
1. Flying at M = 0.84 provides the optimum margin with respect to buffet onset.
2. The maximum altitude that can be achieved with respect to buffet onset, according to Certification Specifications, is higher at M = 0.82 than at M = 0.75.

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting
Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure
Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage
learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. The aircraft must therefore be operated in such a manner that a (safety) margin exists before aerodynamic buffet will occur. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved. This is called a ‘Buffet Onset’ chart which is used by flight crews to ensure their aircraft is always operated with a specified minimum buffet margin. For any given combination of mass, center of gravity position and airspeed, the maximum operating altitude is that altitude at which a normal positive acceleration increment of 0.3 g, without exceeding the buffet onset boundary, is possible. It is, therefore, common practice to draw the ‘buffet-onset boundary chart’ for a range of cruise masses at 1.3 g. Any maneuver having a load factor exceeding 1.3 g will initiate the buffet onset. In this exercise: This chart is specific to an aircraft, and shows the relationship of altitude, load factor, cruise data, weight, Mach number, and IAS. The optimum speed can be found by intersecting the top of the altitude curve. In this case it is M0.80, therefore statement 1 is incorrect. Start by drawing a vertical line from M0.82 and M0.75 to the FL410 curve (first altitude curve). From here, draw a straight line from left to right that intersects the weight curves. Finally, draw a vertical up from 1.3 g load factor that intersects the lines drawn in step 2. As we can see, flying at M0.82 gives us the ability to carry a greater weight. We can then conclude that it also gives us a higher buffet onset margin, therefore statement 2 is correct.

content.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a turbulent boundary layer?

options.A: Greater laminar flow transition tendency.
options.B: Reduced ability to follow a profile.
options.C: Lower drag due to reduced mixing.
options.D: Better ability to follow a profile.

key_points: In contrast to a laminar layer, a turbulent boundary layer exhibits greater thickness and higher skin friction
With increased energy, it displays a reduced tendency to separate from the surface
This higher level of kinetic energy, results in the ability of a turbulent layer to follow a shape better than a laminar flow
learning.explanation: In contrast to a laminar layer, a turbulent boundary layer exhibits greater thickness and higher skin friction. With increased energy, it displays a reduced tendency to separate from the surface. This higher level of kinetic energy, results in the ability of a turbulent layer to follow a shape better than a laminar flow. The thin laminar layer is highly responsive to surface irregularities. Any roughness on the leading portion of an aircraft's skin triggers a transition to turbulence at that point. This results in the thickening of the turbulent boundary layer, which fans out downstream and leads to a significant rise in skin friction drag.

It then releases from the surface and causes flow reversal along the top of the surface of the wing

It then releases from the surface and causes flow reversal along the top of the surface of the wing. The earlier the separation, the larger area is covered with reversal flow, meaning less off the wing is producing lift. Do not confuse separation point with the transition point! Transition point is that where the boundary layer goes from laminar to turbulent. See the difference in the figure.
