content.question: Consider only the wing and tail moments of an aircraft. How will the following changes affect the relationship between CM and Alpha?

options.A: Moving the tailplane aft and increasing the surface will increase the negative CM for a given AoA.
options.B: Moving the wing forward will have the same effect as moving the tailplane aft.
options.C: Moving the tailplane forward and decreasing the surface will increase the positive CM for a given AoA.
options.D: Increasing the wing area will decrease the CM variation with AoA.

key_points: Static longitudinal stability depends upon the relationship between angle of attack (α) and pitching moment coefficient (CM)
Consideration must be given to the pitching moment contribution of each aircraft component
The pitching moment coefficients contributed by all the various components of the aircraft are summed and plotted versus lift coefficient (angle of attack)
learning.explanation: Static longitudinal stability depends upon the relationship between angle of attack (α) and pitching moment coefficient (CM). Consideration must be given to the pitching moment contribution of each aircraft component. The pitching moment coefficients contributed by all the various components of the aircraft are summed and plotted versus lift coefficient (angle of attack). Figure 1, shows the variation of pitching moment coefficient (CM) with lift coefficient (CL) for an aircraft with positive static longitudinal stability. Static stability is shown by a return to equilibrium, or trim, upon displacement. The aeroplane described by graph A is in trim or equilibrium when CM = 0. If the aeroplane is disturbed to some different CL, the pitching moment change tends to return the aircraft to the point of trim. If the aeroplane were disturbed to some higher CL (point y), a negative or nose-down pitching moment is produced which tends to decrease angle of attack back to the trim point. If the aeroplane were disturbed to some lower CL (point x), a positive or nose-up pitching moment is developed which tends to increase the angle of attack back to the trim point. Positive static longitudinal stability is indicated by a negative slope of CM versus CL. The degree of static longitudinal stability is indicated by the slope of the curve. Effect of Wing and Tail Position (figure 2) When the aerodynamic stability of a configuration is looked at, power effects are ignored and the stability is considered by a build-up of the contributing components. If the CG is set at 30 ̊ percent MAC, the contribution of the wing alone is destabilising, as indicated by the positive slope of CM versus CL. The combination of the wing and fuselage increases the instability. The contribution of the tail alone is highly stabilising from the large negative slope of the curve. By moving the tail aft (increasing the distance to the CG) and increasing its area both contribute to the stabilising moment, which means that the slope will be steeper, making this the correct answer.

content.question: Given an aeroplane in steady, straight and level flight at low speed and considering the effects of CG location and thrust, the lowest value of wing lift occurs at:

options.A: aft CG and high thrust.
options.B: aft CG and low thrust.
options.C: forward CG and low thrust.
options.D: forward CG and high thrust.

key_points: CG location: As you can see in the diagram, rearward cg location requires less lift than a forward one because the horizontal stabilizer can contribute to the total lift instead of it working against (downwards) the total lift in the case of a forward cg
Therefore, a rearward cg requires least wing lift
Thrust: Assuming a pitch up attitude (otherwise thrust would be irrelevant), thrust helps to lift up the aircraft and can reduce the lift required by the wing
learning.explanation: CG location: As you can see in the diagram, rearward cg location requires less lift than a forward one because the horizontal stabilizer can contribute to the total lift instead of it working against (downwards) the total lift in the case of a forward cg. Therefore, a rearward cg requires least wing lift. Thrust: Assuming a pitch up attitude (otherwise thrust would be irrelevant), thrust helps to lift up the aircraft and can reduce the lift required by the wing. This is because at high pitch angle, thrust will produce a vertical component, as can be seen in the right hand side of the figure. Therefore, a high thrust requires the least wing lift.

content.question: An aircraft exhibits both (1) _____ and (2) _____. Which of the following pairs may correctly describe this situation?

options.A: (1) positive dynamic stability; (2) neutral static stability
options.B: (1) positive dynamic stability; (2) positive static stability
options.C: (1) negative dynamic stability; (2) neutral static stability
options.D: (1) neutral dynamic stability; (2) negative static stability

key_points: Static stability pertains to how a system reacts immediately when disturbed
In a statically stable system, when disturbed, it initially moves back toward its equilibrium state
An aircraft's type of static stability is defined by its initial reaction after some external force is removed
learning.explanation: Static stability pertains to how a system reacts immediately when disturbed. In a statically stable system, when disturbed, it initially moves back toward its equilibrium state. An aircraft's type of static stability is defined by its initial reaction after some external force is removed. We use the term "static" because we're only concerned with the initial tendency to return to equilibrium, without considering subsequent motion. Dynamic stability, on the other hand, covers what happens after this. An aircraft can only have any measurement of dynamic stability if it is first statically stable. If an aircraft is then dynamically stable, the oscillations will gradually reduce until the aircraft is back at equilibrium. Neutral dynamic stability will mean the aircraft continues to oscillate either side of equilibrium by the same amount (no damping). Dynamic instability (negative dynamic stability) means the aircraft oscillations get larger in magnitude each time. For this question, it is very important to note that any form of dynamic stability (or instability) can only come if the aircraft first has positive static stability. Without first going towards the equilibrium point, there are no oscillations to either shrink or grow. This means there is only one possible correct answer.

content.question: Given an aeroplane in steady, straight and level flight at low speed and considering the effects of CG location and thrust, the highest value of wing lift occurs at:

options.A: forward CG and low thrust.
options.B: aft CG and low thrust.
options.C: forward CG and high thrust.
options.D: aft CG and high thrust.

key_points: On the left side of the figure, we can see the effect of a forward moving c
g on the lift produced by the main wing
When moving forward, the c
learning.explanation: On the left side of the figure, we can see the effect of a forward moving c.g on the lift produced by the main wing. When moving forward, the c.g will cause either a reduced positive lift created by the horizontal stabilizer, or an increase in negative lift. This is dependant on whether the c.g is located in front or behind the centre of pressure. Due to the decrease in positive lift or increase in negative lift of the tail, the main wing will have to compensate and produce more lift. Therefore a forward c.g will cause a higher value of wing lift. Secondly, on the right side of the figure, we can see the effect of a decrease in thrust on the aircraft at high angle of attack (slow speed flight). At high AoA the thrust will have a strong vertical component, therefore a high thrust will help lift the aircraft up and reduce the lift required. This is opposite when the thrust is reduced at high AoA, then the wings will have to compensate and create more lift to remain in level flight.

content.question: In an aircraft that has positive stick force stability, whilst remaining in straight and level flight and without retrimming, the elevator stick force required when accelerating from 70 to 75 kt will be _____ than the force required when accelerating from 100 to 105 kt.

options.A: greater than
options.B: less than
options.C: close to zero, and the same as
options.D: very large, and the same as

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: We believe that "greater than" is the correct answer here (and most recent feedback seems to agree), but we have varying feedback about the correct answer over the past few months
Please let us know in the comments if you see this question in the real exam, thanks
Also please note that this is a very different question to 811457, as many people (understandably) have connected the two
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: We believe that "greater than" is the correct answer here (and most recent feedback seems to agree), but we have varying feedback about the correct answer over the past few months. Please let us know in the comments if you see this question in the real exam, thanks. Also please note that this is a very different question to 811457, as many people (understandably) have connected the two. This question is about stick force stability, the force required to hold a different airspeed, whereas 811457 is about stick force per G, the force required to pull a particular G-force, so they are very different. Figure 1 indicates the variation of stick force with airspeed and illustrates the effect of tab setting on stick force. You can see from the graph, that dependent on EAS (Equivalent Air Speed) and trim tab setting, the stick force to hold a 1 kt change in airspeed from the trimmed speed DECREASES as the trimmed speed increases. There are a few factors at play that cause this, including the change to elevator displacement, effect of the trim tab, dynamic pressure change, etc. This means that holding the aircraft 10 kts from its trimmed speed requires less stick force at a high trimmed speed than if it were trimmed at low speed. Therefore, holding a 5 kt difference from 70 kts would required a greater force than holding a 5 kt difference from 100 kt. Stick position stability exists when the aircraft responds "correctly" to a push or pull. For example, pushing the stick causes a pitch down and an airspeed increase (this is binary, an aircraft either has stick position stability or it doesn't). Stick force stability is a further continuation of that, and in an aircraft that has positive stick force stability, a greater push force produces a greater increase in airspeed (it is a bit more nuanced than this, but this is all we need to know here). The level of stick force stability is proportional to the slope of the curve of stick force vs. speed (annex above). The steeper the curve, the higher the stick force stability (i.e. a 1 kt change to airspeed requires more force).

content.question: Aircraft certified under CS-23 and CS25 have to be able to show that they can avoid upset situations and unusual attitudes, as well as withstand and recover from them. Consider two identical aeroplanes, one with its CG at the FWD limit, the other with its CG at the AFT limit; which of the following statements is true regarding stability and manoeuvrability?

options.A: Stability increases as the CG moves aft.
options.B: Stability and manoeuvrability are not affected by CG position.
options.C: Stability decreases as the CG moves forward.
options.D: Manoeuvrability reduces slightly with a FWD CG compared to an AFT CG.

key_points: Stability of an aeroplane is its tendency to return to an original point after a disruption
Manoeuvrability is the exact opposite, it is how easy it is to change an aircraft's attitude or direction
With high stability comes low manoeuvrability (think large jet aircraft) and with low stability comes high manoeuvrability (fighter jets or aerobatic display aircraft)
learning.explanation: Stability of an aeroplane is its tendency to return to an original point after a disruption. Manoeuvrability is the exact opposite, it is how easy it is to change an aircraft's attitude or direction. With high stability comes low manoeuvrability (think large jet aircraft) and with low stability comes high manoeuvrability (fighter jets or aerobatic display aircraft). The movement (forward/aft) of the CG is incredibly important to longitudinal stability (stability in pitch movements), as having a forward CG means that the CG is further in front of the neutral point. This means greater stability, and therefore lower manoeuvrability. The neutral point is the place on an aeroplane that the CG must be in front of to make the aircraft stable in a particular axis. Its location is decided by the aerodynamic surfaces and qualities of the aircraft only. The distance between the neutral point and the CG is called the static margin. The larger the static margin, the greater the stability, (and lower the manoeuvrability). Therefore, now we know that manoeuvrability is higher with an AFT CG, and lower with a FWD CG, there is only one correct answer left.

content.question:
Which of these statements are correct or incorrect regarding a sideslip, with the relative airflow coming from the right, on an aeroplane that exhibits both directional and lateral stability?
I. The initial tendency of the nose of the aeroplane is to move to the right.
II. The initial tendency of the right wing is to move down.

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is correct.

key_points: Sideslip is the displacement angle of the airplane’s longitudinal axis in azimuth from the relative airflow
It is positive when the relative airflow is to the right of the longitudinal axis and negative when the relative airflow is left of the longitudinal axis
An airplane has directional static stability if, when in a sideslip with the airflow coming from the right initially the nose tends to yaw right
learning.explanation: Sideslip is the displacement angle of the airplane’s longitudinal axis in azimuth from the relative airflow. It is positive when the relative airflow is to the right of the longitudinal axis and negative when the relative airflow is left of the longitudinal axis. An airplane has directional static stability if, when in a sideslip with the airflow coming from the right initially the nose tends to yaw right. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane. Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left. Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip. Therefore, statement 2 is incorrect.

content.question: Aeroplanes are designed to be statically stable...

options.A: to increase fuel efficiency and decrease total fuel consumption.
options.B: to ensure that less control deflections are required to change the state of the aeroplane.
options.C: to make it easier to return to steady flight after being disturbed by an external force.
options.D: as this positively affects the controllability of the aeroplane.

key_points: This question is unnecessarily long and wordy, but does give some hints which help to remove incorrect options quickly
Static stability pertains to how a system reacts immediately when disturbed
In a statically stable system, it initially moves back toward its equilibrium state
learning.explanation: This question is unnecessarily long and wordy, but does give some hints which help to remove incorrect options quickly. Static stability pertains to how a system reacts immediately when disturbed. In a statically stable system, it initially moves back toward its equilibrium state. An aircraft's type of static stability is defined by its initial reaction after some external force is removed. We use the term "static" because we're only concerned with the initial tendency to return to equilibrium, without considering subsequent motion. Manoeuvrability/controllability, on the other hand, are similar terms (not quite the same), and are the aircraft's ability to change its position or attitude in response to pilot inputs, allowing it to perform various manoeuvres. The more stable an aircraft is, the less controllable, and vice versa. The only option that makes any sense is "to make it easier to return to steady flight after being disturbed by an external force" as the other options either describe low stability or fuel efficiency, which is not related.

content.question: What combined lateral/directional phenomenon can be caused by a yaw disturbance in the transonic speed range?

options.A: Spiral divergence
options.B: Long period oscillation
options.C: Phugoid
options.D: Dutch roll

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.04.06.03.03: Describe how the asymmetric nature of shock waves on both wings, at high Mach numbers, can lead to Dutch roll. Dutch Roll Dutch roll is a coupled lateral and directional oscillation which is undesirable because of the oscillatory nature. Dutch roll can occur when the static lateral stability (caused by dihedral, etc.) is high in comparison to the static directional stability (caused by the tail fin, etc.) Asymmetric shockwaves Modern transport jet aircraft tend to cruise at high altitudes with high Mach numbers, very close to - or just inside - the transonic regime. This is the range of speeds (At and above MCRIT) where some of the aircraft experiences supersonic airflow, but not all the aircraft does. This brings rise to shockwaves, first on the upper wing surfaces near the roots, then spreading to other areas of the aircraft. Shockwaves produce quite high drag forces, classed as "wave drag". If the shockwaves form asymmetrically on the aircraft, whether due to different airflow patterns over the wings, small differences in the aircraft structure, control surfaces, etc., then the different drag forces can cause a yawing motion, which sets off the oscillation known as Dutch roll. This Dutch roll would be made worse by the shockwaves forming on the faster wing, reducing lift and increasing drag to drop it down and drag it back, exacerbating the Dutch roll.

content.question: Which of the following options best defines the oscillatory nature of a spiral dive and the direction of both yaw and roll?

options.A: The spiral dive is oscillatory, and yaw and roll act in the same direction.
options.B: The spiral dive is oscillatory, and yaw and roll act in opposite directions.
options.C: The spiral dive is non-oscillatory, and yaw and roll act in the same direction.
options.D: The spiral dive is non-oscillatory, and yaw and roll act in opposite directions.

key_points: Spiral divergence will exist when static directional stability is very large when compared to the dihedral effect
The character of spiral divergence is not violent
The aeroplane, when disturbed from the equilibrium of level flight, begins a slow spiral which gradually increases to a spiral dive
learning.explanation: Spiral divergence will exist when static directional stability is very large when compared to the dihedral effect. The character of spiral divergence is not violent. The aeroplane, when disturbed from the equilibrium of level flight, begins a slow spiral which gradually increases to a spiral dive. When a small sideslip is introduced, the strong directional stability tends to restore the nose into the wind while the relatively weak dihedral effect lags in restoring the aeroplane laterally. The rate of divergence in the spiral motion is usually so gradual that the pilot can control the tendency without difficulty. It is therefore considered non-oscillatory and both yaw and roll moments will occur to the same side.

content.question: Which of the following aircraft design characteristics is desirable during a flight with a long time spent in straight and level flight and only gentle manoeuvring?

options.A: An aeroplane with neutral stability to reduce the workload of the pilot, since flying requires lower control forces.
options.B: An aeroplane with neutral stability, because it will tend to move less in turbulence since it will remain in its new attitude.
options.C: A statically stable aeroplane where the aeroplane shows a natural tendency to return to its pre-disturbed position.
options.D: A statically unstable aeroplane to reduce the workload of the pilot with lower control forces to maintain an attitude.

key_points: An aircraft is in a state of equilibrium (trim) when the sum of all forces is zero and the sum of all moments is zero; there are no accelerations and the aircraft will continue in steady flight
If equilibrium is disturbed by a gust, or deflection of the controls, the aircraft will experience accelerations due to an unbalance of moments or forces
The type of static stability an aircraft possesses is defined by its initial tendency, following the removal of some disturbing force
learning.explanation: An aircraft is in a state of equilibrium (trim) when the sum of all forces is zero and the sum of all moments is zero; there are no accelerations and the aircraft will continue in steady flight. If equilibrium is disturbed by a gust, or deflection of the controls, the aircraft will experience accelerations due to an unbalance of moments or forces. The type of static stability an aircraft possesses is defined by its initial tendency, following the removal of some disturbing force. Positive static stability (or static stability) exists if an aircraft is disturbed from equilibrium and has the tendency to return to equilibrium. Neutral static stability exists if an aircraft is subject to a disturbance and has neither the tendency to return nor the tendency to continue in the displacement direction. Negative static stability (or static instability) exists if an aircraft tends to continue in the direction of disturbance.

content.question:
Which design features reduce static lateral stability?
1. High wing.
2. Low wing.
3. Large and high vertical fin.
4. Ventral fin.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

key_points: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane
Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left
Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip
learning.explanation: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane. Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left. Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip. A disturbance in the rolling plane causes the angle of attack of the upgoing wing to decrease and the angle of attack of the down going wing to increase. Provided the airplane is not flying close to the stalling speed, then the upgoing wing produces less lift than it did before the disturbance and the down going wing will produce more lift than it did. Together, these changes result in a rolling moment in opposition to the initial disturbance and have a ‘roll-damping’ effect. When the roll damping exactly matches the aileron torque the airplane has a steady rate of roll. content.question:
Fill in the blanks with the most suitable choice:
If the distance between Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) becomes (1) _____, a greater balancing force from the stabiliser will be needed, and that force will act (2) _____.
Assuming lift does not change, and CG is forward of CP.

options.A: (1) greater; (2) downward
options.B: (1) less; (2) downward
options.C: (1) less; (2) upward

key_points: Centre of Pressure (CP) is considered as the point at which lift acts through, while Centre of Gravity (CG) is the point where weight of aircraft acts through
Refer to the situation 1 in diagram: The moments have to be balanced for straight and level flight
Since the CG is forward of CP, lift (L) is producing an anticlockwise moment around the CG
learning.explanation: Centre of Pressure (CP) is considered as the point at which lift acts through, while Centre of Gravity (CG) is the point where weight of aircraft acts through. Refer to the situation 1 in diagram: The moments have to be balanced for straight and level flight. Since the CG is forward of CP, lift (L) is producing an anticlockwise moment around the CG. To balance this anticlockwise moment from lift, we need a clockwise moment from the force of the stabiliser (F). To procedure a clockwise moment from the stabiliser, a downward force will be needed. If we take moment at the point of CG, we can establish the formula Lx=F(x+y). With rearrangement we can see that F = Lx / ( x + y) Refer to situation 2 in diagram: Now if the distance between CG and CP becomes larger than before, the new formula will become Wz + Lx = F'(x+y), if we take moment at the original GC position and F’ is the new force required from the stabiliser. With rearrangement, F’ = (Wz + Lx) / (x + y). If we compare F and F’, we can see that they share the same denominator while F’ has a larger numerator (Wz + Lx > Lx), with all parameters positive real numbers). Therefore, F’ is larger than F, which means as the distance between CG and CP becomes greater, the downward balancing force of the stabiliser becomes greater as well. (In this case) Another way to visualise the situation is to plug in some convenient numbers. If lift, distance x and y are all 1, F will be 1/(1+1) = 0.5 originally (taking moment at the CG). Now, let’s say the x is increased to 2, with other parameters unchanged. Taking moment at the new CG, F’ will be 2/(2+1) = 0.67, which is larger than 0.5 previously. Notes for further learning: This question assumes lift does not change when the distance between CG and CP increases. As the force from stabiliser becomes greater, the weight will have to be reduced in order to balance the upward and downward forces in this case.

learning.explanation: The CM (pitching moment) vs alpha (Angle of Attack) graph is a graph depicting the longitudinal stability of an aircraft. As a very short explanation, the point where the line crosses the X-axis (Angle of Attack) is the trim position, where no pitching moment exists. As long as the gradient of the graph is negative, whenever the aircraft has a nose-up disturbance, the AoA will decrease to correct for this, and vice versa. That means that a negative gradient gives positive static longitudinal stability. The more negative the gradient of the line is, the stronger the stability. The line is not usually straight, it changes gradient due to the aircraft's design and window of stability. The CM vs alpha graph is affected by various things in the aircraft's design, including the locations of the wings and the shape of aerofoils, size of wings, etc. The CG location also massively affects the CM vs alpha graph, of course. The question is terribly worded, but really we only have to be able to say which factors a pilot can change in flight, and make sure that they actually do affect stability, and the CM vs alpha graph. Whilst the question is terrible, the answer isn't too bad. "The centre of pressure, by changing the flap setting." Yes, the centre of pressure is one of the key factors determining the CM and it can be changed by changing flap setting, which is something we can do in the air. This would likely change the CM vs alpha graph completely. "The neutral point, by varying alpha." The neutral point is a set location in the aircraft, determined by things such as the wing sizes and moment arms, and cannot be changed in flight. "The centre of pressure, by varying alpha." Yes, again, the centre of pressure does affect the CM, and changing the angle of attack changes the CM and the gradient, strength of stability, etc., and is something that we can do in flight, of course. "The centre of gravity, which influences the degree of pitching moment." This is where the question gets a bit more difficult. We are assuming that the pilot cannot change the CG during flight, but of course, some aircraft have trim tanks for that possibility, and we know that fuel burn does alter the CG, but not in a way the pilot can meaningfully control. The second part, the "degree of pitching moment" is also incredibly vague, and given the vague question, we agree that this option is incorrect.

Now, let's differentiate between two essential concepts: Controllability: This refers to the pilot's ability to control the aircraft using inputs. These regulations mandate that an airplane must exhibit static stability and meet specific criteria for controllability and manoeuvrability. In general, an aircraft with static stability is easier to control, and its movements are more predictable. The connection between manoeuvrability and stability is such that as an aircraft's static stability increases, an aircraft equipped with a particular size of control surfaces may experience a slight reduction in manoeuvrability. This is because static stability characterizes the aircraft's capacity to reestablish its initial position following a disturbance. In essence, a statically stable aircraft tends to oppose alterations in its attitude, which can introduce increased challenges when manoeuvring, especially in specific situations.

learning.explanation: Dutch roll is a coupled lateral and directional oscillation which is objectionable because of the oscillatory nature. Dutch roll will occur when the dihedral effect is large when compared to static directional stability. Assymetric Nature of Shockwaves Generally, flight at high altitude will be flown at high Mach numbers by aircraft with sweepback wings. Drag increase encountered at these higher speeds is called wave drag. At and above MCRIT, the drag of the airplane wing increases rapidly and there is a large reduction of lift. If the shockwave develops earlier on wing than the other (assymetrically), the wing drops and tends to yaw creating the conditions for a coupled lateral and directional oscillation or Dutch roll. With increasing altitude (decreasing density) or increasing Mach number, the possibility of a Dutch roll increases. This means that the correct course of action following a Dutch roll is to reduce the Mach number and to descend.

key_points: Learning Objectives reference 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives reference 081.04.06.03.03: Describe how the asymmetric nature of shock waves on both wings, at high Mach numbers, can lead to Dutch roll. Dutch roll is an oscillatory instability associated with swept-wing jet aircraft. It is the combination of yawing and rolling motions. When the aircraft yaws, it will develop into a roll. The yaw itself is not too significant, but the roll is much more noticeable and unstable. This is so because the aircraft suffers from a continuous reversing rolling action. Dutch roll occurs when static lateral stability is strong and static directional stability is relatively weak. Yaw dampers prevent Dutch roll on swept-wing aircraft. Dutch roll is most common at high speed and high altitude. At high altitude and high Mach number, aerodynamic damping decreases. Decreasing both altitude and Mach number should increase damping and stop the oscillation.

key_points: The most direct appreciation of the manoeuvring stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor
The airplane with positive manoeuvring stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”

The manoeuvring stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive (so that pulling back equals increased G-force) but should also be of the proper magnitude, so we can't easily rip the wings off with a small input, or inversely, need to input huge forces for normal manoeuvres
learning.explanation: The most direct appreciation of the manoeuvring stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor. The airplane with positive manoeuvring stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”. The manoeuvring stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive (so that pulling back equals increased G-force) but should also be of the proper magnitude, so we can't easily rip the wings off with a small input, or inversely, need to input huge forces for normal manoeuvres. This means that the stick force per g must have upper and lower limits to ensure that the airplane always has acceptable control characteristics. Stick force per G is affected by factors such as the aircraft CG, airspeed, altitude. When the pilots make an input on the controls, lets say the elevators for example, this puts a pitch moment on the aircraft, which the aircraft's natural stability fights against, this is a part of what's called "aerodynamic damping". At high altitudes, the high TAS reduces the change in tail angle of attack for a given pitching velocity and reduces the aerodynamic pitch damping. Thus, the aircraft becomes more manoeuvrable and less stable. This means that the stick force per G decreases (a 1G increase in load factor is easier to pull through the control column). It is also worth noting for real life flying that this makes hand-flying much more difficult at high altitudes, as very small movements are required but still produce large changes to attitude.

When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state
The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations
learning.explanation: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor. When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state. The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations. One is a short-period oscillation and the other is a long-period oscillation called a phugoid. The phugoid is usually poorly damped; it has large variations of speed and height and has an almost uniform load factor (n). It has a constant energy motion in which the potential energy and the kinetic energy are continuously interchanging. The motion that causes short-period oscillation is normally heavily damped. It not only involves small changes of speed and height but also large changes of load factor. The speed and height of the airplane remain approximately constant.

options.B: There is NO change to the feel since the increased stick force per g, caused by the lighter mass, is offset by the forward CG.
options.C: The stick force per g is reduced since the aeroplane is lighter, but the forward CG makes this reduction less noticeable to the pilot.
options.D: The stick force per g is increased since the lighter aeroplane and forward CG both reduce the manoeuvrability of the aeroplane.

key_points: Important Note: This question ventures outside of the learning objectives and therefore should be appealed if seen in the exam
We have had various different pieces of feedback come through for this question and similar questions, and they don't really make sense
We do not know whether this question is currently being asked, and we very much hope that it has been removed
learning.explanation: Important Note: This question ventures outside of the learning objectives and therefore should be appealed if seen in the exam. We have had various different pieces of feedback come through for this question and similar questions, and they don't really make sense. We do not know whether this question is currently being asked, and we very much hope that it has been removed. Please send us any further questions or exam feedback in the comments, or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! The feel of an aeroplane is how much force is required to make a particular manoeuvre, often referred to in the units of "stick force per G" for longitudinal stability (pitch changes). Stability and manoeuvrability are intrinsically linked, in that the more manoeuvrable an aircraft is, the less stable it is, and vice-versa. Stick force per G simply measures how much force the pilot needs to exert on the controls to cause a 1G change in load factor, the higher this value, the more stable (less controllable) an aircraft is. The movement (forward/aft) of the CG is incredibly important to longitudinal stability, as having a forward CG means that the CG is further in front of the neutral point. This means greater stability, and therefore lower manoeuvrability. A change in mass (without a change in CG) is much more complicated. It appears that mass change has an effect on the manoeuvrability that cannot be simply stated for the average aircraft, as mass and wing loading (a function of mass) appear to have opposing effects, but with different values, and the effect of different speeds for higher masses is not accounted for anywhere in the question. As you can probably tell, this is already much too complex for the ATPL exams. This is likely why the effect of mass on manoeuvring stability/stick force per G is not on the learning objectives. It is intuitive to think that a lighter aircraft is more manoeuvrable, but that is not something that can be absolutely stated without further information, and not even something the learning objectives mention. We think that the examiner has written a question to test knowledge of CG movements, assuming that their intuition on the change in weight is correct, but has ended up making a question much more complicated, which ventures outside the learning objectives. Therefore, our new recommendation here would be to answer the question assuming that the weight reduction decreases the stick force per G, even though that is not an absolute statement. This leaves us with the answer "The stick force per g is reduced since the aeroplane is lighter, but the forward CG makes this reduction less noticeable to the pilot."

key_points: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane
Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left
Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip
learning.explanation: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane. Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left. Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip. A disturbance in the rolling plane causes the angle of attack of the upgoing wing to decrease and the angle of attack of the down going wing to increase. Provided the airplane is not flying close to the stalling speed, then the upgoing wing produces less lift than it did before the disturbance and the down going wing will produce more lift than it did. Together, these changes result in a rolling moment in opposition to the initial disturbance and have a ‘roll-damping’ effect. When the roll damping exactly matches the aileron torque the airplane has a steady rate of roll. The airplane design features that increase the lateral static stability are: dihedral. sweepback. high-wing mounting. increased effective dihedral. large, high vertical fin. low CG. The airplane design features that decrease the lateral static stability are: anhedral. forward-swept wings. ventral fin. low-wing mounting. extending inboard flaps.

options.D: They will all remain constant.

key_points: The feedback for this question is not confirmed and there is another recently added question which asks a similar question in the opposite manner (Q811560 - originally seen in Latvia), so we could really use some further feedback to help make sure this question is representative of the real exam, thank you very much
This is quite a tricky question as the examiner is trying to get you confused about which stability they are discussing
The spiral dive occurs as a link between strong directional (yaw) stability but weak lateral (roll) stability
learning.explanation: The feedback for this question is not confirmed and there is another recently added question which asks a similar question in the opposite manner (Q811560 - originally seen in Latvia), so we could really use some further feedback to help make sure this question is representative of the real exam, thank you very much. This is quite a tricky question as the examiner is trying to get you confused about which stability they are discussing. The spiral dive occurs as a link between strong directional (yaw) stability but weak lateral (roll) stability. Imagine an aircraft is disturbed to roll slightly right, and therefore takes up a slight right sideslip. The large fin yaws into the turn before the aircraft can roll out of it, and this yaw causes a further bank, which again causes more yaw before the aircraft can roll out of it. During this process, the nose keeps dropping to increase airspeed to maintain lift in the turn without any increase in angle of attack. In IMC without good use of instruments, this feels like straight and level flight until the G forces start to increase noticeably, at which point the pilot would finally notice that something was wrong, as they are in a high speed spiral dive. But now back to the theory. Many aircraft have a slight spiral instability, which, even though the aircraft might be statically stable in all axes, means that a small departure from straight and level will gradually become a spiral dive if no pilot inputs are made. As this is a gradual process, it is acceptable up to a certain rate of instability as the pilot can easily override it. Being stable in the spiral mode means that the aircraft naturally tends to reduce any spiral dives to zero. If an aircraft is stable in the spiral mode, then it is likely to have a strong tendency for dutch roll. For this question, though, if the aircraft is stable in the spiral mode, then the aircraft will start to roll more wings level, decreasing the rate of turn when they release the controls, decreasing the airspeed and starting to loosen the spiral, so all these parameters decrease.

content.question: When is the airplane longitudinal stable?

options.A: When the CG is behind the CP/Neutral point
options.B: When the CG is at the CP/Neutral point
options.C: When the CG is in front of the CP/Neutral point
options.D: It is independent of the CG location

key_points: A variation of CG position can cause large changes in the static longitudinal stability
In the conventional airplane configuration, the large changes in stability with CG variation are primarily due to the large changes in the wing contribution
As the CG is gradually moved aft, the airplane static stability decreases, then becomes neutral then unstable
learning.explanation: A variation of CG position can cause large changes in the static longitudinal stability. In the conventional airplane configuration, the large changes in stability with CG variation are primarily due to the large changes in the wing contribution. As the CG is gradually moved aft, the airplane static stability decreases, then becomes neutral then unstable. The CG position which produces zero slope and neutral static stability is referred to as the “neutral point”. For an airplane to always have positive longitudinal static stability the CG must be ahead of the neutral point, so that the wing-pitching moment always exceeds the tail plane pitching moment. The further aft the neutral point is from the CG the greater is the static longitudinal stability.

content.question: A pilot is teaching a student the effects of individual control inputs. First, the pilot deflects the ailerons only, holding a constant deflection. Eventually, the aircraft enters a spiral dive. After recovering, the pilot then inputs a constant rudder deflection only. This also causes a spiral dive. Which of the following statements is correct regarding aircraft stability?

options.A: The ailerons are the main contributors to lateral stability and the rudder is the main contributor to directional stability.
options.B: The ailerons are secondary contributors to directional stability and the rudder is a secondary contributor to lateral stability.
options.C: Lateral and directional stabilities interact through sideslip, which is created when using either aileron or rudder alone.
options.D: Since the aeroplane enters an un-coordinated spiral dive, it is a result of both the lateral and directional stabilities being too weak.

key_points: This is a very complex question, but the answer is the simplest one present
The examiner has put in a lot to try and confuse you
The answer to the question is right at the top, but keep reading if you want to know more and if you want to know why the other answers are incorrect
learning.explanation: This is a very complex question, but the answer is the simplest one present. The examiner has put in a lot to try and confuse you. The answer to the question is right at the top, but keep reading if you want to know more and if you want to know why the other answers are incorrect. Directional stability (stability in yaw) and lateral stability (stability in roll) are very well linked. The linkage between the two is via sideslip, the condition where the aircraft is not pointing in the same direction it is travelling through the air, so the relative airflow is arriving from one side of the nose, rather than straight on the nose. We can cause this by not flying the aircraft properly, and by flying uncoordinated, so using the ailerons without also using correct rudder, and vice-versa. LATERAL/DIRECTIONAL STABILITY Imagine that we have a left sideslip, so the aircraft is pointing forwards, but travelling to the left of that, and the relative airflow is hitting the left windshield first. A directionally stable aircraft will naturally yaw into this (nose left moment), because of the positively stable effect of the fin (vertical stabiliser), any rear strakes or ventral fin, the differential drag of the wings, etc. A laterally stable aircraft will roll away from this sideslip (right bank moment), due to the dihedral effect, sweepback, high wing effect, etc. Both of these movements decreases the sideslip, just in different ways; the aircraft can either yaw into it, or roll away from it. Most civilian aircraft are both laterally and directionally stable at once, in equal measure. If the stability becomes too high on one or the other, then it can cause either Dutch Roll or Spiral Instability. DUTCH ROLL Too much lateral stability and not enough directional stability can cause a periodic motion of sideslip and overcorrection which we call Dutch Roll. Imagine an aircraft with very long, dihedral wings, but a small tail fin. SPIRAL INSTABILITY The opposite of Dutch Roll, Spiral Instability is where we have too much directional stability but not enough lateral stability, which causes an increasing bank angle, with the aircraft constantly yawing further to keep the turn coordinated and ending up in a spiral dive. It is an aperiodic motion (it only happens once, not back and forth). Imagine a large tail fin and short, non-dihedral wings. So in terms of this question, we have already seen the correct answer, "Lateral and directional stabilities interact through sideslip, which is created when using either aileron or rudder alone.". Whilst there are other ways to create sideslip, this is a very common one. For two other options, we should mention that the rudder and ailerons are not contributors to stability. They are control surfaces, and the pilot has direct control over them. Stability has to be natural within the aircraft. If it takes a pilot to remove the sideslip, then the aircraft is not that stable. In a stable aircraft, we manipulate the ailerons and rudder against the natural stability of the aircraft design. For the final option remaining, most aircraft would enter a spiral dive under the conditions mentioned in the question (depending on the extent of the deflection). However, with stronger lateral stability, the aircraft would be able to resist the spiral dive. Extra directional stability would just make a spiral dive easier to enter. So you could say that lateral stability is too weak, but not both lateral and directional stabilities.

options.C: Phugiod

key_points: Dutch roll is the undulating motion of an aeroplane in the directional and lateral planes, following a lateral disturbance to the equilibrium of the aeroplane

Dutch roll occurs when the directional stability of an aeroplane is weak and the lateral stability is strong, which may be exacerbated by an aft CG position because of the shortened corrective moment arm

If an aeroplane is disturbed laterally the combined rolling motion and yawing motion, either of which may be extreme, can cause oscillatory instability, which is much more serious than spiral instability
learning.explanation: Dutch roll is the undulating motion of an aeroplane in the directional and lateral planes, following a lateral disturbance to the equilibrium of the aeroplane. Dutch roll occurs when the directional stability of an aeroplane is weak and the lateral stability is strong, which may be exacerbated by an aft CG position because of the shortened corrective moment arm. If an aeroplane is disturbed laterally the combined rolling motion and yawing motion, either of which may be extreme, can cause oscillatory instability, which is much more serious than spiral instability. Modern jet transport aeroplanes are fitted with yaw dampers to relieve the pilot of the need to manually control Dutch roll.

content.question:
Sweepback of a wing positively influences:
1. static longitudinal stability.
2. static lateral stability.
3. dynamic longitudinal stability.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

key_points: Sweep Angle: The angle between the line of 25% chords and a perpendicular to the root chord
Purpose of Sweepback: To increase MCRIT
Sweepback factsheet: A Swept Wing Increases the Critical Mach Number (MCRIT)
learning.explanation: Sweep Angle: The angle between the line of 25% chords and a perpendicular to the root chord. Purpose of Sweepback: To increase MCRIT. Sweepback factsheet: A Swept Wing Increases the Critical Mach Number (MCRIT). All other effects from a swept wing are by-products, most of them disadvantages. However, the benefits from a higher MCRIT outweigh the associated disadvantages. Increased tendency to stall at the tip first: Tip stall can lead to pitch-up, a major disadvantage. Pitch-up can give the tendency for a swept wing aircraft to Super Stall. Aircraft that show a significant tendency to pitch-up at the stall must be fitted with a stall prevention device, a stick pusher. When compared to a straight wing of the same section, a swept wing is less aerodynamically efficient. At a given angle of attack CL is less, which increases the stall speed. CLMAX is less and occurs at a higher angle of attack. The lift curve has a smaller gradient (change in CL per degree change in alpha is less). Swept wings must be fitted with complex high lift devices, both leading and trailing edge, to give a reasonable take-off and landing distance. A swept wing must be flown at a higher angle of attack than a straight wing to give the required lift coefficient; this is most noticeable at low speeds. A swept wing makes a small positive contribution to static directional stability. A swept wing makes a significant positive contribution to static lateral stability. At speeds higher than MCRIT a swept wing generates a nose-down pitching moment, a phenomenon known as Tuck Under. The hinge line of trailing edge ‘flap’ type control surfaces is not at right angles to the airflow, which reduces the efficiency of the controls.

key_points: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor
The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”
The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude
learning.explanation: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor. The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”. The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude. The stick force gradient must not be excessively high, or the airplane will be difficult and tiring to maneuver. Also, the stick force gradient must not be too low, or the airplane may be overstressed inadvertently when light control forces exist. When the airplane has high static stability, the maneuvering stability will be high, and a high stick force gradient will result. A possibility exists that the forward CG limit could be set to prevent an excessively high maneuvering stick force gradient. As the CG moves forward, the stick force gradient increases with increasing maneuvering stability and the higher limit of stick force gradient may be reached.

key_points: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP)

As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure
learning.explanation: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP). This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating. As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure. Aircraft longitudinal stability is directly related to Centre of Gravity (CG) position. An aircraft with a more forward CG is more longitudinally stable than an aircraft with a more aft CG. Placing the CG beyond the forward limit can cause an unacceptably high value of longitudinal stability, decreasing manoeuvrability by a significant amount. Place the CG beyond the aft limit and the aircraft is too unstable, having excessive manoeuvrability. If an aircraft is longitudinally stable, an increase in Angle of Attack (α) results in a negative pitching moment. The nose will slightly fall down, decreasing the Angle of Attack. If this aircraft has a decrease of Angle of Attack, the nose will come slightly upwards again, creating a positive pitching moment again by slightly raising the nose. For this specific question, we can see that line 1 is the most longitudinally unstable aircraft and line 4 is the most longitudinally stable aircraft. With this information we can derive that the CG position is further aft at line 1 compared to line 4.

content.question: With a nose heavy aircraft (CG moves forward), the negative force produced by the horizontal stabiliser...

options.A: increases.
options.B: decreases.
options.C: remain the same.
options.D: the tailplane never produces a negative force.

key_points: Longitudinal stability is motion about the lateral axis

Static Longitudinal stability is the aircraft's natural tendency when disturbed in pitch, to return to its former trimmed angle of attack without pilot input, and is desirable throughout the aircraft's complete speed range
For the study of stability, we consider the changes in magnitude of lift force due to changes in angle of attack, acting through a stationary point, the aerodynamic centre (AC)
learning.explanation: Longitudinal stability is motion about the lateral axis. Static Longitudinal stability is the aircraft's natural tendency when disturbed in pitch, to return to its former trimmed angle of attack without pilot input, and is desirable throughout the aircraft's complete speed range. For the study of stability, we consider the changes in magnitude of lift force due to changes in angle of attack, acting through a stationary point, the aerodynamic centre (AC). There are two moments to consider: the wing moment and the tail moment: - The wing moment is a function of the change in wing lift multiplied by an arm (distance from wing CP to CG). - The tail moment is a function of the change in tailplane lift multiplied by arm (distance from tailplane CP to CG). The length of both arms is dependent upon CG position. If the CG is considered in a more forward position, the tail arm is larger and the wing arm is smaller. A more forward CG position increases static longitudinal stability. The position of the CG directly affects the magnitude of the longitudinal static stability, the tailplane downforce and the stalling speed because its position determines the length of the arm of any restoring moment. A forward movement of the CG increases the positive longitudinal static stability of an aircraft but decreases the manoeuvrability and control response because the moment arm is increased in length and increases the nose-down pitching moment. Thus, the required downforce on the tailplane increases.

content.question: In aircraft aerodynamics, what is the "static margin"?

options.A: The ratio of the tailplane’s lift coefficient to the wing’s lift coefficient.
options.B: The percentage of the mean aerodynamic chord (MAC) from the leading edge to the centre of gravity.
options.C: The distance between the centre of gravity (CG) and the neutral point.
options.D: The difference in angle between the aircraft’s longitudinal axis and the relative airflow.

key_points: STABILITY Stability of an aeroplane is its tendency to return to an original point after a disruption
Manoeuvrability is the exact opposite, it is how easy it is to change an aircraft's attitude or direction
With high stability comes low manoeuvrability (think large jet aircraft) and with low stability comes high manoeuvrability (fighter jets or aerobatic display aircraft)
learning.explanation: STABILITY Stability of an aeroplane is its tendency to return to an original point after a disruption. Manoeuvrability is the exact opposite, it is how easy it is to change an aircraft's attitude or direction. With high stability comes low manoeuvrability (think large jet aircraft) and with low stability comes high manoeuvrability (fighter jets or aerobatic display aircraft). The placement (forward/aft) of the CG is incredibly important to longitudinal stability (stability in pitch movements), as having a forward CG means that the effect of any movement affects the tailplane more than the main wing and the rest of the aircraft, and it has a greater stabilising effect (like the fins on a dart). The "neutral point" is the where the CG would be for the aircraft to have NEUTRAL static stability (in pitch). If the CG is in front of the neutral point, the aircraft is statically stable in pitch. The further forwards the CG goes, the more stable the aircraft gets. The location of the neutral point is decided by the aerodynamic surfaces and qualities of the aircraft only. The distance between the neutral point and the CG is called the static margin. The larger the static margin (forwards of the neutral point), the greater the stability, (and lower the manoeuvrability). As for the other options: "The ratio of the tailplane’s lift coefficient to the wing’s lift coefficient." Incorrect as these do not include the location of the CG. "The percentage of the mean aerodynamic chord (MAC) from the leading edge to the centre of gravity." Incorrect. This is describing the CG location as a percentage of the MAC. "The distance between the centre of gravity (CG) and the neutral point." Correct. "The difference in angle between the aircraft’s longitudinal axis and the relative airflow." This is close to the angle of attack, but not exactly. Certainly not the static margin.

content.question: A transport aircraft must display adequate stability in each of the three axes to comply with CS 25 standards. What is the main reason behind this requirement?

options.C: To reduce fuel consumption.

key_points: CS 25
171 General The aeroplane must be longitudinally, directionally and laterally stable in accordance with the provisions of CS 25
learning.explanation: CS 25.171 General The aeroplane must be longitudinally, directionally and laterally stable in accordance with the provisions of CS 25.173 to 25.177. In addition, suitable stability and control feel (static stability) is required in any condition normally encountered in service, if flight tests show it is necessary for safe operation. Stability is the tendency of an aircraft to return to a steady state of flight (equilibrium) without any help from the pilot, after being disturbed by an external force. An aircraft must have the following qualities: Adequate stability to maintain a uniform flight condition The ability to recover from various disturbing influences Sufficient stability to minimize the workload of the pilot Proper response to the controls so that it may achieve its design performance with adequate manoeuvrability

content.question: Which of the following flight phenomena can occur at Mach numbers below the critical Mach number?

options.A: Dutch roll.
options.B: Tuck under.
options.C: Shock stall.
options.D: Mach buffet.

key_points: Critical Mach Number: (MCRIT) The critical Mach number is the Mach number of the aircraft when the speed of the airflow over some part of the aircraft first reaches the speed of sound
At high altitude, a large high-speed jet transport aircraft will be cruising at a speed marginally above its critical Mach number, and it will have a small shock wave on the wing
If such an aircraft overspeeds, the shock wave will rapidly grow larger, causing the static pressure to increase sharply in the immediate vicinity of the shock wave
learning.explanation: Critical Mach Number: (MCRIT) The critical Mach number is the Mach number of the aircraft when the speed of the airflow over some part of the aircraft first reaches the speed of sound. At high altitude, a large high-speed jet transport aircraft will be cruising at a speed marginally above its critical Mach number, and it will have a small shock wave on the wing. If such an aircraft overspeeds, the shock wave will rapidly grow larger, causing the static pressure to increase sharply in the immediate vicinity of the shock wave. The locally increased adverse pressure gradient will cause the boundary layer to separate immediately behind the shock wave. This is called a ‘shock stall’. Shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. As the shock wave moves aft over the surface of the wing, the CP also moves aft. This aft movement combined with the reduced downwash at the tail plane due to the presence of the shockwave will lead to Tuck Under. As we can see, from all the options, shock stall, mach buffet and tuck under only occur when operating above MCRIT (transonic speed regime). Dutch roll occurs when the static lateral stability (caused by dihedral, etc.) is high in comparison to the static directional stability (caused by the tail fin, etc.) and may occur at Mach numbers below the critical Mach number.

Pilot-induced oscillations are where the pilot "over-controls" the aircraft, and therefore, will not only correct for an incorrect attitude, altitude, speed, etc., but will over-correct, and go through the equilibrium, ending up in the opposite scenario. This can often be seen on a pilot's first few ILS approaches when they begin to get very accurate near the runway, or during the flare, when pilots sometimes over-flare, and end up porpoising (up and down) along the runway. It is very common in many stages of flight, and something to try and avoid. Autopilots can perform self-induced oscillations too, if they are not quick enough to catch the overcontrolling with their feedback loop, for example. This could be in pitch, or in yaw and roll (which could lead to Dutch roll). This question is very vague, it does not tell us what oscillations we are feeling, nor much about how they have been formed, so we have chosen the most vague answer that is correct (it could also be Dutch roll, but we would have to make a lot more assumptions, so we think that "Dutch roll" is not as correct).

key_points: An aircraft is in a state of equilibrium (trim) when the sum of all forces is zero and the sum of all moments is zero; there are no accelerations and the aircraft will continue in steady flight
If equilibrium is disturbed by a gust, or deflection of the controls, the aircraft will experience accelerations due to an unbalance of moments or forces
The type of static stability an aircraft possesses is defined by its initial tendency, following the removal of some disturbing force
learning.explanation: An aircraft is in a state of equilibrium (trim) when the sum of all forces is zero and the sum of all moments is zero; there are no accelerations and the aircraft will continue in steady flight. If equilibrium is disturbed by a gust, or deflection of the controls, the aircraft will experience accelerations due to an unbalance of moments or forces. The type of static stability an aircraft possesses is defined by its initial tendency, following the removal of some disturbing force. Positive static stability (or static stability) exists if an aircraft is disturbed from equilibrium and has the tendency to return to equilibrium. Neutral static stability exists if an aircraft is subject to a disturbance and has neither the tendency to return nor the tendency to continue in the displacement direction. Negative static stability (or static instability) exists if an aircraft tends to continue in the direction of disturbance.

key_points: SPIRAL DIVERGENCE/INSTABILITY Spiral divergence will exist when static directional stability is very large when compared to the lateral stability
The character of spiral divergence is not violent
When a small sideslip is introduced, the strong directional stability tends to restore the nose into the wind while the relatively weak “dihedral effect” lags in restoring the aeroplane laterally
learning.explanation: SPIRAL DIVERGENCE/INSTABILITY Spiral divergence will exist when static directional stability is very large when compared to the lateral stability. The character of spiral divergence is not violent. When a small sideslip is introduced, the strong directional stability tends to restore the nose into the wind while the relatively weak “dihedral effect” lags in restoring the aeroplane laterally. The rate of divergence in the spiral motion is usually so gradual that the pilot can control the tendency without difficulty. Spiral instability is normally considered less objectionable than oscillatory instability, so most aircraft are designed to be spirally unstable. With this characteristic, when the aircraft is yawed, either by the prolonged application of rudder or asymmetric power, a rolling moment in the direction of yaw occurs and the aircraft quickly enters a spiral dive. This can occur when flying at low airspeeds under asymmetric power conditions, when excessive yaw due to too much power is coupled with insufficient rudder control to balance it, and may quickly place an aircraft in a dangerous attitude.

learning.explanation: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP). This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating. As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure. Aircraft longitudinal stability is directly related to Centre of Gravity (CG) position. An aircraft with a more forward CG is more longitudinally stable than an aircraft with a more aft CG. learning.explanation: "By increasing anhedral." Incorrect. Wing dihedral increases lateral stability, while anhedral reduces it. "By fitting a ventral fin (a fin at the under side of the aeroplane)." Incorrect. A ventral fin is placed on the underside of the aircraft’s fuselage. Any fin placed on the underside of the fuselage is called a ventral fin, it improves static directional stability and reduces lateral stability. "By applying wing twist." Incorrect. key_points: DUTCH ROLL Basically speaking, Dutch roll is a series of out-of-phase turns, when the aircraft rolls in one direction and yaws in the other
When the yaw is introduced, the strong “dihedral effect” will roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into wind
The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations
learning.explanation: DUTCH ROLL Basically speaking, Dutch roll is a series of out-of-phase turns, when the aircraft rolls in one direction and yaws in the other. When the yaw is introduced, the strong “dihedral effect” will roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into wind. The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations. This might occur when the lateral stability is large compared to the directional stability. To reduce the aircraft tendency to Dutch roll, either the lateral stability should be decreased or the directional stability increased => anhedral would decrease the lateral stability.

learning.explanation: The longitudinal static stability of an airplane is its ability to return to its original pitch attitude with no outside assistance, after the disturbance that caused a nose-up or a nose-down movement has ceased. The main factors that affect the longitudinal static stability are the design of the tail plane and the position of the CG relative to the position of the CP because they determine the direction of the additional wing-pitching moment. The tail plane and elevators act as a horizontal stabilizer and the degree of positive longitudinal static stability that they provide is dependent on the size of the restoring moment they can attain; nevertheless, they do make the largest contribution to the longitudinal static stability. The tail plane design and the length of the moment arm from the tail plane CP to the CG condition the magnitude of the restoring moment. The effect that the fuselage, and to a lesser extent wing-mounted the engine nacelles, has on the airplane’s longitudinal static stability is normally a destabilizing influence, a negative contribution. If the fuselage aerodynamic center is ahead of the wing aerodynamic center, the aerodynamic center of the wing–fuselage combination is further forward than it would normally be. If such is the case the aircraft CG will be further aft than is normal and the aircraft longitudinal static stability is decreased.

learning.explanation: Dorsal and ventral fins are used to overcome the instability in the fuselage. A dorsal fin is mounted on top of the fuselage near the rear. Whereas a ventral fin is mounted below. If the aircraft is yawed to the right, the dorsal and ventral fins will create a side force to the right. key_points: Dutch Roll Dutch roll is a coupled lateral and directional oscillation which is undesirable because of the oscillatory nature
Dutch roll can occur when the static lateral stability (caused by dihedral, etc
) is high in comparison to the static directional stability (caused by the tail fin, etc
learning.explanation: Dutch Roll Dutch roll is a coupled lateral and directional oscillation which is undesirable because of the oscillatory nature. Dutch roll can occur when the static lateral stability (caused by dihedral, etc.) is high in comparison to the static directional stability (caused by the tail fin, etc.) Asymmetric shockwaves Modern transport jet aircraft tend to cruise at high altitudes with high Mach numbers, very close to - or just inside - the transonic regime. This is the range of speeds (At and above MCRIT) where some of the aircraft experiences supersonic airflow, but not all the aircraft does. This brings rise to shockwaves, first on the upper wing surfaces near the roots, then spreading to other areas of the aircraft. Shockwaves produce quite high drag forces, classed as "wave drag". If the shockwaves form asymmetrically on the aircraft, whether due to different airflow patterns over the wings, small differences in the aircraft structure, control surfaces, etc., then the different drag forces can cause a yawing motion, which sets off the oscillation known as Dutch roll. This Dutch roll would be made worse by the shockwaves forming on the faster wing, reducing lift and increasing drag to drop it down and drag it back, exacerbating the Dutch roll.

content.question: The aft CG limit can be determined by the:

options.A: minimum acceptable elevator deflection.
options.B: maximum elevator deflection available.
options.C: minimum acceptable static longitudinal stability.
options.D: maximum static longitudinal stability required.

key_points: A variation of CG position can cause large changes in the static longitudinal stability
In the conventional airplane configuration, the large changes in stability with CG variation are primarily due to the large changes in the wing contribution
As the CG is gradually moved aft, the airplane static stability decreases, then becomes neutral then unstable
learning.explanation: A variation of CG position can cause large changes in the static longitudinal stability. In the conventional airplane configuration, the large changes in stability with CG variation are primarily due to the large changes in the wing contribution. As the CG is gradually moved aft, the airplane static stability decreases, then becomes neutral then unstable. The CG position which produces zero slope and neutral static stability is referred to as the “neutral point”. The aft limit, which for safety reasons on a transport airplane is always forward of the neutral point, is confined by insufficient stick-force stability and/or excessive in-flight maneuverability (minimum acceptable stability). The minimum stick force per ‘g’ for the maximum permitted load factor, which is 2.5 for large transport airplanes, determines the aft limit of the CG envelope. A CG position aft of this point would produce an unacceptably low value of maneuver stability and would make the airplane difficult to fly. For transport airplanes the aft limit is normally located at approximately 30% of the MAC.

key_points: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium
It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time

Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes
learning.explanation: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium. It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time. Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes. An airplane that is statically stable is not necessarily dynamically stable. However, for an airplane to be dynamically stable it must be statically stable. In other words, it cannot have long-term stability without first having short-term stability. An airplane that has positive static stability may be dynamically neutral, stable, or unstable; but an airplane that is statically unstable can never attain dynamic stability. The dynamic stability of an airplane is dependent on the airplane design, its speed, and the altitude at which it is flying. There are five states of dynamic stability and for each of them the airplane must have positive static stability. Negative dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation increases with the passage of time. Neutral dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation remains constant with the passage of time. Positive dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation decreases with the passage of time. ‘Dead beat’ positive dynamic stability – the oscillations cease immediately because they are heavily damped. ‘Divergent’ negative dynamic stability – the oscillations cease because the motion completely diverges from the original motion.
